PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. In view of the Australian Mining Industry Council's blunt refusal to take at face value Commonwealth assurances that its proposed Mabo legislation will validate all previous titles, will the minister now settle this matter once and for all and give the Senate an unequivocal assurance that all past titles for land will be fully secured and will not be affected by native title? Further, is it correct that, even where a possibly invalid mining lease is validated, native title rights will not be extinguished and will be restored at the end of the lease so that any proposed extension will need to be negotiated and paid for by mining companies?

—The mining industry, like industry and investors generally, does need predictability and security. That is exactly what this legislation is all about. We will allow validation of any existing grant which may have been invalid because of the existence of native title, including all rights under those grants, including rights of renewal.

PARA.TAB: We have said all along that our legislation deals with the concerns of the states and industry that as a result of the Mabo decision there may be invalid grants. There is no point in legislating to validate grants that are already valid and there is no point, accordingly, in the legislation addressing that issue. AMIC's position does appear to be based on misconceptions about the government's proposals.

The legislation protects the rights of all existing titleholders. It does allow, as I have said, validation of existing grants, including rights of renewal. Any grant of interest in land which is invalid because of the existence of native title will be validated or able to be validated by the states and territories as a result of this bill.

The legislation does not give native titleholders any new veto, de facto or otherwise. They will have the right to negotiate on actions affecting their land, but in no way do the tight but very fair provisions for negotiation and arbitration, if necessary by a tribunal, constitute a veto. There will be stringent criteria for registration of claimants to avoid delays through vexatious claims. Nowhere have we ever proposed that consideration of native title will have to precede other approval processes, which seems to be another thing that is worrying the industry. That is a complete misconception of our proposals.

Again, the revival of native title after mining leases expire is hardly a source of uncertainty because any native title will be subject to the grant during its life and the life of any legitimate renewals. Additional conditions or costs will not be imposed on existing exploration and mining titles. Generally, when you put all of that in a pot and look at the total picture, it is evident that we are providing a workable system that will be quite fair both to native titleholders and to the mining industry. Far from driving away investment, we are providing the certainty and the fairness that will encourage it.

What seems to be totally lacking in the appreciation of many commentators, whether fair-minded or otherwise, is an acknowledgment that the Mabo decision itself by the High Court introduced a degree of uncertainty. What the legislation is about is avoiding a protracted process of litigation to test the parameters of that uncertainty. Rather, we will by this legislation resolve a great many of the issues that, in the absence of it, would be left unresolved. That is the reason this legislation does make total sense from the point of view of the mining industry, the pastoral industry, the state governments and anyone else that is seriously minded to deal with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Could the minister table the programmed answer which he has been reading and—
—Pretty unpredictable question, wasn't it?

—In fact, I do not think the second part of it was answered. I ask, firstly, whether the answer given is an assurance that all past titles will be fully secured and not affected by native title. Secondly, do I take it the minister concedes that, at the expiration of a mining lease, it will be necessary to renegotiate and take into account not just any valid claims which might be established in due course but, indeed, as the mining industry says, that applicants for future grants would have to deal not just with native titleholders with proven claims but also with those who merely claim native title? I note that the answer which was read did not deal with that point.

—It was not dealt with because it has been dealt with a dozen times in previous answers. In the case of valid leases, which the legislation is not directly addressing, the government of course believes that the chances of success for any native title claim that may be made in respect of such leases are negligible. The legislation will ensure that the existing rights of those leaseholders are protected. That is because the legislation will validate any rights available to existing leaseholders if they would otherwise be invalid as a result of the existence of native title. So, if there is no prima facie reason whatsoever to believe that the lease or the interest is other than valid to start with—
—Is that a blanket assurance?

—Well, that will be there in the legislation. The capacity will be there; the Commonwealth will do that first up. The states will have the capacity to do that if they choose to; they will be empowered to do so. That is as I understand the intention, and that is what again makes utterly inexplicable the approach taken by Richard Court. If we do not legislate to close off these particular avenues, create certainty through the legislative package that we are creating, we will leave ourselves open for endless litigation and endless uncertainty. That is the virtue of the Commonwealth legislation.

PARA.TAB: There are a few other virtues to go with it, namely, the Commonwealth will pick up most of the tab for compensation. There is just no real choice in the matter. What the hell the fuss is about at this stage continues to amaze me. It is all about politics; it is not about reason.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will you table the answer?
—No, I will not table the answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Following the passing of the budget bills in their amended form, can the minister inform the Senate of the current status of the government's medium-term deficit reduction strategy? Are there any implications to be drawn from this for future budget processes and for economic strategy generally?

—I thank Senator Beahan for raising what is an important issue and one which requires, I think, more consideration from some in the opposition in the Senate than it has to date received. The deficit reduction strategy which the Treasurer articulated on 17 August 1993 remains essentially intact. Of the extra revenue sought from the revenue measures passed by the Senate last week, the government will gather in 1996-97 some 97 per cent of the budget night estimate.

PARA.TAB: The importance of this outcome cannot be overstated. We now have in place a medium-term deficit reduction strategy that will deliver progressive deficit reductions over four years: from $16 billion in 1993-94 to about $6 billion in 1996-97—that is, about one per cent of GDP in future.

As I have pointed out on several occasions to those who have paid any attention—and who now happily constitute a majority in the Senate, even if not all—international financial opinion, including that of the IMF, has placed great emphasis on governments having established credible medium-term fiscal strategies. They recognise the need to have a short-term increase in deficit for stimulus purposes. But they do believe it is very important that we have a medium-term deficit reduction strategy to deal with questions about interest rates—because a failure to do so would put up the pressure for increased interest rates—and to reduce the scope for capital formation and job creation. A failure to do so would lower the growth of output and income.
Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I believe most Australians, even if not the opposition, think those are issues worthy of serious consideration. I think they are concerned about interest rates. I think they are concerned about jobs, about investment and about output and income. Of course, they take as much notice of those interjections as I am proposing to do.

PARA.TAB: Australia is one of the few industrial nations that has put a credible medium-term fiscal situation in place. Other countries have tried to do so. For example, the very valiant efforts of the President of the United States have brought that country's deficit target for 1996-97 down to three per cent of GDP, whereas ours by 1996-97 will be approximately one per cent of GDP. Locking such a strategy firmly into place is very important. The business community recognises that it is important and welcomes it, because it knows that it provides certainty—certainty to plan, to invest and to expand. In achieving that outcome, the minor parties in the Senate have played a key role.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're the minor party in the Senate.

—More people voted for my party in the Senate last time than for the opposition. Senator Macdonald should look at the arithmetic. In looking to the future and the new issues and challenges that will inevitably emerge, the Treasurer has indicated the need to establish processes that allow a continuing constructive role for those parties. I welcome that. A more open budget development process will be a bit of a test for all of us—a test for the budget development process and for our democratic processes. I think it is a very worthwhile endeavour. It can give us an improved budget process and, if it comes to pass, an improved budget outcome. The medium-term deficit reduction strategy is in place. It is important and it is welcomed by responsible commentators. Everybody except those opposite always knew that it was a good idea, and they will eventually wake up.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Minchin Sen N.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer to the Attorney-General's answer to a question on Mabo in the House of Representatives last Wednesday in which he said:

QUESTION.PARA: I think it is the balance of legal opinion . . . that a valid issuing of a leasehold interest by a government would have extinguished native title.

If the government accepts that this is the case, why will it not simply end any possible uncertainty concerning pastoral leases and include provisions in its proposed legislation that will confirm, by statute, that legal opinion?

TALK.START.PARA: —I said a moment ago that it is the government's judgment that the chances of success for a native title claim in any such context would, in our view, be negligible. The right to pursue an action through the courts, however, is one open to all Australians, whether they are likely to succeed or not. The government has been absolutely adamant, and remains so, that native title claimants should be able to do what all other Australians can do.

PARA.TAB: The opposition really is showing its true colours by running an argument that essentially would deny Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples the fundamental right to take legal action simply because of the effect it might have on other Australians. I repeat that the government believes that the real effect on other Australians will be negligible and certainly does not justify this kind of assault on routine individual rights.

What is very interesting in this respect is how, increasingly obviously, Dr Hewson, in his leadership of the party, is being isolated on this issue and progressively disowned by members of his own party. Even Richard Court, according to Dr Hewson this morning, has moved on from a referendum—which is something that Dr Hewson himself has not discarded.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The question related to earlier assurances that title would be secured. Senator Minchin is asking why the government has departed from that position. It has nothing to do with what Dr Hewson might say or what Premier Court says. The minister should answer the question that he was asked.

—The balance struck by this legislation, as we have said over and over again, is to take as given title which on the face of it is valid and not purport to do anything to remove people's rights in relation to that, on either side—just let people take any course of action they might choose to. What we do need to do to remove uncertainty is to take action right now to validate those titles which are—if there are any—manifestly invalid right now so as to ensure continuity of economic use of the land in question and to make provision, as I said in answer to Senator Alston a moment ago, to validate any title that might be found invalid by a court as a result of some process initiated by Aboriginal claimants based upon native title.

PARA.TAB: If those opposite are not satisfied with a process that produces that result, which makes provision right now for the validation of titles which are now invalid and which makes provision for the validation of titles which may be found invalid, they are simply incapable of satisfaction by any reasonable argument. That view is taken by their own party members. Former senators Chaney and Durack have a civilised appreciation of the balance that has to be struck here.

Even Alexander Downer was showing some signs of sensitivity in his response in a media interview this morning which was repeated in the Australian Financial Review. It is about time that those who are continuing to run this campaign, mainly from the benches in here and with an extraordinary degree of stridency, understood the extent to which they are out of step with the more enlightened opinion both in their own party and across the length and breadth of this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I am sorry that my simple question got the minister so excited. Is it not a fact that there will be nothing in the legislation which will in any way immunise valid—that is, pre-1975—leaseholders from potentially successful challenge in the courts by any native title claimant believing that his or her rights still coexist with the rights of existing leaseholders?
—I can do no more than repeat what I have already said. The legitimate interest that existing interest holders in land have—

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Minchin asked the supplementary question.

—The legitimate interest that holders of interests in land have, be they pastoral, mining leases or anything else, is that they have a presumption of continuity and are able to continue without interference the economic use of the land which they have been granted by proper process in the past. They will be assured that as a result of the operation of this legislation.

PARA.TAB: Aboriginal claimants are not stupid and are not going to waste time, money and emotional energy pursuing claims that obviously have not got a hope in Hades of succeeding, but nonetheless it is conceivable that in some cases claims will be pursued in order perhaps to clarify the native title status of some common law reservation, statutory reservation or something of that kind. It is conceivable that a claim of that kind might be pursued in order to establish the extent to which the native title interest can live alongside the previous valid interest. In order to cover that situation, the legislation provides exactly as I have stated. There is no ground for uncertainty there either.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Trade to recent press reports of the current state of play in the Uruguay Round negotiations and efforts under way to break the current impasse, including the Prime Minister's efforts at CHOGM and Senator Cook's lobbying in Europe following the recent Cairns Group meeting in Geneva. Can the minister inform the Senate what his discussions with his European counterparts revealed of the present attitude to the Uruguay Round in Europe and, in particular, whether there is any sign of a shift in the French position?

—I should say first that my discussions with Mickey Kantor, my US counterpart, on 14 October were extremely fruitful. He has promised, as he said at a joint press conference at the conclusion of our talks, for the US to work with the Cairns Group and Australia and for him to work with me on completing the Uruguay Round and on securing the Blair House accord in its current form. He has undertaken that we will be involved—that is, the Cairns Group—in any talks that might come in the future over that agreement. He is not in favour of reopening or watering down the Blair House accord.

PARA.TAB: In the discussions in Europe, we first began on 18 October with a Cairns Group meeting. That has positioned the Cairns Group as the third force in the multilateral trade negotiations in the world and sharpened our tactics for the end game. In Europe, we lobbied in Paris, Bonn and Brussels. We saw governments in all those cities and had extensive media coverage internationally, nationally and in the city press of the cities that we were in.

The question is about especially France. Until now, the debate in France has been one-sided. There are signs that it is now turning. In recent days, former French Prime Minister, Raymond Barre, former French President, Valery Giscard d'Estaing, and the current president of the European Commission, Jacques Delors, have all said things in the French debate in France which are helpful to a conclusion of the round in a balanced way.

Indeed, the wine and spirits exporters have also come out supporting the round and, coming from the agricultural stable, that is quite significant for France. Recently, the SOFRES poll in France indicated that 48 per cent of French voters thought that the round would end with France signing the agreement, even though it was unsatisfactory for French interests. It should be remembered that four per cent of the French economy is devoted to agriculture and six per cent of the work force derive employment from agriculture. A completion of the round for the French economy would be worth in US dollars $25 billion, in French francs $150 billion, in extra income, and it would create half a million jobs in France. These figures are now increasingly part of the public debate.

Elsewhere in Europe there is a view that for the round to be successfully completed `something' has to be given for France. I do not know what all that means but I think it comes down to this: the signs are that there could be some sort of change. I do not know what that change will be; it will depend on something happening. Australia and the Cairns Group will be involved in any of those ongoing debates about that and we will play our role in order to protect the interests of the agriculture fraternity in Australia and the best interests of our trade account in this country.

The next most important dates are Friday of this week when there will be a special European summit—I do not expect that will deal with GATT; it will deal with Maastricht—and 8 November when there will be a European Council meeting which I do expect will deal with GATT issues. Meanwhile, on the US side, the NAFTA bill goes to Congress shortly. It will be out, on the predicted timetable now, on the 17th. So we are shaping up to a last round of the Uruguay Round in the last month. That will be crunch time. We have positioned ourselves, I think, to exert as much influence as we could ever be expected to exert in order to get a good outcome for this round completed on timetable by 15 December and to ensure that the outcome is not a partial solution but a global package which features agriculture in a bold and balanced outcome for the round.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Has the minister seen media reports quoting Australia's former ambassador to China, Professor Ross Garnaut, as suggesting that Australia should be less active on human rights issues in the Asia region if it is to succeed in closer economic ties with Asia? Does the minister agree with the assessment that Australia's trading and commercial interests are more important than human rights concerns? Can the minister describe the type of human rights abuses on which Australia can or should take a softer approach when dealing with other nations in this region?

—I have not seen the full text of Professor Garnaut's reported remarks and I do not think it would be fair to him, under those circumstances, to seek to respond directly to what he is reported as saying. So far as the government's own position is concerned, it really is as has been stated on many occasions, and that is that our concern about human rights takes its place as one of a number of issues that we seek to pursue in a balanced and total way in our relations with all our regional neighbours.

PARA.TAB: We do, of course, regard trade and political relations as important. We regard as important our capacity to influence our neighbours on matters of traditional political diplomacy and matters of trade and economic policy. Our capacity to be influential in that respect depends, among other things, on our willingness to approach those issues, as others, in a reasonable and balanced way. But, at the end of the day, none of those concerns will stop us raising human rights issues where we believe it is appropriate and likely to be productive to do so.

The judgment we make about the effectiveness of the action will often determine the precise nature of the action that is taken—whether it is a public statement that is made or a private representation; whether it is an exercise in seeking to apply economic sanctions, or whether it is simply the taking of political action; whether it is doing things bilaterally or whether it is trying to do things multilaterally. It will all depend on the particular circumstances of the individual case.

There is no attempt on our part to walk away, in any respect, from the obligations that we see as being on ourselves and all other members of the international community, both to observe for ourselves the standards of human rights that are set out in the international declarations and covenants and also our responsibility to urge upon other members of the international community that they respond likewise.

It is my very firm belief that this approach that Australia has taken is well understood in the region, that it has been increasingly effective in recent years, and that it has not prejudiced our capacity to work with other countries in a balanced and effective way on a whole variety of other strategies in the region. The government certainly has no intention of accepting advice from any quarter to moderate to any greater degree than we are at the moment our human rights stance. Our judgment, I repeat, will be based always on the likely effectiveness of that stance, not on any anxiety about its implications for other policy areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Defence. Did the Australian Army sell a Special Air Services building used for the live firing of ammunition and known in military terms as `the slaughterhouse' to the Western Australian police force some time over the past three years? If so, what was the purchase price? Was the building transported from the Commonwealth property and, if so, when? Was Commonwealth assistance used to facilitate this purchase to the Western Australian police force?

—Over the past five years Defence has constructed new special training facilities for the Special Air Services regiment at Swanbourne, Western Australia. As the new facilities are being delivered, temporary facilities constructed in 1979 for interim use have become surplus to requirement. I am advised that two old facilities—a room and a floor combat range, and an aircraft mock-up range—were transferred to the Western Australian police. These are essentially small steel-lined buildings used for live firing during close quarter battle training. The buildings had no further Defence use and had a sale value less than the cost associated with demolition and site clean up.

PARA.TAB: The Western Australian police expressed an interest in acquiring the facilities for special police training. The facilities were transferred to the Western Australian police at no cost and moved from Swanbourne under WA police arrangements in early February 1993. The Western Australian police paid $2,393 to DAAS Asset Services for a quantity of stratmit, which is a straw lining used for range maintenance. No direct Commonwealth assistance was provided in this matter.

The standing advisory committee on Commonwealth-state cooperation for the protection against violence provided $30,000 this year to each state police force for the development of special ranges in support of their role in the national anti-terrorist plan. The Western Australian police may apply some of these funds to refurbish these ranges to reasonable working order.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Fitzroy Island and Green Island Resorts

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Tourism. I draw the minister's attention to the Mabo style claim by the Gungandji people for the Fitzroy Island and Green Island tourist resorts—both prominent tourist attractions off Cairns. What effect will these claims have on investment in these and other nationally significant tourist resorts on the Queensland coast? Has the minister had discussions with the owners of Green Island resort on the effects that these claims might have on current upgrading work on Green Island? Is the minister aware that the uncertainty surrounding these claims affects the market value of these tourist properties and others even if the claim is not ultimately successful?

—I do have some information, but, in prefacing this information, I must say that this is a typical question that one would expect from Senator Ian Macdonald from Queensland who is just about scaremongering to adversely affect the Australian tourism industry.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators—Who is scaremongering?

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those opposite for that interjection. If we are talking about scaremongering, Senator Macdonald's performance in the last election campaign was probably worth about five seats for us in trying to explain the GST.
—Order! You should be relevant to the question that was asked, Senator Schacht.

—The information provided by my colleague Minister Lee is as follows: the government has finalised its response to the Mabo judgment which ensures development and investment can continue with certainty over existing titles. The federal government has brokered an historic agreement between Aboriginal Australians and industry groups. The resulting agreement gives certainty over validated titles and will allow the states and territories to validate freehold, residential and commercial leases which generally underpin tourism operations, extinguishing that native title.

PARA.TAB: Aboriginal groups which establish native title over these areas will be eligible for compensation from extinguishment of their native title rights. Other more minor grants, such as permits to visit particular islands and reefs, will also be validated but normally will not extinguish native title, although, when existing permits expire, they will be subject to negotiation with native title owners prior to their renewal.

The claimed area includes significant tourism infrastructure on Green and Fitzroy islands and reefs and seas used extensively by tour operators. The claim excludes freehold land while reserving a position in regard to leasehold property. The claimants have indicated that the lodging of their writ is a defensive measure to highlight their interest in the claimed area.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I would like Senator Schacht to confirm whether he said that native title will not be extinguished over Green Island. Will the minister also confirm—this relates directly to his portfolio and the tourism industry—what effect Mabo style claims on the Great Barrier Reef will have on the work of the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority and the Australian Institute of Marine Science? Will the government be doing anything with the reef tax to pay compensation claims in relation to the Great Barrier Reef? If not, where will the government be getting the money from to pay compensation?

—In the six months that I have been a minister that supplementary question must be the closest thing to gibberish that I have heard. The question was all over the place. Clearly Senator Ian Macdonald tried to construct something in 15 seconds flat by putting together 37 different loose thoughts. He failed miserably. As far as I can detect any theme in that question that relates to tourism, I will refer it to the Minister for Tourism. As to the other areas, if I can ascertain what was meant, I will try to get more information. But I will have to read the question very carefully because it struck me as being total gibberish.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and relates to the budget of the United Nations. What is the Australian Government's evaluation of the determination of the Congress of the United States to reduce US funding for the United Nations regular budget and for peacekeeping operations? What impact will this decision have on the ability of the United Nations to live up to increased expectations which the international community now has for that organisation's role in the maintenance of international peace and security? Finally, how will this decision influence necessary organisational reform in the UN—a goal which the government of the United States has publicly stated it shares?

—The Australian government believes that all UN member states, without exception, should pay their assessed contributions in full and on time as is our practice. It is a basic obligation for member states under the UN charter to make these payments.

PARA.TAB: The Australian government is concerned that the 1994 budget bills passed by the US Congress last week, 21 October, will mean that the US will, in fact, drop further behind in its payments of UN regular budget and peacekeeping contributions. This can only have a negative impact on the ability of the UN to fulfil the heightened expectations that now exist of its role in the maintenance of international peace and security. Nor do I believe that the conditions that have been set by the US are likely, in practice, to contribute much that is helpful to the UN reform process. I will come to that point if I have time at the finish.

The government is aware that the Clinton administration is working very hard to improve the US record in making financial contributions to the UN and we very much appreciate that the challenge that it is facing in this respect is coming more from Congress than from inside its own administration ranks. In fact, the Clinton administration on 6 October made a very substantial contribution of something over $500 million to clear the US pre-1993 regular budget arrears, and to also make a substantial payment towards its peacekeeping arrears. The trouble is, however, that new obligations continue to accrue, in particular, so far as peacekeeping operations are concerned, of which currently 17 such operations are in progress.

Last week the administration requested the US Congress to appropriate $291 million for its 1993 regular budget payment and $66 million as a contribution to catching up on its arrears to the UN and a range of specialised agencies which were accumulated during the 1980s. President Bush had undertaken to clear those arrears by 1995. President Clinton himself repeated that commitment, including in his recent address to the UN General Assembly.

Last week Congress appropriated the $291 million for the 1993 regular budget, but directed that 10 per cent of this figure should be withheld, pending the appointment by the Secretary-General of an inspector-general as a watchdog against fraud and waste. It also decided to cancel entirely the $66 million in repayment of arrears. Moreover, so far as peacekeeping is concerned, the administration sought $619 million for peacekeeping operations in the year ahead, which was itself something of a low estimate, given that the anticipated requirement of the US will be in the order of $1.2 billion.

Congress has appropriated only $401.6 million of that and, in the process, directed the US administration to continue to work to reduce the US share of new peacekeeping operations to no more than 25 per cent of the total, whereas the United States' current assessment is 31.7 per cent. What all that means in hard percentage terms is that the US Congress has made provision for only about 30 per cent of the likely US UN peacekeeping bill this year. It has withheld 10 per cent of the US assessment to the regular budget and it has not made provision for any arrears payment in 1994.

As to the implications of all this for UN reform, which is part of the justification for the congressional attitude, let me say that while we certainly agree with a number of the specific objectives the US has in this respect—in particular, we are sympathetic to the proposal to appoint an inspector-general to combat fraud and waste—we do, nonetheless, take the strong view that reform can occur only in an atmosphere of mutual confidence based on member countries meeting their obligations. The UN really would become unworkable and consensus for reform unachievable if countries withdrew unilaterally their financial support. We certainly hope that the majority of members of Congress will recognise that the United States' capacity to influence UN reform simply is not aided by a failure to meet its financial obligations to the UN.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. I refer the minister to the Treasurer's claim in yesterday's Australian Financial Review that compensation costs arising from Mabo would be only around $100 million. In the light of the Prime Minister's statement that the compensation bill would be at least hundreds of millions of dollars and in light of the minister's own statement to the Senate last week that his expectation was that the sum would be very small, could the minister indicate on what basis the Treasurer has claimed that the bill will be only around $100 million? Is the Treasurer's statement based on some Treasury prediction or analysis?

—I do not know. I will have to find out what basis the Treasurer may have had in mind in making that statement. The point of the matter is, however, as I said in answer to a similar question directed to me last week, that any assessment of compensation payable for validation, if that should prove necessary at all, must necessarily be a guesstimate at this stage. It is only likely to even begin to arise in the context of the maximum of 11 pastoral leases in north-west Australia. That is really the only context in which it seems likely that any compensation payment could arise at all.

PARA.TAB: No-one can have any confident basis on which to make any assumption about any particular payment. One can make only informed guesses, and the assumptions on which those guesses are made may vary from person to person, depending on whether one takes into account legal and administrative costs as well as the final payment, or some notional monetary value for perhaps non-monetary compensation that is made part of the package. I simply cannot add anything—and I doubt whether the Treasurer will be able to—to those guesses that have been made; they remain such. We are quite frank and open in acknowledging that they are guesses and there is no basis on which anyone needs to get alarmed, excited or have his or her hormones racing again—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Alston should stay under control. It is okay. He does not have to worry about it. It is not a matter for concern for any of the industry groups that are concerned. The compensation, if it is payable, will have to be paid by government. That is frankly acknowledged.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In the spirit of the minister's frankness and openness, I would hope that if there are any Treasury predictions or analyses, he will table those in the Senate. While he is inquiring of the Treasurer as to the whereabouts of that analysis, if it exists, could he also inquire as to whether or not these compensation payments will be classified, within the meaning of Part IIIA of the Income Tax Assessment Act, as being capital gains and would be subject to tax in the same way that the tax office ruled in April 1993 that compensation payments made to the south-west farmers in Western Australia would also be subject to capital gains tax?
—I will see what, if any, comment the Treasurer might have on that question.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development. I preface my question by welcoming the announcement by industry Minister Alan Griffiths that the government is now going to pursue a more activist industry policy on a sector by sector basis, albeit with a `light' touch. I ask the minister: first, will the government establish permanent industry councils comprising business, union and government with a task to develop and implement strategic industry plans for each sector; and, secondly, is there any reason why these bodies cannot be established before next year's industry statement by the minister? Will the minister initiate action to establish these bodies right now?

—I am pleased that Senator Spindler has brought to the notice of the Senate the major statement made by my colleague the Minister for Industry, Technology and Regional Development, Mr Griffiths, on the preparation of an industry statement by early next year. The minister has indicated that he will be seeking to consult with and obtain the views of industry, unions, state and regional governments and the academic community—they will all be given an opportunity to have an input into the process of developing that statement. It will be an inclusive process, not an exclusive one. I would suggest that, in view of Senator Spindler's role as shadow spokesman for the Australian Democrats in this area, he may well consider putting his views forward as well. I am sure that he will use the opportunity.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the specific question about the establishment of industry councils comprising business, unions and government, that is not specifically mentioned in the range of areas to be considered. The minister has made it clear, because he wants full consultation, that if people genuinely raise that proposal as a way for industry to develop, that will be considered on its merits. I would imagine that there may be people other than Senator Spindler who would be willing to raise that particular proposal.

There are now many industry groups, networks and clusters developing where industry of its own volition has realised that it is better to come together and work collaboratively to develop industry. They have had outstanding success. Of course, as a group, those organisations have not relied on the old ideas of high protection and high tariffs to develop their industry. They want to develop an internationally competitive industry that can stand on its own, both within Australia and with the rest of the world. That particular area will be part of the discussion if people choose to raise it. I am sure that they will. We will not be pre-empting anything in the statement before it is ready next year, because obviously that would affect the consultative process.
In conclusion, the investment climate for industry in Australia at the moment is very good.

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha—a million unemployed.

—Senator Ian Macdonald may laugh; he cannot help himself; he only opens his mouth to change feet. Low interest rates, a very competitive exchange rate and a new company tax rate of 33c in the dollar are some of the measures that are very useful for encouraging industry to invest. In view of Senator Macdonald's remarks, I would point out to the Senate that last night minister Griffiths and I attended the annual awards for small business in Australia—a very successful awards ceremony. The enthusiasm of those people from the small business community to get on with the job of developing their business and Australia is something that the opposition should take note of, rather than continually going around whingeing, whining and putting Australia down.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Health. Now that the minister has said that he will urge the Prime Minister to take out private health insurance, will the minister also be urging all of his ministerial colleagues without private health cover, together with the ALP minister for health in the ACT, Wayne Berry, who said today on the ABC that he refused to take out private health cover, to stop expecting that their health bills will be paid for by the taxes of Australia's battlers?

—I have gone to great lengths, more times than I can now recall, to defend the Prime Minister's statement that he was relying upon Medicare. I did so on the basis that the opposition, the AMA and the health funds had embarked upon a campaign to undermine the faith that Australians have in their health system. The Prime Minister felt at the height of that campaign that the very best way to make sure that he could assist them to attain, acquire or keep the faith was to prove it by suggesting that he and his family were going to rely on it—that if it was good enough for the Prime Minister, it would be good enough for everyone else.

PARA.TAB: Senator Herron interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —I might say to Senator Herron that, for all the interjections, the great shame for him is that time and time again Australia has endorsed Medicare—five elections in a row. Senator Herron has not got the message yet, but hope does spring eternal. Senator Bishop has now acknowledged the virtues of bulk-billing. Senator Bishop and the National Party—what a combination! Those opposite will never resist it.

PARA.TAB: That having been said, I have been preparing a package on private health insurance. In my view, we cannot continue to have private health insurance bleed in the way that is has in the past years because this does increase the strains on the public system. That being the case, one of the things that I will probably be suggesting in a package that I shall put to my party later on in the year will include a levy for those on higher incomes in lieu of private health insurance. If that is the case, then, of course, the Prime Minister will have the same choice as everybody else on higher incomes—to take it or not take it, as the case may be.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. The establishment of the National Rail Corporation as the sole provider of interstate rail freight services has been a major element of the federal government's program of micro-economic reform. Can the minister advise the Senate what progress has been made in setting up National Rail as a viable commercial entity?

—National Rail began its operations in February this year. From that time it has been progressively transferring the interstate activities of state rail systems into its own organisation. All freight terminals, except Kewdale in Western Australia, are now under the direct control of National Rail and are staffed by National Rail employees.

PARA.TAB: National Rail has, in the last few weeks, taken control of the deployment of wagons around the National Rail system and in November will be running its first trains operated by National Rail crew. The transfer of wagons, locomotives and other assets will accelerate into 1994.

National Rail has also developed new industrial arrangements which herald a new era of efficient operating practices in the rail industry. National Rail emphasises multiskilling and the formation of independent work teams who cover the full range of tasks at their facility. National Rail employees have welcomed these new arrangements, which they find far more interesting and challenging.

It is significant that we were advised last Friday at the board meeting of National Rail that these industrial arrangements are now securely in place and now form the basis for commercial rail operations. This is important because this confirmation, which was formally taken at the board meeting on Friday, allows the release of cash equity funds for investment in capital projects. The Commonwealth has contributed $290 million of this equity pool. National Rail is therefore now in a position to commence an $800 million capital investment program over the next five years. An early priority of this capital program will be to install facilities and equipment which will improve the speed and reliability of services provided to National Rail customers.

The freight terminals in particular will be immediately upgraded with six container forklifts being acquired over the next three months and four gantry cranes operating around the country by April 1994. Track alignments and hard stand areas will also be immediately improved and expanded. Major terminal works will commence at Acacia Ridge, the Melbourne steel terminal and at the new Enfield rail freight terminal in Sydney. The five-year capital program will also involve investments in acquisition of new rolling stock, enhancement of rolling stock maintenance facilities, upgrading of train control facilities centred in Adelaide and improved information technology.

Honourable senators should also be aware that this capital program is quite separate from the One Nation rail investment program which is now well under way. Under One Nation, over $100 million was spent last financial year and a further $300 million will be spent by the end of this financial year. These developments represent major steps forward in the establishment of an efficient, reliable and seamless interstate freight service which for so long has eluded this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. Can the minister confirm the invitation from Japan for Australia to make submissions to two government advisory bodies, the Office of Trade and Investment Ombudsman and the MITI Import Board, in respect of market access for Australian products? If this is the case, can the minister advise whether the issue of rice imports into Japan was included in the submission; and if not, why not?
—I do not have any information on that matter. I will make inquiries and get back to Senator Brownhill.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Science and Small Business. As the minister would be aware, recently the Leader of the Opposition in South Australia, Mr Brown, latched onto alleged criticisms that have been made about Multifunction Polis Australia. In particular, he referred to a report in the Sydney Morning Herald claiming a lack of Japanese investment interest. Do these criticisms have any basis or are they just another example of Mr Brown talking down the MFP and the South Australian economy?
—This'll be good; listen to this!

—This is just for you, Amanda. Senator Vanstone and I are fellow South Australians. I have been amazed at the comments made by Dean Brown, the Leader of the Opposition in South Australia, latching onto, as Senator Foreman said, criticism by one particular journalist in a couple of newspapers in Australia about two weeks ago, claiming that the Japanese were pulling out completely from the MFP.

PARA.TAB: Last week, with the Chief Executive of MFP Australia, Mr Ross Kennan, I attended a seminar for the companies in Japan interested in being involved in the MFP. We both attended a seminar for several hours and spoke to representatives of about 40 companies that had indicated their interest. Not one of those companies indicated in any way that it wished to pull out of the MFP. They indicated that they wanted their commitment to continue, but they were honest enough to point out that, because Japan has gone into a recession, Japanese business at the moment is very wary about investing anywhere, let alone in the MFP.

TALK.START.PARA: —Aha!

—They have difficulty investing even in Japan, Senator Hill. They made the point that as Japan comes out of the recession, interest will therefore grow amongst Japanese companies to look at investment opportunities, including the MFP. They made it quite clear that it would be extraordinarily short-sighted for Australia or some Australian politicians to go around talking down the MFP, trying to bring it to a very sudden end. In fact, some of them were astonished that Australian politicians, for parochial or short-term supposed political advantage, would go around bagging this project.

PARA.TAB: I was very pleased with the discussions I had with the Japanese business representatives, and so was Mr Kennan. We would anticipate that in the next few days, Mr Kennan, on his return from Japan and Korea, will be able to make announcements about a commitment made by Japanese and Korean companies plus Australian companies to the establishment of an Australian-Asian business centre as one of the MFP projects in Adelaide.

Mr Kennan also made progress on a commitment to establishing a project called `the intelligent precinct'. This project is all about providing people in their homes with access to the latest data information through fibre-optic cable—again, another major project.
I am very pleased to be able to report to the Senate that, despite the carping of the opposition in South Australia, the MFP does have commitment from the Japanese companies—

TALK.START.PARA: —Hang on! You said you didn't have any commitment.

—No; commitment in interest. Some people, like Senator Hill, have gone around speaking of commitment on investment. The Japanese companies are committed to the project. They make it clear that the investment climate in Japan has been affected by the recession; but, as they come out of the recession, the opportunities will increase for both their companies and other international companies.

PARA.TAB: I am just appalled that, for narrow political reasons, Mr Brown will go out of his way to wreck a project that has great benefit in the long term not only for South Australia but also for Australia as a whole.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services. I refer to the Acting Prime Minister's shameful response to the Burdekin report on people with mental illness in which he said, firstly, that funding is not the issue and money is not the answer; secondly, that the government will not approach the states until March 1994; and, thirdly, that much of the report is anecdotal and not based on any expert study. Does the minister support this blatant repudiation of Mr Burdekin's findings? Does the minister stand by his own claims made in the Senate when he said, firstly, that it would be difficult for any government to look at the Burdekin report and not realise that more money had to be spent; secondly, that additional Commonwealth funds were inevitable; and, thirdly, that Burdekin showed there was a paucity of services right across the nation?

—It is certainly the case that the Burdekin report on mental health is, to say the least, disturbing—and I do not resile from that at all. It is a powerful statement of the needs of people with psychiatric disability and their families and, as such, I think it has value.

PARA.TAB: I think where it does not have all the strength of some other reports made over previous years is that it does not give any detailed policy response or blueprints for governments as to what action they may wish to take in response to it. I think the Acting Prime Minister is correct in saying that we need to be very careful indeed as to how we respond to it. That is why we will have an interdepartmental committee which will go through that report line by line and make sure that we can find the right solutions. On the question of money—

TALK.START.PARA: —More money?

—Just a minute—be patient. Take three deep breaths; I am getting there. When it comes to money, I indicated the other day that, if more money were required at the end of that process, I am sure it would be found. I stand by that statement; I do not know how else I can put it.

PARA.TAB: I believe that Mr Howe is correct in saying that we do not just throw money at the problem; we will need to find what those innovative, effective solutions might be; and we ought not commit ourselves in any open-ended way to providing money until we have them. Finding those solutions will not be a quick process; it is going to take some time. If, at the end of the day, more Commonwealth money is required, I am sure it will be found.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Does the minister agree with the Client Services Manager at the Sydney City Mission, Ms Joanna Wilcox, who has described Mr Howe's reported dismissal of Mr Burdekin as a `very passionate man' as disgraceful? Is the revelation that Mr Burdekin will not be reappointed when his term expires in December an example of the rather more hard-headed approach that was signalled by Mr Howe last Thursday, or is it just another case of the government shooting the messenger when it does not like the message?

—There is, I think, very considerable scope in looking at the response to the Burdekin report to look at what properly is a state responsibility and what is a Commonwealth responsibility. I think Brian Howe showed some vision and some commitment by getting the Commonwealth back into mental health in a big way by the five-year plan that he announced last year. I support him wholeheartedly in doing it.

PARA.TAB: There is no question that we can point to shortages of care, particularly in supported accommodation, right around the country. I do not think anyone, from Brian Howe down, will dispute that. There will always be some dispute as to which government's responsibility it is to fix the problem, but I do not think anyone can deny that the problem exists. As no-one previously has known, I am not sure yet what the solutions might be.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Colston.
—You haven't answered my supplementary question.

—I have answered it exactly. Mr President. On the last point, about Mr Burdekin, I have not been consulted on what Mr Burdekin's future may be. I have absolutely no idea whether he is being reappointed or not. I do not reappoint him, so why should I be consulted?
—Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—Mr President, I raise a point of order. You had called Senator Colston.

—The Leader of the Government asked that further questions be placed on notice. Senator Richardson had not finished his answer. When he finished his answer, the leader asked that further questions be placed on notice.

—Last Thursday I undertook to provide Senator MacGibbon with further details in regard to the landing of an RAAF B707 aircraft at Fairbairn on Tuesday, 19 October. I am now in a position to provide him with that information.

PARA.TAB: It is neither RAAF policy nor practice to allow unqualified pilots to operate RAAF aircraft during take-off or landing. The pilot who carried out the landing was a fully qualified B707 co-pilot who had recently commenced upgrade training to become a captain. The pilot was under the supervision of a currently fully qualified B707 flying instructor. In accordance with RAAF training policy, available flying hours are fully utilised for the training and development of aircrew. For that reason, on both B707 and Falcon 900 flights which are not carrying a VIP, the co-pilot, who is the backup and safety pilot for the captain, flies the aircraft to develop and retain his or her currency.

In regard to the influence of wind conditions at the time of the incident, I am advised that the cross-wind conditions during the approach on landing were continually monitored by the crew and remained at all times within the published aircraft operating limits. Although conditions were not ideal, the supervising captain assessed that the environmental conditions should have been within the capabilities of the co-pilot. The appropriate repairs to the aircraft were undertaken immediately, resulting in a very minor delay to the departure of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) for CHOGM.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine asked me a question in my capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Development Co-operation and Pacific Island Affairs on 21 October about malaria control in various parts of the world. I seek leave to incorporate what is a quite detailed answer to that question.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Harradine asked me representing the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, on 21 October 1993:
Why has not the Government given a higher priority to malaria control and to the development of vaccines or anti-bodies to alleviate this very serious problem?
My colleague, the Minister for Development Cooperation and Pacific Island Affairs, has provided me with the following answer to the Honourable Senator's question.

PARA.TAB: Health is an important sector within the aid program and increasing emphasis is being placed on malaria interventions. The Government is well aware that malaria is a significant concern among countries receiving Australian aid—particularly in the Pacific. Malaria is a major killer, and of special concern is the increasing resistance of the vector mosquitoes to pesticides, and of the malarial parasite to modern drugs.

ANSWER.PARA: This financial year, approximately $37.4 million will be spent directly on health activities which represents an increase of approximately $8 million over 1991-92 expenditure. In addition, as the PNG program moves from budget support to project aid, it is anticipated that by the turn of the century, that approximately $40 million per year will be spent on health in PNG. These figures do not take into account the funds that are spent indirectly on health through our contributions to the international financial institutions and other multilateral agencies such as UNICEF.

In accordance with internationally accepted health practices, Australian assistance concentrates on integrated, cost effective primary health care interventions. Although most activities are not specifically malaria-oriented, they do make a substantial contribution to the control and treatment of the disease through improved health education, supply of drugs, staff-training and more effective village and township health centres. In addition to supporting primary health care activities, the Government also supports direct malaria control programs in a number of countries.
In the Solomon Islands, Australia has been providing funds since the early 1980s for its malaria control program. This financial year, $500,000 has been allocated to this activity.
In Vanuatu, a total of $147,093 will be provided this financial year for anti-malaria bed-nets.

In the South Pacific, Australia will conduct a joint planning mission with USAID to develop an integrated vector control activity with a strong public health theme to tackle both dengue fever and malaria.

In Vietnam, Australia is currently designing an aid project which will address the malaria problem through the assistance for the manufacture of anti-malaria drugs, early diagnosis and treatment of malaria and the development of new methods for reducing the transmission of malaria. A feasibility study report is currently being prepared and it is estimated that the project will commence in 1994 at a cost of $10 to 15 million over five years.

Australia is also supporting malaria research through the World Health Organisation program for Research and Training in Tropical Diseases (TDR). Forty per cent of TDR's funds are directed to malaria research—including vaccine development. In the 1992-93 financial year, TDR received $539,000 from Australia. Although the 1993-94 contribution to TDR has not been finalised, it is expected that it will be maintained at approximately the same level of funding.

As can be seen, the Government does give high priority to malaria control and research. Australian assistance encompasses primary health care, direct malaria programs, commodity supply and research. This is an area of expansion within the aid program.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter asked me a question on 19 October about uranium. What I can say publicly about this is only that the depleted uranium tails were taken to another country within our agreement network which we are unable to identify on the grounds of commercial confidentiality. It continues to be satisfactorily accounted for in storage under third party agreements which we have with that country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht), to a question without notice asked by Senator Foreman this day, relating to investment in the Multifunction Polis.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Schacht sought to use question time to suggest that the Leader of the Opposition in South Australia, Mr Dean Brown, was talking down the MFP. In fact, Mr Dean Brown is recognising the reality that in all the years of the concept of the MFP, which must be nearly now a decade, there has been not one single financial commitment by a Japanese or overseas company to the project.

PARA.TAB: As I heard in one interview last week, when these expressions of concern were emanating from Japan, as to why there had not been such commitments, the answer that was given—and it is a valid answer—is because there are not any projects in which the Japanese can yet invest. That is the tragedy of this concept—a concept that held great hopes for the future. Despite a decade in which it has been under the control of Labor, it has still not got to the stage where there is any project to which any international investment can be attracted. Surely one has the right to criticise that totally unsatisfactory state of affairs.

The worst error of judgment that was made in relation to the MFP was the selection of the swamp at Gillman as the site. I have it on good authority that when the Japanese delegation came out and was shown the selected site—the site that the Australian side had selected at Gillman, the swamp—they were simply bemused. They could not understand why something that we would want to trumpet as attractive to international investment would have been selected to be planted in a swamp. Unfortunately, that poor judgment has put the total concept of the project years and years behind. This government has committed tens of millions of dollars of taxpayers' money to try to reclaim the swamp in order that a start might be made to the project.

It should be fairly said that we ought to be recognising with appreciation the incredible patience of the Japanese in relation to this matter. They are still committed to the concept of international funds helping to build science and scientific research with an industrial application at the really sharp end of international technology. They are also committed to the concept of partnership between Japan and Australia in that regard and of attracting investment from other countries. But we have let them down.

The trouble with South Australia is that it has been governed by Labor. The state Labor Party has got it wrong in the same way that the federal Labor Party has got it wrong. South Australia has enormous opportunities with its Waite Institute and its research—

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you hate your own state?

—Shut up, will you! The Waite Institute is doing research into plant technology, and artificial intelligence research is being conducted at Flinders University. There are magnificent investment opportunities at The Levels, the old institute of technology, but the money is not being attracted to them because Labor has committed this project to the swamp at Gillman.

PARA.TAB: That is what Mr Brown has said is wrong. He said, `If you can get rid of the concept of the swamp at Gillman and join these institutions in South Australia that have international reputations of the highest level, give them some further capital to help them develop in these areas that are particularly attractive to industry, and offer specific projects to international investors—the Japanese and others—you will have something that you can really develop within the framework of the original concept of the MFP'. If Labor did that, it has a hope of producing real material benefit for Australians.

The way that this project has gone—this government committing the project to the swamp at Gillman, investing tens of millions of Australian taxpayer dollars which have simply been lost—is evidence of appalling misjudgment. That is what Mr Brown has every right to criticise. Under a new Liberal government in South Australia, the project will have a chance of success because it will get back to the area that has the potential to attract real capital. Finally, after all these years, we might start getting some commitment to projects rather than simply commitment to a concept.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am really pleased that the opposition, after about three years of criticising the MFP proposal, has finally come in behind at least one of the substantial arguments against the MFP and has seen that the Gillman site is totally unacceptable for a whole lot of very good environmental reasons.

PARA.TAB: When this proposal was first launched in this chamber by a former senator, Senator Button, we had undertakings from him that no government money—that was repeated on many occasions when I asked questions; I think I asked some 15 questions on this over the years—was going towards this. This proposal was going to be privately driven. As far as I can ascertain, $167 million has been committed to the MFP at the Gillman site, not all of which has been spent. This is a totally unsatisfactory situation which needs to be repaired by pulling the plug on it now and not simply committing more and more funds to it.

The other aspect to this, which evidently the opposition has not yet caught up on, is the way in which this Labor government has repeatedly and consistently, over much longer than a decade, run down Australia's research and development capability. It has done so to the point where it is now going overseas on bended knee to the Japanese and to anybody else and saying, `Please come in and provide us with the technology that we are now no longer capable of developing for ourselves'. Australia has been a remarkably productive country. Senator Hill mentioned a moment ago some of the research institutions in South Australia.

We have been remarkably productive when it comes to basic research. When we have had a piece of basic research which could be turned into some profitable product for sale, we have failed to make the transition through that particular stage. The government needs to come in and recognise those areas and provide assistance. Instead, what this government is doing is further pulling the plug on Australian research and development. The Japanese and other countries that perhaps might be attracted here will take our basic research away and develop it overseas.

Senator Schacht should know from his own publication, which he put out after the budget, that only 0.4 per cent of research and development funds in last year's expenditure in this area came from foreign companies. Foreign companies are not investing in Australia. We have seen absolutely massive salaries paid to those people who are promoting the MFP—public relations merchants, not scientists. That is where the money is going. As Senator Schacht knows, Mr Kennan is being paid $300,000 per year plus a $70,000 bonus. Over the past few months, a number of other very highly paid people have come in to promote this project because clearly it is failing.

It is about time that the government recognised that it is failing and not go after the circuses. It is about time that it pulled the plug on it and put the money into those institutions that desperately need it. It should put the money behind those very good Australian scientists who are working with insufficient funds, who are working in decaying buildings with equipment that is falling into disrepair. The government should then get behind that research work and make sure that developments are developed in Australia and do not go overseas. That is what needs to be done, not this stupid idea of multifunction polises.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the remarks of my colleague Senator Hill on this matter. Indeed, I welcome the remarks made by Senator Coulter who is from my state of South Australia. Senator Schacht, in the dorothy dixer given to his colleague Senator Foreman, was priming up a question which he thought might bring some small amount of embarrassment to his opponents in South Australia; it has blown up in his face. The state of South Australia is directly critical of Premier Arnold and of the minister representing South Australia in this government, Senator Schacht, for their failures to live up to the reality in my state.

PARA.TAB: I wish to make two points. The first concerned the executive officer of the MFP, who has already been referred to and who has a very high salary—about one-quarter more than that received by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). His report, released in the middle of this year, was a very clear, plain speaking and straightforward analysis of the MFP as he discovered it in the three months since he had been appointed to the position. He said that there was a whole lot of hype and nonsense being spoken about the MFP—the project he has been appointed to administer—and he wished to disabuse those who were continuing with that hype. He called for a degree of realism in the way in which this whole project might be furthered.

I see realism in the remarks of my colleague Dean Brown, the Liberal leader in South Australia, who made a clear statement about the reality of this matter in South Australia. I refer not only honourable senators but also members of the press and the Australian public generally to the considered remarks of Mr Kennan, who has been able to look at every element of the MFP. I think Senator Schacht would acknowledge that the realism which has come from that statement must be considered and taken into account, even by him, and he should desist from continuing with the hype and unreality of this matter.

The second and final matter I wish to refer to is the comment made by Dean Brown, which is that any investment that would generate new activities, whether economic or academic, related to an international project such as the MFP ought to be invested by extension to the institutions that already exist in South Australia. South Australia has three excellent universities; a science and technology centre adjacent to one campus of one of the universities at Salisbury; another science and technology centre in the south that is developing and an industry base in various parts of the city and suburbs. It is in these established areas that the MFP ought to gain some real world shape by way of an extension of these already existing facilities.

By all means, let South Australia be at the forefront in this country of fresh investment, especially in advanced technologies and in the extension of research, but let us be realistic about it; let us act upon the advice of the chief executive officer of the MFP, Mr Kennan and let us support the views of Dean Brown and the Liberal Party generally in South Australia. They are quite rightly castigating the federal Labor government and the state Labor government of South Australia for living in a world of hype and, ultimately, of nonsense and of misdirecting energies that could be put to a real world outcome. Let us see developments in South Australia which can be best furthered by the election of a Liberal government in the coming weeks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ferguson Sen A.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues Senator Hill and Senator Teague. I fully understand why the Minister for Science and Small Business (Senator Schacht) is trying to raise this issue today by way of answering a question in order that he might get a bit of political mileage out of it. This is especially so when we consider that his own state Labor colleagues in South Australia are currently agonising over whether they are going to be massacred at the polls before Christmas or whether they will wait until after Christmas. Whether they do it before or after Christmas, the massacre will be the same.

PARA.TAB: In his answer to Senator Foreman the minister said that the Japanese have a commitment to the MFP project but their investments have been affected by the recession. He also said that the Opposition Leader, Dean Brown, has gone out of his way to wreck this project. I will read to the minister what some of his colleagues said in an article in the Advertiser of 16 October. The article was headed `Signs that the MFP won't see the light of day'. It says—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was written by somebody else.
—It was written by somebody else. But the journalist is obviously looking at it in perspective and can see the facts.
—It wasn't one of my colleagues; it was a journalist.
—No, but the minister's colleagues were talked about later on in the article. The article states:

PARA.TAB: At the end of the week, at the end of the debate and at the end of the accusations, it seems that Mr Toshikuni Yahiro does not believe that the $2 billion multifunction polis is progressing satisfactorily. It seems that, despite the protests of Premier Arnold, Mr Yahiro believes it is a victim of the recession.

Present at the meeting were three Labor Mps.
