TALK.START.PARA: —Are they carping whingers too?
—Yes, they are carping whingers. The article continues:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there was little "evidence of the new focus" so often talked about, that there were "a surprisingly small number of projects for which firm commitment has been made to the MFP" and "the committee is concerned at the slow progress of the corporation to date".
The minister's state colleagues agree with the findings of this report.

TALK.START.PARA: —What did they say about Gillman?
—The first thing they said was that there are two holes in the ground at Gillman.
—What did they say about the future? The chairman of the committee said that if there was no Gillman there would be no MFP.
—The minister will get his chance in a minute.
—I just want you to be accurate.
—I am quoting the article quite accurately.
—You have quoted from the Advertiser.
—I am quoting quite accurately what has been reported. The article goes on to state:

PARA.TAB: There are but two holes in the ground at Gillman and the new MFP chief, Ross Kennan, arrived "absolutely dismayed" at the progress made by the project.

SPEECH.PARA: The article further states:

PARA.TAB: The problem is the MFP is looking more like Jurassic Park II, with Steven Spielberg dumped as director and being replaced by Mr Arnold.

SPEECH.PARA: The article then mentions the minister. The minister got a real mention. It states:

PARA.TAB: It is interesting to note Minister for Science Senator Chris Schacht's solid support for the project. Senator Schacht is a former ALP State secretary in SA and a leading member of the dominant Centre Left faction.
The State Government breathed a sigh of hope when the senator was given the portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: I bet it was a big sigh of hope too. It is only hope; that is all they are ever going to get.
The article continues:
Mr Arnold wheeled out the hollow argument this week that it took Japan and France many years to get their equivalents out of the project office and into reality.

If the minister is to criticise what the state leader of South Australia has said he ought to look back and see what some of his state colleagues are saying about the MFP project. It is quite obvious that the remarks made by Dean Brown had been carefully considered in the light of what has happened to the MFP over the last few days and in the light of many of the other issues that have been raised, some by Senator Coulter, with regard to environmental impact of the Gillman site. I await with interest to hear what the minister's comments will be in regard to these matters.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the motion that my question be noted. Firstly, I want to put a couple of things straight with respect to the history of this matter. I fully supported Mr Kennan's remarks made in the middle of this year that the Gillman site was not the only focus for the MFP. As the federal minister responsible for the MFP I welcomed that statement. Since Mr Kennan became the chief executive and now that the project is operating with a fully functioning permanent board, established by legislation in the South Australian parliament at the end of last year, we are now getting action at the MFP.

PARA.TAB: I agree that there was unnecessary delay in the previous two or three years, but that was due to the fact that we did not have a functioning MFP corporation board or a permanent chief executive. The chief executive, Mr Kennan, is an engineer; he is not a publicist. In fact, he has been abused by the Advertiser for not being a publicist and for not making public statements—

TALK.START.PARA: —On $300,000 a year, he ought to be able to say a word or two.

—He is now saying a few words. He is now getting out and selling the MFP. I want to refer to the Gillman site itself. From the very moment South Australia won the MFP, Gillman was made the core site. It was known full well that it was an environmentally degraded site. An argument put in favour of the site was that one of the themes of the MFP would be environmental rehabilitation. The Gillman site would be used elsewhere as an example of environmental rehabilitation. That was mentioned in the submission that South Australia put forward to win the MFP. It was not something `snuck up' on the Japanese or anybody else; it was in the South Australian submission. The justification was using environmental rehabilitation as an example.

PARA.TAB: The Japanese are still very keen on the environmental rehabilitation aspect of it. However, it has never been said from the beginning that the MFP would only be at Gillman. For example, there are discussions about part of the MFP project being involved in film production on a site in Queensland.

TALK.START.PARA: —Something might happen.

—I am sure that Senator Ferguson would be interested to know that a former Liberal leader from Queensland, Sir Llew Edwards, is a member of the MFP board. I think that indicates his interest in the project. The issue of the development of the MFP has never been said to be just one site. It is a national and international project that will have connections around the world.

PARA.TAB: If we listen to Dean Brown, who is talking about removing the core site and saying that it will only be an adjunct to existing institutions, I think we then run a risk that this will be seen as just another variation of a technology park or science park in Australia, which is different from the MFP. From the federal government's point of view, we are committed to the MFP because of its international nature—not just because it is a tech park. I suspect it will be much more difficult to convince my colleagues in the federal government to give special funding to the MFP if it is a local South Australian tech park. There are a dozen tech parks all around Australia run by state governments. They would all be queuing up for funding. It is the international nature of the MFP that gives it its distinct feature and which attracts the commitment, in principle, for federal government funding for a national project.

I turn to the Japanese side. Mr Yahiro certainly expressed concern about the delay. I agree with him about the delay, but he made it quite clear that they are committed to the concept of the MFP. All the other senior executives I spoke to at that seminar said exactly the same thing. They made it quite clear that it is the recession that has delayed the investment that we would have liked to have seen. I agree that, until we got the full board and a chief executive this year, there was unnecessary delay back in South Australia with respect to getting that structure in place. We now have it in place. I think that South Australian senators opposite would be much better off being constructive in their criticism. They should remember that tech park and science parks sites are already included in the MFP site.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson), to a question without notice asked by Senator Newman this day, relating to the Medicare levy.

SPEECH.PARA: In answering Senator Newman's question, Senator Richardson showed his total ignorance of the Medicare levy and what it brings in. It is a fact that only one-tenth of the taxpayers of this country have a taxable income over $47,355. An article in today's Australian newspaper states:

PARA.TAB: The Minister for Health, Senator Richardson, said yesterday the Prime Minister should take out private health insurance or pay a higher Medicare levy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Herald-Sun states:
High-income earners, including Prime Minister Paul Keating, should pay more into the public health system or pay their own private cover . . .

A table in that same article shows that the gross annual wage of Mr Keating is $179,174 and that he pays a Medicare levy of $2,508. The questions put to Mr Keating should be: have you had surgery in the past couple of years? Did you go to a private hospital? Did you pay for it yourself? Any private hospital would tell us that 10 per cent of the people who are admitted to it pay their own way—they carry their own insurance. They are already paying a Medicare levy—$2,500 in Mr Keating's case—they are not accessing the public system; they are going to private hospitals and paying their own way.

PARA.TAB: Senator Richardson will be saying to Mr Keating, `You should pay a higher Medicare levy or take out private health insurance'. The cost of private health insurance quoted in today's Herald-Sun is: HBA, $1,730; Australian Unity, $1,652; and Medibank Private New South Wales, $1,327. Senator Richardson cannot have it both ways. If he increases the Medicare levy he has to increase it to Mr Keating for Mr Keating to be paying $2,500.
It is also a slur on the medical profession, and, again, this is the way Senator Richardson operates. According to the Australian he said:

"The trouble is, you see, when people on higher incomes drop out of private health insurance, they do elbow the old pensioner out of the queue because if you're on a hundred grand a year you know how to work systems.

SPEECH.PARA: That is the way Senator Richardson works. I would like Senator Richardson to know that in the public hospital system—of which I was a proud employee for 30 years at three half days a week in the teaching hospitals in Brisbane—it was the medical necessity that determined where people came on a medical queue. It did not matter whether they were pensioners or whether they were prime ministers. If they had an urgent condition, they went straight to the top of the list. If they had a cancer of some kind, they went straight to the top of the list. We did not care who they were.

PARA.TAB: I can tell the Senate that there are no wealthy people in the public hospitals that I have ever been associated with. There are very few who work the system. One always hears about the odd one who does but the majority—if one questions them—want private health care, they want access to a doctor of their choice and they want continuity of care 24 hours a days, seven days a week which private doctors do give their patients.

TALK.START.PARA: —They don't want doctors ripping off the system and charging exorbitant fees.

—That is what Senator Murphy would want: he would want continuity of care; he would want the best available technology available to him; and he would want a caring system. He will only get that in a private system; he will not get it in a public system. It is like asking the Public Service to work and be available 24 hours a day, seven days a week. We just do not get it. In conclusion, I reiterate the questions that Senator Richardson should ask the Prime Minister: has he had surgery in the last couple of years? Did he go to a private hospital? Did he pay for it out of his pocket himself?

—I am concerned about the answer that Senator Richardson gave to me today because he full knows, and has acknowledged publicly, that the crisis in the health system needs addressing. His response is that we need to get wealthy people into private health insurance. That is only one part of the measure. If we go down that track alone, all we will end up with is wealthy people in private health insurance and all the rest of us burdening the public system so that it totally collapses.

PARA.TAB: During the election campaign people who were in a position to know how the health system was failing—which included the public hospital system, I might add—pointed out what needed to be done, and that is to encourage as many people as wanted to, to get into private health insurance. There are a lot of battlers in this country who have had private health insurance but who have dropped it, or who are struggling to maintain it. I am thinking particularly of people who are struggling in their self-funded retirement, but there are also pensioners and families with kids.

PETITION.TITLE: HMAS Huon
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned shows:

PETITION.PARA: We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that the Keating Government's decision to close down HMAS Huon is clearly and demonstrably wrong and should be reversed having regard to:
(a)The fact that HMAS Huon has been part of the Royal Australian Navy in Tasmania for over 80 years;
(b)It has continually demonstrated itself to be a most efficient shore-based designated Naval facility and Headquarters for the Royal Australian Navy in Tasmania;

PETITION.TITLE: Australian National Flag
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth
That the majority of Australians clearly stand united in satisfaction with their existing Australian National Flag which reflects their values, history and heritage,

Dear Senator Loosley

Thank you for your letter of 19 August 1993 to the Hon B. L. Howe, Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services, regarding amendments NHP2/1993 to the Nursing Home Financial Arrangements Principles ("the Principles").

In your letter, you raised concerns regarding certain of the amendments which make provision for determinations by the Minister and by the Secretary of the Department in respect of funding for adjusted fee government nursing homes (AFGNHs).

AFGNHs are State government nursing homes which are funded by the Commonwealth under a similar funding system to that for non-government nursing homes. New subparagraph 2(b)(ii) of the Principles sets out the transitional hourly rate (a component of AFGNHs' funding) which applies to AFGNHs for a maximum of 12 months after they become an AFGNH. The words "or such other amounts as are determined in writing by the Minister for the purpose of taking into account the changes with time in the cost of employing nursing and personal care staff" enable the Minister to vary the rates to take account of increases in award rates for relevant staffing categories. The transitional hourly rates are reviewed every three months and any variations are gazetted. If you consider it necessary, the Minister for Housing, Local Government and Community Services is prepared to take measures to amend the Principles to remove the above words, in which case, subparagraph 2(b)(ii) of the Principles will need to be amended every three months. However, the transitional hourly rates apply only to a very small number of State government nursing homes for a very limited time. Moreover, the transfer of State government nursing homes to the different funding system will be completed by the end of 1995/96 at the latest, after which this provision will cease to have any effect.
New paragraph 18(5)(b) has been deleted by an amendment to the Principles gazetted on 30 June 1993 and tabled on 27 September (amendments NH4/1993).

New paragraph 21(4)(b) and new subparagraph 32(30C)(a)(ii) both deal with funding for AFGNHs in respect of long service leave costs. AFGNHs' funding entitlement in respect of these costs is based on actual State average proportions of long service leave costs to nursing home payrolls for nursing homes other than AFGNHs in the funding year. During the funding year, the AFGNH receives an advance of its estimated entitlement, calculated using the actual State average proportion for the year before the previous funding year. At the end of the funding year, the home's advance is reconciled with its entitlement and any differences are taken into account in its funding for the following year. Paragraph 21(4)(b) covers the funding advance, while subparagraph 32(30C)(a)(ii) covers the reconciliation.

The words "the proportion determined by the Secretary as being the State average proportion of incurred long service leave costs to NPCE for nursing homes other than adjusted fee government nursing homes" have been included in both cases so that, if at the time the State average proportions are calculated for the purposes of the funding advance or reconciliation, data is unavailable in respect of a number of homes, the Secretary can determine State average proportions on the basis of available data. Without this discretion, it would be necessary to include in the Principles, notional State average proportions of long service leave costs to nursing home payrolls based on earlier years, and to amend the Principles annually to update these notional figures.

There would be significant disadvantages in including notional figures in the Principles. What is important to the Government and to the AFGNHs is that the funding be based on accurate State average proportions. Notional figures based on earlier years will necessarily be inaccurate and their inaccuracy will be exacerbated by the lead time required to seek amendments to the Principles to incorporate updated figures. The use of notional figures could, therefore, cause AFGNHs to be significantly financially disadvantaged. If, on the other hand, there is the flexibility to make determinations close to the time advances are made and entitlements calculated, the determinations will relate closely to the actual State average proportions.

The whole of the Commonwealth legislation on aged care is currently being reviewed by the Australian Law Reform Commission and the Commission will be specifically looking at the role played by subordinate legislation and the issue of sub-delegation. I would, therefore, like to request your Committee to allow the new paragraphs 2(b)(ii) and 21(4)(b) and new subparagraph 32(30C)(a)(ii) to remain on an interim basis.
Yours sincerely
Dr Andrew Theophanous

SPEECH.PARA: Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2600
Dear Senator Loosley,

Thank you for your letter of 19 August 1993 regarding your consideration of the Fifth Amending Deed to the Deed establishing an occupational superannuation scheme for Commonwealth employees and certain other persons under the Superannuation Act 1990 and in particular the changes to Rule 1.1.1.

The changes to Rule 1.1.1 amending the definition of "spouse" and introducing a new definition of "marital relationship" were introduced in order to comply with the amended Sex Discrimination Act 1984 by removing certain discriminatory provisions. These new provisions mirror the changes made to the other Commonwealth schemes (eg the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme, the Defence Force schemes, the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Scheme and the Judges Pension Scheme). Importantly the changes provide slightly wider criteria under which persons can qualify for spouses' benefits.

Part 11 of the Rules provide an extensive mechanism for the review of decisions made by the Board or by delegates of the Board. These provisions have application where a person requests reconsideration of a decision but also apply where the Board decides to reconsider a decision of its own volition. The discretionary powers provided by the changes to Rule 1.1.1 are subject to these review provisions.

I also mention that it is intended that the scheme under the Superannuation Act 1990 would be subject to the provisions contained in the Superannuation (Resolution of Complaints) Bill 1993 which are due to come into effect from 1 July 1994. A person could also seek review under that mechanism after the scheme's own review procedures have been complete.
Yours sincerely
Ralph Willis

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received the following letter from Senator Chamarette:

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to standing order 75, I write proposing that today I shall move a motion that, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

the need for the Government to take decisive action, using the powers at its disposal, including export controls, corporations powers and external affairs powers to ensure that the requirements of the "Strategy to protect old-growth forests and wilderness" agreed to in the National Forest Policy Statement, are being adhered to by the State agencies responsible for forest management and conservation.

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of senators required by the standing orders having risen in their places—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Chamarette, I understand that informal arrangements have been made to limit the time for the debate and also the speaking times during the debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to take decisive action, using the powers at its disposal, including export controls, the corporations power and the external affairs power, to ensure that the requirements of the "strategy to protect old-growth forests and wilderness" agreed to in the National Forest Policy Statement are being adhered to by the State agencies responsible for forest management and conservation.

The need for this urgency motion has become increasingly apparent in recent months around Australia as we move into the 1993-94 summer logging season. There is an emerging consensus amongst conservation groups and those concerned to protect our natural heritage that the state agencies responsible for forest management are ignoring the conservation sections of the national forest policy statement. My own recent trip to the magnificent karri forests around Pemberton in the south-west of Western Australia has provided vivid personal evidence of the disregard shown by the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management for the need to protect old growth and wilderness forests.

PARA.TAB: The national forest policy statement, which was signed by the Commonwealth government and all state governments except Tasmania in December 1992, was effectively born out of the failure of the current government to obtain agreement in this chamber to its Forest Conservation and Development Bill 1992. That bill and the subsequent national forest policy document received unanimous condemnation from the conservation movement due in large part to their emphasis on harvesting the forests. It is now an outrageous fact that even the limited conservation provisions in this national forest policy are being ignored, confirming the worst fears of the conservation movement that this government was yet again paying lip service only to the concepts of forest conservation and protection.
It is appropriate at this point to reiterate the conservation provisions contained in the national forest policy. Section 4.1 states:

SPEECH.PARA: "Conservation" commences with the laudable claim that: "Two of the principal objectives of this Statement are the maintenance of an extensive and permanent native forest estate in Australia and the protection of nature conservation values in forests.
The statement proceeds to outline a methodology for establishing an agreed set of criteria on which to base a reserve system and to protect those reserved forest areas.

PARA.TAB: The strategy to protect old growth forests and wilderness contains five basic elements. The first is the establishment of agreed criteria for determination of areas to be protected; secondly, an assessment of forests by state agencies; thirdly, an embargo on forest management activities that may significantly affect those areas of old growth forests or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value until assessments are complete—that is the crucial one which we are debating today; fourthly, the establishment of conservation reserve systems to protect old growth and wilderness forests on public land by 1995, those forests on private land that are to be protected in conservation reserves are to be established by 1998; fifthly, the development of management plans to appropriately protect old growth forests and wilderness values.

At this stage of its development, the key element of the strategy is the need for an embargo or moratorium on forestry activities in areas of forest likely to have high conservation value—the third element I mentioned before. If this element of the strategy is not adhered to by all parties, there will be little forest of high conservation value left to be protected. We find that the national forest policy is doing the exact opposite of what it is designed to do; that is, it is actually indicating those remaining areas of high conservation value and yet allowing a time lapse which the state departments are not protecting and which allows the industry to go ahead in those areas.

For example, I have recently alerted the Commonwealth Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) to extensive logging activities by CALM in Western Australia in the area known as Sharpe Block in the Roe area in the south-west of the state. This area was highlighted by the Australian Heritage Commission and CALM in their joint assessment of the southern forests of Western Australia as having high conservation value.

The Bridgetown Greenbushes Friends of the Forest have also been fighting for many years to protect areas of old growth and wilderness forest in Hester Block, Dalgarup and Mullalyup from logging. All of these blocks have been identified as having high conservation value. The submission from this group to the recent assessment of CALM's forest management plans highlights the value of Hester Block. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: Hester is ecologically mature and is locally most important environmentally, aesthetically and economically for industries and uses other than timber. CALM should recognise these community claims to the values it has failed to assess, and heed demand accordingly.
That submission also highlights the general concerns of the conservation movement about CALM's logging activity. It states:

We want ecologically sustainable uses of the forest. It is the forest itself that must be sustained; not just the yield of wood. There is no virtue in sustaining a high wood yield from a perpetually juvenile forest. Such action would preclude multiple purpose. To cut and remove a substantial part of the forest within six years and the remainder within fourteen precludes multiple purpose and inter-generational equity.

In New South Wales the Wilderness Society and other conservationists have been protesting the logging of compartment 1402 in the Coolangubra wilderness in south-east New South Wales. This area, which was the subject of two logging bans in early 1992, contains forest giants in excess of 65 metres tall and 10 metres round. In addition, the forest contains many rare and endangered fauna such as the southern brown bandicoot, yellow-bellied glider and powerful owl.

PARA.TAB: These three examples, which are only a small selection of similar activities in most states, are blatant transgressions of the third element of the strategy to protect old growth forests and wilderness that I have just outlined. This logging activity is without doubt affecting those areas of old growth or wilderness forests that are likely to have high conservation value.

The moratorium clause of the federal government's national forest policy would protect the best old growth and wilderness forests in five states—Tasmania, Victoria, Queensland, Western Australia and New South Wales—if it were being acted upon properly. The frustration of the conservation movement is understandable. The quotation from a recent Wilderness Society media release is indicative. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: The fate of the forest giants in `1402' is symbolic of the desperate need to protect the endangered wilderness and old-growth forests of NSW. Experts estimate that only 2.5% of NSW is covered with wilderness forests . . . and overall only 5% of all NSW forests are still of old-growth quality.

Looking at the situation in Victoria, information on East Gippsland also reports breaches of the national forest policy. Thirty-four per cent of the wood utilisation plans are within designated high conservation areas, as per the national forest policy to the federal government, and included in this are Ellery Creek, Martins catchment and Brown Mountain.

PARA.TAB: The old growth survey has been completed. Forty-eight per cent of old growth lies outside national parks; the government aims to protect only 40 to 60 per cent. It has no intention of altering the 15-year licence sustainable yield commitments. To meet this, it will have to log in national parks, and there are allegations that this is already planned. Also up for logging are sites of significance and reserve wildlife corridors. Harris Daishowa has recently been granted 20,000 cubic metres of whole logs from East Gippsland. This is a breach of the state's timber industry strategy as well as the NFP.

In Tasmania we have similar problems because the federal government has given the go-ahead to Hampshire woodchip mill. This will be the biggest woodchip mill in Australia to be located next to Australia's biggest area of pristine rainforests. The Tarkine and southern forests have been identified as having World Heritage values by the World Heritage Bureau.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not true.

—Senator Murphy can reply later, but I will quote him too; I believe he is a supporter of the concern people have about this mill being given the go-ahead by the Minister for Resources, Mr Michael Lee. In the next month or two, Mr Lee will be deciding whether to allow logging in areas of World Heritage quality in the southern forests. There are nine logging coups scheduled in the western tiers in the next few years. Tasmania is under threat because it exports 60 per cent of Australia's woodchips.

PARA.TAB: The apparent conflict between jobs and environment is an issue pushed heavily by advocates of logging, especially those who advocate logging of national parks or old growth forests and stand to gain financially. Old growth forests have been heavily logged by the timber industry in Australia to the point where they have almost disappeared in many areas. This is, by definition, not sustainable and should not be allowed to continue.

Environmentalists are quick to point out, however, that there is little need for conflict—both jobs and a healthy environment are possible. This is the real challenge and also the very real opportunity for Australian industry. The Australian of Monday, 25 October, states that North Broken Hill Peko's Hampshire mill would have a direct and disastrous impact on the biggest block of pristine rainforest in the nation, and I agree. The article also states:

SPEECH.PARA: The move has been opposed within the Labor Party's own ranks and has sparked the unlikely alliance of the green and union movements.
It is not an unlikely alliance at all; it is extremely logical.

PARA.TAB: The timber industries, however, insist that they can manage forests sustainably. They claim they have done so for many years, yet they continually demand the right to log last stands of old growth forest and claim their survival depends on this. The question needs to be asked: if they cannot survive now without logging the last old growth forests, how will they survive when they are gone? Obviously, something is askew.

Ecologically sustainable forestry means plantation forestry and agroforestry. The question is whether some old-growth forests should be saved before the industry becomes sustainable. The logging companies say no, but given the lack of old-growth forests their motive is obviously short-term profit. We as a community should not be forced to pay the enormous price of losing all of our old-growth forests because of the short-sighted perspective of some in the timber and forest industries.

Plantations are more difficult to manage and more expensive than chopping down native forests—expensive, at least, in an economic sense. Some pine plantations are so poorly managed, for example, that the value of timber is being lost through lack of thinning and other maintenance operations, yet plantation management could provide both jobs and alternatives to old-growth forest logging. These jobs are not lost through environmental control.

Jobs are, in fact, being cut by forest product companies. In the south-west forests of Western Australia, environmentalists have shown that job shedding occurs as the larger timber companies convert processing operations to more highly mechanised forms. Conservationists have shown that small mills, on the other hand, provide more jobs and use logged timber up to 50 per cent more efficiently. They process timber for higher value products such as furniture and building timber rather than woodchips or pulp.

With reference to the North Broken Hill licence that has just been given, why is the government supporting a new licence to export 170,000 tonnes a year of woodchips from Burnie, in northern Tasmania, when not only the conservation movement but also the union movement in Tasmania are actively opposing the project because it will actually cost around 90 jobs in more labour intensive sectors of the timber industry? Senator Murphy—and I note he has left since his interjection—was speaking with grave concern about the questionable value adding quality of this particular way of utilising wood. He said that it is very questionable and that the way in which we actually cut down trees should maximise value adding. He continued:

SPEECH.PARA: Some people would say that if one looked at value adding on a dollar basis one would make it all into paper. It is probably true that on a dollar per tonne basis, paper is the most valuable manufactured product that one can get out of trees; but it does not employ many people, and it is going to employ fewer because of the technology that is available in the industry.
Senator Murphy also spoke about waste, which is one of the most fundamental problems we have at the moment. He referred to:
. . . so much wood that is wasted by way of woodchips, et cetera, just being shipped out of the state and certainly from the country in the rawest possible form . . .

Senator Murphy said that surely this should not be allowed to continue. I thank him for his support of this argument. It has also been shown that successful plantations and agroforestry, in conjunction with proper ecological principles, will produce commercial hardwood crops within a few years. This approach will create jobs based on ongoing sustainable work rather than the current short-term extraction based approach.

PARA.TAB: I urge my colleagues to support this motion, which requests that the federal government take decisive action using the powers at its disposal, including export controls, corporation powers and external affairs powers to ensure that the requirements of the strategy to protect old-growth forests and wilderness agreed to in the national forest policy statement are being adhered to by the state agencies responsible for forest management and conservation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government certainly will not be supporting Senator Chamarette's motion, and I will outline a number of reasons.

PARA.TAB: There are two matters on which I want to rebut Senator Chamarette. The first is in respect of the ongoing management of forests in Western Australia. I am aware that a model forestry management code was established at the beginning of last year. There are still some matters to be developed, but that model is continuing. I understand that it was welcomed by our federal Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories (Mrs Kelly) and also by the forest industry and significant sections of the environment movement. I note that Senator Coulter is in the chamber and I understand that it was welcomed by him at the time as well.

In dealing with this issue, I do not accuse Senator Chamarette of suddenly rediscovering this issue in the light of some criticism of the Greens during the budget process. However, I understand the environment movement was a little concerned that the Green senators from WA were spending so much time on matters that, frankly, in terms of the budget should not have been preoccupying them as much as they did.

As to the powers of the Senate and the way in which this house should be used during the budget process, it is interesting to see the divergent views amongst the Greens about the use of upper houses. Whilst I disagree with Bob Brown on many matters in respect of the environment, I do agree with him and the Greens' very strongly principled position in Tasmania that upper houses should not be engaged in usurping the legitimate role of governments, one of which is the formulation and processing of the budget. But I note that the Greens from Western Australia do not have such principles. Perhaps they ought to get themselves together and find out what the role of an upper house should be.

In respect of Tasmania, there has been a blatant misuse of the recently announced Hampshire mill by Minister Lee in this argument about the use of forest resources in Tasmania, my home state. Certainly the trade union movement has some very legitimate concerns in Tasmania about the continuing decline in jobs in the forestry, paper manufacturing and woodchip areas of the industry in particular.

Senator Chamarette, quite rightly, quoted the views of Senator Murphy, a former official of the forest union. Senator Murphy, who has just come back into the chamber, was very unkindly criticised by Senator Chamarette. She made a note that he was not in the chamber. In fact, he was so interested in the arguments she was putting forward that he went to obtain some additional information for use in this debate. Unfortunately, because of the restrictions on the number of speakers, he is unable to make what would be a very worthwhile contribution.

Senator Murphy has highlighted the problems that exist in the employment and industrial relations aspects of the forest industries in some areas in Tasmania. It would be wrong to assume from that that we agree with Senator Chamarette's misleading statement that the implication of the Hampshire mill being built next door to the so-called Tarkine wilderness—and I notice that these are the words, or words to very similar effect, that were used by Mr Marr in the Australian yesterday—is that the Hampshire mill is, in fact, drawing all its resources from this so-called Tarkine wilderness area. Again I notice that the allegation is made that it is the last stretch of pristine wilderness in Tasmania.

TALK.START.PARA: —What rubbish!

—As Senator Archer says, this is absolute rubbish. I certainly agree with him on this matter. The Hampshire mill is 50 kilometres—or is it 50 miles?—away from the so-called Tarkine area. In fact, it is not called the Tarkine area; it is the Arthur Pieman area of Tasmania. If Senator Chamarette is going to come from Western Australia and lecture people from Tasmania about the nomenclature, I ask her to please get it right. It is the Arthur Pieman region.

PARA.TAB: I refer to one area of principle about which I agree with Bob Brown. However, I do not agree with his plucking Aboriginal names out of the air and misusing them for the Greens' propaganda purposes—and it is blatant propaganda. In fact, much of the resource that will be used by the Hampshire mill will come from APPM's own plantation forests.

TALK.START.PARA: —In fact, by the year 2005, all of it will.

—That is right. Senator Murphy has interjected that by the year 2005 all the resource going into the Hampshire mill will come from APPM's plantations. Senator Chamarette is condemning the use of the resource from plantations. I understood that the green movement supported the use of forest timber from plantations. Frankly, I find her position contradictory. On the one hand, she is attempting to blatantly misuse—
—They are pretty strong words.

—That is being very kind in my criticism. I could be much stronger, but I will not use unparliamentary language. I can see that the Acting Deputy President is looking a little concerned about where I am headed. Senator Chamarette blatantly misled the Senate about the resource that is being used at the Hampshire mill. I will temper my criticism of the green movement. Senator Chamarette should certainly go back and check her facts.

PARA.TAB: The reasons that the government will not support this motion that was put forward by the Greens is that it clearly demonstrates Senator Chamarette's lack of appreciation of the national forest policy statement. Indeed, the motion that she has put forward is internally contradictory of the national forest policy statement.

The national forest policy statement contains processes which aim to promote ecologically sustainable forest development by ensuring the adequate protection of Australia's forests while at the same time allowing for the future development of our forest industries. These industries have a very strong and significant employment base, particularly in regional areas of Australia, such as Tasmania, where I come from and those that Senator Chamarette declares she represents. I note her heavy emphasis on regional employment in her recent alleged defence of the wine industry. She should certainly take this issue into account when coming to her position.

The national forest policy statement was developed cooperatively between the Commonwealth and the states. It outlines an agreed vision and policy framework for the management of Australia's forests. It is based on a cooperative partnership, recognising that the states have institutional responsibility for the day-to-day management of Australia's forests.

The Commonwealth also has a legitimate interest in forest issues. Under that national forest policy statement, the Commonwealth and the state and territory governments have agreed on a cooperative approach to ensure the protection of old growth forests and wilderness with a view to having a representative reserve system in place by 1995. In case Senator Chamarette does not know it, it is not 1995 yet. There is still some time for that representative reserve system to be put into place. By 1998—Senator Chamarette should be aware of these dates—a reserve system will be established for private forested land.

Progress in implementing this old growth strategy is well under way. There has been a joint committee of the Australian and New Zealand Environment and Conservation Council and the Australian Forestry Council. They are developing the criteria for the representative forest reserve system, which is to be finalised at the end of this year. I suggest that Senator Chamarette be a little patient in her knee-jerk reaction to the criticisms she has been receiving from her supporters about her lack of attention to these matters. She should not overreact as she has by moving this motion today.

During the interim period, as part of this cooperative approach, it is also agreed that forest assessments are to be completed by the forest management agencies. These will avoid activities that may significantly affect those areas of old growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value. Both the Commonwealth and the states recognise that some logging in old growth areas has been necessary as their resources are vital to the veneer and sawlog requirements of a major part of the forest industries. Again, these industries employ many people. Veneer and sawlog requirements are a very necessary part of employment in rural and regional Australia. In accordance with these arrangements, the Commonwealth is keen to cooperate with the states. To date, that cooperation has been quite extensive.

The motion before us fails to recognise that there has been substantial progress in meeting the national forest policy statement. I will refer to a couple of practical examples of the progress that has been made to date. The Queensland government, in cooperation with the Commonwealth, is undertaking an assessment of the conservation values of forests to meet the government's environmental and heritage obligations.

In Queensland, the government is committed to avoiding activities in forests likely to have high conservation values while these assessments are being undertaken. The Victorian government is progressively implementing its commitment to assess old growth forests for their conservation value. A survey of the East Gippsland forests has been completed, a survey of the central highlands forests has commenced and a survey of the north eastern Victorian forests will commence shortly.

It may shock Senator Chamarette, but these sorts of processes and surveys cannot be implemented overnight. I note that she referred to her trip through the karri forests of Western Australia. Frankly, it is a bit like the budget: one cannot put these things in place overnight; it is simply not possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially as she got it wrong in the first place.

—As Senator Alston very smartly observes, particularly as the green movement got it wrong in the first place. Senator Alston is spot on. That is what I like about him. He is so perceptive in his criticism of the green movement—on this occasion.

PARA.TAB: One cannot undertake these surveys of the forest regions of Australia overnight. It is simply not possible to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had numerous surveys in Tasmania.

—As Senator Murphy points out, I think it is 13 or 15 at the last count. Tasmania must be the most surveyed part of the globe. We know every stick and tree in every wilderness area. There has been very extensive observations of forestry in Tasmania over the last 20 or so years, but I will not say any more about that on this occasion; time precludes me from doing so in this debate.

PARA.TAB: In conclusion, I reiterate that the government is committed to minimising conflict over the use of our forest resources. The national forest policy statement is a cooperative statement which, for the first time in Australia's history, represents a coordinated national approach to forest issues.

The protection of old growth forests is an important part of this statement. The government is committed to the cooperative arrangements it has in place to ensure that these forests are protected. I urge all parties interested in the forest debate in Australia to work within this cooperative framework with a view to ensuring that the forest industries in Australia are conducted in accordance with the principles of ecologically sustainable development, and not as the Greens suggested.

We have this cooperative framework. It is working well. There are surveys taking place. While we are part-way through this process, with no evidence of a breakdown, we should not do as the Greens suggest, that is, to come in and bludgeon the state governments with a whole range of powers which at this time are simply not appropriate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —At the conclusion of my speech, I will seek leave to move an amendment circulated in my name in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit all words after "decisive action", substitute "to protect old growth forests and wilderness and to assist the States in meeting the specific goals and objectives of the National Forests Policy Statement, specifically to avoid actions, including logging, that may significantly affect those areas of old growth forests or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value.".
Honourable senators should note that this amendment is slightly different from the one that is presently being circulated.

PARA.TAB: The federal constitution was not drawn up to be the plaything of federal politicians. This is especially so when state governments are behaving responsibly in their management of forestry and in land management. Senator Chamarette's desire to use federal powers to override state responsibility is not the way this country should be run. Federal powers such as export controls, corporations and external powers were never intended to be used in the way that Senator Chamarette is proposing. Although Senator Chamarette's motion does not refer to New South Wales directly, it is primarily about the New South Wales decision to log compartment 1402 of the south-east forests in the Nalbaugh special prescription area.

I will outline the specific conditions applying to compartment 1402, which has been the centre of media attention in recent weeks. The New South Wales Minister for Land and Water Conservation has advised me that only about half of that compartment will be logged. The area which will be logged is subject to stringent conditions set by the National Parks and Wildlife Service of New South Wales. Specific fauna conditions have been placed on the licence for this compartment by the New South Wales director of the National Parks and Wildlife Service.

In 1990 there was an agreement between Mr Hawke and Mr Greiner—the south-east forest agreement—that would lead to the declaration of a national reserve system in New South Wales. There would have been Commonwealth funding for this. This accord is still alive but has not yet been signed. What we really need is Mrs Kelly to stop the political point scoring and get on with admitting that the 1990 agreement is a valid compromise as a result of which the conservationists will get their additional reserve areas and the industry will get guaranteed access to the remaining resource.

Subsequent to the Hawke-Greiner forest accord, all states, except Tasmania, agreed to the national forest policy statement in December 1992. Under this statement the states and the Commonwealth agreed on a strategy to protect old growth forests and wilderness. They agreed, firstly, to determine criteria for identifying old growth forests and wilderness; secondly, to undertake assessment of forests for conservation values, including old growth values; and, thirdly—and this is crucial to Senator Chamarette's motion—to avoid activities that may significantly affect old growth forests or wilderness that are likely to have a high conservation value.

Shortly after the New South Wales government signed the national forest policy statement, Mrs Ros Kelly wrote to the New South Wales government stating that a moratorium should be put in place until comprehensive regional studies, estimated to take four years, had been completed. This covered some 1.4 million hectares of forest in New South Wales and would have resulted in a 52 per cent reduction in the annual sustainable yield from New South Wales state forests. The Western Australian Greens do not have a mortgage on the environment.

TALK.START.PARA: —They think they have.

—They certainly do. Australia needs balanced development coupled with environmentally sensitive controls. The trouble with the Western Australian Greens is that they regard all Australians as overgrown rabbits—pests, real pests, that should never have been imported into this country. It is time for a bit of rational decision making on the forestry issue so that the people involved in that vital industry—vital for employment, vital for growth—can get on with the job. I now seek leave to move the amendment I foreshadowed.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: Omit all words after "decisive action", substitute "to protect old growth forests and wilderness and to assist the States in meeting the specific goals and objectives of the National Forests Policy Statement, specifically to avoid actions, including logging, that may significantly affect those areas of old growth forests or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value.".

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats strongly support the motion moved today by Senator Chamarette. The national forest policy, which was signed last December by all governments except Tasmania, is a document cynical in its intent. The policy commits the federal and state governments to a strategy to protect old growth forests and wilderness areas. Since it was signed, the destruction of our last ancient, old growth forests and wilderness areas has continued apace. There has been no let-up, and there will be no let-up until there is strong pressure brought to bear on this government.

PARA.TAB: The supposedly shared commitment to save our unique natural heritage from the ravages of the woodchip mill is being flouted around the country and this government is doing nothing about it. Not only is this federal government failing to act, it is even propounding the view that there is nothing it can do to save the forests. This is the largest dissimulation of all time. There are many actions this government can take, and I will deal with some of these later on. The fact is that this government's failure is a failure of political will. It is that failure of political will that allows the destruction of Australia's magnificent ancient forests to continue.

On the issue of forest protection, the national forest policy outlines a strategy to protect old growth forests and wilderness. State forest agencies are to undertake assessments of forests for their conservation and wilderness values as `a matter of high priority'. The strategy also states that until assessments are completed—this is the important point, picking up on Senator Sherry's remarks—forest management agencies will:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . avoid activities that may significantly affect those areas of old-growth forest or wilderness that are likely to have high conservation value.

This has become known as the `moratorium clause' and it is the critical area of contention. This is what the strategy says in theory; in practice, the state forest agencies are raping the forests while the federal government is lying back and thinking of the republic, unwilling to stand up for its own policy—a policy shared with the rampant states.

PARA.TAB: There have been many inquiries into the future management of Australia's forests. Inquiries have been carried out by the Resource Assessment Commission, the National Plantations Advisory Committee, the ESD forestry working group and the Industry Commission, which reported on forest products. Forest protests have occurred throughout the 1980s and into the early 1990s. Yet in 1993, we are still fighting to save what should have been considered a natural heritage so precious that we should not dare to sacrifice it to the pulp mill or sawmill.

Our old growth forests and wilderness areas are our natural heritage. They are irreplaceable treasures which can never be reconstructed by human hands. To say, as the forestry industry does, that the forests will grow back as they were is simply a lie. Humans cannot replace 300- to 500-year-old trees and the complex ecology associated with them.

The critical point is that we are dealing with two different views of the world when we talk about forests. On the one hand, the forest industry looks at old growth forests and all it sees is timber; on the other hand, conservationists and the community at large see the forest as an inspiration in a world of concrete, metal and straight lines. They see it as a haven for biodiversity, as a thing that is precious and beautiful and valuable in itself.

In the middle lies the government. It says that it is committed to ecological sustainability, but we have not seen that commitment translated into action. Most ordinary Australians expect the government to save our natural heritage for all Australians who are alive now and also for future generations. If we stand back and allow the destruction to occur, we deny our children and our grandchildren and all succeeding generations the joy and peace that we derive today from the existence of these magnificent areas. I ask this chamber: is that fair? Is that fair to later generations? Will their humanity not be diminished if these experiences are denied them, and denied them by the present generation?

Of course, it is also the role of government to ensure that all people have jobs, but the key point that this government seems unable to appreciate is that sustainable jobs are found in plantations and not in the ever dwindling old growth forests. They are not found in forestry practices that have moved increasingly into high capital, low labour woodchip exports. This government is not acting in the public good. It is in the pocket of the forest industry. If it were acting in the public good, it would use its powers to stop logging in high conservation value areas. Let there be no mistake: it does have those powers.

This spring and summer we will witness, if nothing is done to stop the destruction, the devastation of our forests on an unprecedented scale. In New South Wales, one of the most blatant examples of the state government's failure to commit itself to the national forest policy is the controversial decision to commence logging in compartment 1402 of the Nalbaugh state forest. This area is listed on the National Estate and is part of the Coolangubra wilderness area. Compartment 1402 is home to five endangered animal species.Many other areas of the state are under threat from logging, including Barrington, Chaleundi, the Kempsey-Wauchope forests and the old growth forests of the Bulga Plateau.

In Victoria, Brown Mountain on the Errinundra Plateau is up for logging. So too are the old growth areas of Ellery Block and Yalmy Creek—two of the last pristine water catchments in the east Gippsland region. These areas are home to the long-footed potoroo, an animal that is supposedly protected by the federal government's Endangered Species Protection Act. Logging threats to the potoroo only serve to highlight the total inadequacy of that legislation.

In Queensland, logging continues to take place in the state forest on the Clarke Range situated on either side of the Eungella National Park, west of Mackay, as well as the Conway State Forest, adjoining Conway National Park east of Proserpine. Both these areas have been identified as being of high conservation value and comprise old forest growth types.

In Western Australia, the Court government has decided to triple the quantities of karri, jarrah and marri to be extracted from the south-west forests. Clearly, this decision will have a catastrophic effect on the remaining old growth forests and will greatly exacerbate problems associated with dieback in these forests.

As I have said, Tasmania did not sign the national forest policy. However, the destruction of Tasmania's forests cannot be ignored in this debate. The state government is logging forests in the south-west of Tasmania and the great western tiers. These areas have been identified by the Australian Heritage Commission, the International Union for the Conservation of Nature, the Tasmanian Department of Parks, Wildlife and Heritage, and even the World Heritage Bureau as having World Heritage values. Many of these logging operations are destroying wilderness that is, quite frankly, irreplaceable.

During the third session of the renegotiation of the international tropical timber agreement held recently in Geneva, the Australian delegation issued a statement saying that the Australian government would protect old growth forest and wilderness values by 1995 for all Australia's forests. The Australian branch of the Worldwide Fund for Nature issued a press release welcoming the government's statement to the world community which clearly signalled the federal government's intention to overrule state governments which fail to act on the forest policy strategy. The Australian delegation's statement relating to all Australian forests has to be seen to include Tasmania.

Mr Michael Rae of the WWF warned that the government must honour these pledges or rightly be judged as a hypocrite. In that regard it is not too cynical to believe that the government purposefully developed a strategy to protect old growth forests and wilderness knowing that it would not be adhered to by the states. But at least it would let the Commonwealth off the hook. Now the government can say, `We are abiding by the policy; it is the state governments who are not keeping their side of the bargain'.

Why is it that the Commonwealth could not see that the states were never going to keep their bargain in the first place? The simple answer is that the federal government was looking for a way out of the issue. It wanted to be able to say `The Commonwealth isn't to blame'. Well, who believes this? It just leaves the government's credibility on forestry matters in tatters. It has been a deliberate policy of this federal Labor government to abandon its responsibilities and to hide behind the facade of intergovernmental agreements. What can the Commonwealth do? There are a number of actions it could take. It could refuse to renew permits for the export of woodchips under the Export Control Act 1982.

TALK.START.PARA: —That would be smart!

—In fact, we subsidise the export of woodchips anyway. The Commonwealth would save money by not exporting. It could prohibit the logging of old growth and wilderness areas by legislating in respect to export corporations and trading and commerce powers.

PARA.TAB: Both the old parties—the Labor Party and the coalition—are prepared to use the corporations power when it suits their political purpose. During the last federal election campaign John Howard pledged that he would use the corporations power to get his way on industrial relations. As we have seen in recent weeks, Senator Richardson is on record as saying that he was prepared to use the corporations power to override Victorian tobacco advertising legislation. The corporations power was also used by this government in its ozone protection legislation. So the government is prepared to use the corporations powers but not, evidently, to protect the environment.

I return to actions that the government could take. It could prohibit logging using the trade and commerce powers; it could introduce tighter restrictions on foreign ownership of corporations involved in woodchipping operations; it could use the Commonwealth tied grants power; it could fulfil the spirit and the letter of section 30 of the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975. This section requires a Commonwealth minister to ensure that any department or agency administered by him or her:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . does not take any action that adversely affects . . . a place that is on the register unless he is satisfied that there is no feasible and prudent alternative to the taking of that action . . .

The government could fulfil its obligations under the World Heritage Properties Conservation Act 1983 which ensures that no act be taken that damages or destroys any property that is listed as a World Heritage area. There are many actions that can be taken by the Commonwealth. The pretence that the federal government cannot do anything to protect the forests must stop.

PARA.TAB: I was most heartened to see an article in the Weekend Australian of 9 and 10 October which reported the findings of a new international barometer conducted in 12 countries, including Australia. The poll found that Australia was a nation gripped with concern. What must come as a surprise to this government is the fact that 69 per cent of those polled worried about the environment. The environment was one of the top three concerns of Australians, coming third after unemployment and violence and personal safety. Australians worried more about the environment than any other country polled. This does not surprise the Australian Democrats, who know that the environment is a deep concern for many Australians. I have personally received many letters from people all around the country about the fate of our forests. These people are very distressed to see our natural heritage being destroyed year after year. They desperately want this federal government to take action to stop this desecration.

I foreshadow that the Australian Democrats will not support the package of bills dealing with the introduction of a forest research levy until the government protects old growth forests and wilderness. Why should we assent to one initiative arising out of the national forest policy in relation to valueadding—which I assure the government we support in principle—when the government is sitting on its hands with respect to another and far more important policy initiative?

On behalf of all concerned Australians, I urge the government to support Senator Chamarette's motion and to act immediately to halt the logging of our magnificent ancient forests, to stop the destruction of the homes of many endangered and vulnerable species, and to fast-track the development of an ecologically sustainable industry—one that is based on plantations and tree farms rather than on the unabated slaughter of our precious forests and wilderness areas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to the urgency motion moved by Senator Chamarette today. The first question I wish to ask is: why is it here before us today? It is here purely and simply for the Greens to try to recapture the confidence of the people they upset—in fact, deserted—last Thursday; their own constituents in the Margaret River-Pemberton area where they got most of their vote. They will live with last Thursday's performance for a long time. But this urgency motion will not regain what they lost there because it is based on a false premise, particularly in Western Australia. It is inappropriate to suggest that we use the types of powers that they are suggesting, particularly the external affairs power, when dealing with this matter.

PARA.TAB: The point that I wish to make, and which Senator Chamarette has conveniently forgotten, relates to the agreement that was reached between the Australian Heritage Commission and the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management under the former state Labor government, which was supported by the coalition in Western Australia, in relation to forest management and the preservation of old growth forest and how it operated in Western Australia. Senator Chamarette has conveniently forgotten what was reached at that time. I am surprised that she would move a motion of this type after what was done there.
When Senator Sherry finished speaking I showed him four newspaper articles, which I now seek leave to table.

TALK.START.PARA: —What are they? I would like to see them first.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Senator Chamarette would like to see them before leave is granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have shown these newspaper articles to the government. I would like to highlight the position that came from one of these articles entitled `Green-friendly forest plan, a model for the nation'. The article, which refers to the Western Australian agreement that was reached, reads:

PARA.TAB: A plan to overhaul the way forests are managed in Western Australia that "delivers a green component to resource security" would become a model for other States, it was predicted yesterday.

SPEECH.PARA: That prediction was made by the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, Mrs Kelly. The article goes on to state:

PARA.TAB: The report is unique because it ambitiously lays claims for both green and logging interests by setting aside areas for timber harvesting and recreation.
It creates 18 new conservation reserves, including two new national parks, and proposes 44 areas for listing on the National Estate register.

SPEECH.PARA: I particularly want to make a point about the part of the article which states:

PARA.TAB: The review was also welcomed by the leader of the Democrats, Senator Coulter . . .

SPEECH.PARA: I find the comments that Senator Coulter made today very strange. I am pleased the government is not supporting the motion because it would have made a mockery of the work carried out by the Australian Heritage Commission and the Western Australian Department of Conservation and Land Management. The work of this department was hailed, by no less than the minister for the environment, as a model for the resolution of forest and land use conflicts. The work done in Western Australia was supported by the opposition and, as I said before, the Australian Democrats.

PARA.TAB: A feature of this agreement was that it accommodated the need to set aside reserves and old growth forests and, at the same time, it provided for the long term future of the timber industry. I emphasise that the development of the plantation industry in Western Australia has been expansive and significant. The criteria developed for the reserves and management system are the ones that must be used to implement the national forest strategy.

It goes without saying that if the Greens—or as they are known in many parts of Western Australia, the new fruit loop party—continue with this proposal they will shoot themselves in the foot and destroy this very important agreement which has received international recognition, and I underline the importance of international recognition. (Time expired)
The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Is leave granted for the newspaper articles to be tabled by Senator Crane?
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by my colleague Senator Sandy Macdonald. It is impossible for this parliament or the Commonwealth government to make decisions about tiny bits of land here and there throughout the nation. At the moment we are talking about a few small pieces of land. The Greens and Democrats obviously think that wisdom resides here in Canberra and that the decisions have to be made in Canberra. That simply cannot be done; it is not practical.

PARA.TAB: Last century a substantial portion of the native forests of Australia were cleared for agriculture. From those clearings the wealth of this nation was raised, and we are still dependent upon them.

Earlier this century forest services were formed by the state governments to conserve what was left—which was roughly half—of the native forests, and they have been well managed every since then. They have been managed for several uses, such as wood, water, recreation and conservation values. However, it was in the 1980s, due to rising pressure from the Greens in various states, that the federal government interfered, particularly in Tasmania and Queensland, and large areas of forests were locked up from multiple uses. This was due to political pressure stirred by the Greens and acted upon by the Labor government. This was to the detriment of workers in regional Australia.

That having been done, there have been continuing rows between the Commonwealth and the states over forest issues; again largely stirred by the green movement. There has been a continual argument about whether areas should be preserved or used for multiple purposes.

In 1990, the government set up the Resource Assessment Commission which ran for over two years and cost millions of dollars. Its purpose was basically to examine and take evidence about what the truth of the argument was about preservation versus multiple use of forests. In the end that report concluded that native forests could be used largely for multiple use, although some areas needed to be set aside for nature conservation—they needed to be preserved.

From that extensive study the Commonwealth and the states agreed on a national forest policy statement. All the states except Tasmania signed that agreement. The only reason Tasmania did not sign was that there was disagreement between the Commonwealth and Tasmania about re-using some of the information from some 15 surveys that had been carried out in Tasmania. This was largely due to political pressure. That matter still has not been resolved.

In the forest policy statement there was agreement that there would be a survey of the old growth forests of high conservation value across all states. As my colleague Senator Crane said, this was done in a very excellent manner in 1991 and in early 1992 in Western Australia by an agreement between the Australian Heritage Commission and CALM, which is the Western Australian department responsible. The Minister for the Environment, Sports and Territories, Mrs Kelly, claimed peace in our time from that agreement.

I believe all the states are managing their forests well. It is absolutely impossible for this parliament or the Commonwealth government to get involved in block X or area Y or block Z here or there around the nation. That cannot be done. Large areas of forests can be managed from here only by agreeing on the process. We have been through that process. There has been agreement on the process and we should stand by that process. I support the amendment to the urgency motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Many words have been said today. I think one of the most important statements that can be made today is that the green movement in Australia is not divided in its concern about the flagrant disregard for forest conservation strategies. One has only to look at the work that Senator Chamarette has done over the year. One need only refer to questions and notices of motion in Hansard. One can ask the conservation groups in Western Australia about the continued efforts of the Greens (WA) in this debate and about the very strong network, communication and ability it has to keep these issues in the public debate in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: I will give the Senate an idea of the work of the Greens (WA). We have had to deal with the pressure that has been put on us from a number of different areas and a number of major debates and issues in recent weeks. Senator Chamarette made a visit to the Hawke Block just a few weeks ago on request from the people who work in this area. They are just about at the end of their tether with regard to government policy. I was asked to visit the South East Forest a couple of weeks ago. I also visited and walked down the catchment at Tantawangalo—I have the bruises to prove it. I have visited the Hester Block in Western Australia in recent weeks.

In Western Australia, the Greens (WA) is the only party to stand up to this destruction in recent times. I have had calls from members of the Labor Party and the coalition parties asking whether the Greens (WA) can do something to bring this issue even more to the public fore. They recognise that nobody else is prepared to stand up for these issues. The CALM-HAC agreements in our states have been used to the advantage of those people who would like to log to destruction many of our old growth forests.

It was mentioned earlier that the Tasmanian Forestry Commission should be supported in its efforts. However, it hardly seems that money is being made for the government or forestry in that area when $400 million of accumulated debt has had to be written off. It is not necessarily the best policy for money making. One of the statements that should be taken into consideration or reiterated is that the real costs of many of these decisions are borne by the community.The Bridgetown Green Bushes Friends of the Forest has stated that the real cost of re-establishing old growth forests in an area that is currently allowed to be mined for gravel will be about $17 million. So this is not just about the production of timber.

Senator Gibson talked about multiple use. But what is the real multiple use that provides income and jobs for the greatest number of people in regions? I argue, as do many people in the conservation movement, that multiple use is actually locking out a great many economic activities of greater benefit for the community.

We can have our cake and eat it too in terms of providing timber production in agroforestry and in plantations, especially on land that at this stage has been degraded by some other farm practices. Smaller mills can be used for plantation artisan-based production. These areas can exist with beautifully protected old growth forests. Jobs can be created in areas which are attractive to live in or visit. This arrangement has the added benefit of providing extra income, in terms of agroforestry, to those farming sectors that are currently under pressure. We have a very one-sided argument. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a very brief statement in response to the amendment to my motion.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—You do not need leave, Senator Chamarette.

TALK.START.PARA: —I say briefly that, naturally enough, we will not be supporting the amendment to our motion, although we recognise that Senator Sandy Macdonald's amendment indicates the seriousness of the problem we are suffering from in terms of our forest industry. I thank Senator Macdonald for drawing that to our attention.
—On a point of order: I do not think Senator Chamarette was given leave.
—Senator Chamarette can close the debate if she wishes.
—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I understood that I did not have to ask for leave. I would like to finish the very brief statement I was making—
—You don't; you can conclude the debate.

—I conclude the debate by saying that the amendment misses the point. My motion calls for federal powers because cooperation between federal and state governments is leading directly to the opposite purpose for which it was intended. Instead of actually protecting the last remains of our precious old growth forests, it is leading to the unwitting destruction of them prior to the time limits that have been set being imposed. That is why this motion is very important and I commend it to my colleagues.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Sandy Macdonald's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Motion, as amended, agreed to.
