SPEECH.PARA: I wish to take this opportunity to address the tabling of the revised strategic plan 1991-93 of the Australian National Maritime Museum. The Australian National Maritime Museum is a cultural resource with great educational and recreational potential. It is important that this museum prevails as a viable cultural institution, both as a monument to the national service of past generations and to our maritime culture, as well as being an historical centre for Australians of the future.

PARA.TAB: The museum also represents a diplomatic relationship between Australia and the United States in that the USA gallery was donated to the museum by the former President of the United States, George Bush. The USA gallery is a most interesting gallery. I would recommend that when honourable senators who do not live in New South Wales are visiting Sydney they should go to see the National Maritime Museum and spend some time in that gallery. Australia can look to the museum as a bicentennial consecration of our defence bond with the United States by its portrayal of the history of that bond over the years.

Currently, however, the Australian National Maritime Museum is suffering from a range of problems in the fields of finance, housing, administration and marketing. Dr Kevin Fewster has a great challenge ahead of him. The coalition supports him in his cause to address those issues and in particular through this strategic plan.

The National Maritime Museum is slightly off the beaten path for the main group of tourists who visit that area, which poses a problem. Also, the museum was not purpose-built for the particular displays that it has. When I visited the museum I was told that there are enormous overheads on such items as air-conditioning for this very large building. I endorse the strategic plan's view to a more dynamic facility, including greater financial management of projects through staff training, formal procedures and post-project evaluation. The museum had hoped to be more self-supporting than it has been able to achieve and when one visits, one can see some of the problems because of its location and because the building was not specifically designed for that purpose.

I commend to honourable senators the strategic plan and the museum. Visiting the museum, I believe, enables young Australians to develop a greater understanding of some of the historical developments in Australia because of our isolation. Those of us who remember going to the wharves to see friends off and throw streamers to ships realised then how isolated we were. It was not until we had the migrant postwar influx that many of us were exposed to other cultures in a way that I think many young Australians take for granted now.

I endorse the needed thrust of the strategic plan towards raising the profile of the museum in the community, not only at the local level but also for the tourist dollar. I would like to take this opportunity to applaud the museum's move to tap into the market of Australian schools through Kay Cottee's promotional correspondence with schools, writing to them and suggesting that they visit the museum. I ask honourable senators to commend the museum to their schools when they are visiting. It is an important part of Australia's history and culture that requires our support. I commend the strategic plan to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: NURSING HOME CHARGE (IMPOSITION) BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: This Bill proposes the introduction of a means of recovering unspent Commonwealth Nursing Home Benefit from the vendor of a nursing home generally at the time of sale.

SPEECH.PARA: The Nursing Home Charge (Imposition) Bill 1993 imposes a "charge" on the vendor of a nursing home on sale, equal to the amount of any benefit unspent by the nursing home up to 30 June 1993. This Bill complements and should be read in conjunction with the National Health Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993 which sets out the administrative arrangements for the collection and recovery of such amounts from the vendor on sale of a nursing home.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
DIESEL FUEL (EXCISE DUTY REBATE) ADMINISTRATION CHARGE BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: This Bill is one of a package of Bills proposing amendments to the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme to address the escalating costs of that scheme. Together with the Diesel Fuel (Excise Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 and the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 it addresses those escalating costs by proposing the following measures:
the imposition of an administration charge of 1% of the value of the rebate payable to claimants;
adjusting the rebate rate for indexation only once a year; and
establishing a time limit of three years after the purchase of fuel for claims for rebate.

SPEECH.PARA: This particular Bill deals with the first of those points; that is, the imposition of an administration charge on certain applications for rebate of excise duty paid in respect of diesel fuel. As with the Diesel Fuel (Customs Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 the charge is based upon the Government's intention to recoup the costs of administering the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme. Approximately $1,000m is anticipated to be rebated under the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme in 1993-94 and the cost of administering the scheme is anticipated to be approximately $11m, which is slightly in excess of 1% of the amount rebated.
Financial Impact Statement
This Bill together with the Diesel Fuel (Customs Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993, is anticipated to result in the following additional revenue collections:
$5 million in financial year 1993-94;
$11.7 million in financial year 1994-95; and
$12.6 million in financial year 1995-96.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present its accompanying explanatory memorandum.
DIESEL FUEL (CUSTOMS DUTY REBATE) ADMINISTRATION CHARGE BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: This Bill is one of a package of Bills proposing amendments to the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme to address the escalating costs of that scheme. Together with the Diesel Fuel (Excise Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993 and the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 it addresses those escalating costs by proposing the following measures:
the imposition of an administration charge of 1% of the value of the rebate payable to claimants;
adjusting the rebate rate for indexation only once a year; and
establishing a time limit of three years after the purchase of fuel for claims for rebate.

SPEECH.PARA: This particular Bill deals with the first of those points; that is, the imposition of an administration charge on certain applications for rebate of customs duty paid in respect of diesel fuel. The charge is based upon the Government's intention to recoup the costs of administering the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme. Approximately $1,000m is anticipated to be rebated under the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme in 1993-94 and the cost of administering the scheme is anticipated to be approximately $11m, which is slightly in excess of 1% of the amount rebated.
Financial Impact Statement
This Bill together with the Diesel Fuel (Excise Duty Rebate) Administration Charge Bill 1993, is anticipated to result in the following additional revenue collections:
$5 million in financial year 1993-94;
$11.7 million in financial year 1994-95; and
$12.6 million in financial year 1995-96.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present its accompanying explanatory memorandum.
EXCISE TARIFF AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1993

PARA.TAB: This Bill, together with the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 is part of a package of Bills which introduce a number of measures as already outlined in the second reading speech for the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1993:

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, this Bill proposes amendments to:

PARA.TAB: ensure that beer produced using commercial facilities in unlicensed premises is subject to customs control and to duties of excise; and to

ensure certain blended petroleum products and crude oil or condensate delivered for use otherwise than as refinery feedstock are excisable products, and that excise duty will be paid on the blend, the crude oil or condensate at a rate equal to either the diesel rate or the leaded petrol rate, depending upon the composition of the petroleum product.

SPEECH.PARA: In addition, this Bill also proposes amendments which will remove the excise exemption on gasoline and mineral turpentine produced from shale mined in Australia which is a consequence of the new arrangements to provide payments to certain producers of naphtha derived from oil shale as I have previously outlined in the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1993.
Financial Impact Statement
The financial impact for the first two measures is outlined in the financial impact statement in the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1993. The third measure has no financial impact.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present its accompanying explanatory memorandum.

SPEECH.PARA: HIGHER EDUCATION FUNDING LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this bill is to amend the Higher Education Funding Act 1988 in accordance with 1993-94 Budget decisions and other decisions made by the Government in respect of higher education.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill provides for over $4.6 billion for higher education in 1996, including some $500 million to be provided by the Government through the HECS Trust Account. As well, the bill provides for funds that are additional to those already legislated for. These additional funds total over $50 million in 1993, over $270 million in 1994 and over $320 million in 1995. Measures put forward in the bill will also generate additional revenues of $123 million in 1994, $183 million in 1995 and $126 million in 1996.

The Government has framed the measures covered in this bill to meet the need for enhanced efficiencies in higher education funding. These measures will also advance national goals relating to access, equity, diversity and quality in the system.

The bill's provisions include an amendment to the contribution made by certain students under the Higher Education Contribution Scheme—HECS. The change requires students who have already had access to undergraduate, professional and postgraduate opportunities to contribute, in general, twice the standard rate of HECS from January 1994 should they enrol in a second undergraduate course. The reasons for this change are very simple. Every student who undertakes a second undergraduate degree is excluding a school leaver or another person from attending university at all.

Other measures put forward in this bill modify repayment arrangements for HECS. From July 1994, repayment rates will be lifted from the present 2, 3 and 4 per cent levels to 3, 4 and 5 per cent respectively. Concurrently with this change, income thresholds for repayment of the HECS debt will be re-aligned with actual average weekly earnings. In addition, from July 1994 HECS repayments will be made on a PAYE and provisional tax basis.

The HECS amendments in this bill are both equitable and realistic. The measure relating to the amount of contribution stresses that as many Australians as possible should have access to higher education and that those who do have the chance to participate should contribute to the cost of that experience in the fairest way possible. This amendment acknowledges that in a climate of budgetary restraint the opportunities of newcomers to the system, including recent school leavers, have to be protected and that our students need to think very carefully about their study options. The amendment complements other initiatives which the Government is undertaking, in the context of its educational profile negotiations with institutions, to restore opportunities for those new to higher education, especially recent school leavers.

All the HECS measures introduced in this bill will reduce Commonwealth Government outlays to higher education and hence the public sector financial burden. HECS is not a tax. It is a deferred repayment loans system. As such, it is in the first instance a Government outlay and any reduction in student contributions requires greater Government expenditure. Income received through HECS is directly linked to the Commonwealth's ability to provide additional student places. In the same way as HECS has already provided opportunities for more Australians to participate in higher education, the HECS measures in this bill are essential for the Government to meet its ongoing commitment to increased access.

The provisions relating to income thresholds and the rates at which the HECS debt is repaid shorten the repayment period—from 15 to 9 years for the typical graduate—without increasing the actual cost to students. These measures also recognise that Commonwealth funding of the massive growth in higher education since 1989 has substantially exceeded HECS revenue. For example, income from HECS last year, including up-front payments, voluntary repayments and payments against HECS debt assessments by the Australian Taxation Office amounted to about $195 million. This was less than 5 per cent of the total Commonwealth 1992 outlay on higher education of $4.3 billion, which was $274 million above the level of funding provided in 1991. Outstanding HECS debts currently total in excess of $2 billion.

Under another measure introduced in this bill, students undertaking at least 75 per cent of a full-time study load through the new Open learning Initiative (OLI) will have access to a deferred payment facility similar to HECS. The OLI is already extending opportunities for a significant number of Australians who would otherwise find it difficult to participate in higher education by virtue of work commitments or other circumstances. Provision already exists for the Government to fund the development of a decentralised network to support open learning students. A deferred payment facility will further help these Australians by making it easier for them to make the required contribution to the costs involved in their education.

Additional growth in higher education for 1994 and 1995 has already been announced. This bill further expands opportunities for access in 1995 and 1996 with its provisions concerning any spare capacity which institutions may have.

The bill's amendments in respect of research and postgraduate education funding reflect the Government's policy of encouraging the higher education sector to maintain and strengthen its quality of provision and high international standing. The Government will continue the Research Infrastructure Program beyond 1994 at an enhanced level, providing $56.4 million in 1995 and $60 million from 1996 with total Infrastructure Program funding amounting to $176.4 million over the 1995-97 triennium. From January 1994, the Government will integrate the Australian Postgraduate Research Awards, the Australian Postgraduate Course Awards and HECS Exemption Scholarships into a single Australian Postgraduate Awards Scheme. 20,700 of these new Awards will be available in 1994, rising to 25,500 in 1997, an increase that will help expand participation in postgraduate education and thereby assist Australia to enhance its competitive edge in higher education and research. These measures will complement the further deregulation of postgraduate provision, allowing universities to build a postgraduate fee-paying market. Universities will be free to innovate, for example, by using Commonwealth postgraduate load to subsidise fee-paying students.

The Government's commitment to increasing the efficiency, flexibility and productivity of the higher education labour market is reflected in its support for the introduction of workplace bargaining. A national framework agreement for agency bargaining has been reached which the Government will support. This bill provides for on-going supplementation to be made available to universities for funding economic adjustments consistent with the Australian Public Service arrangements which provide 1.4 per cent followed by 1.5 per cent twelve months later. The arrangements cover both academic and general staff.

In addition, the Government will offer to each institution an advance of funds for a sector wide productivity related salary increase of up to 2 per cent for both academic and general staff. This would be conditional on there being agreement as regards a broad range of productivity related measures. There will be no on-going supplementation provided by the Government for productivity related salary increases.

The bill seeks to consolidate amounts at present specified separately in the legislation for quality, research, equity, National Priority (Reserve) Fund and advanced engineering centres. The distribution of funds across these programs is determined three years in advance but allocations to universities for most of these programs are made annually. This unnecessarily inhibits the capacity of Government and higher education institutions to respond to needs that emerge over the course of a triennium.

While this bill proposes the consolidation of funding, the specific purposes for which grants can be made will remain unaltered and programs will not be administratively affected. While the total level of available funding will continue to be legislated three years in advance, allocations will be decided annually and announced in the yearly higher education funding report. The value of this measure lies in the increased flexibility it will accord to recurrent funding arrangements. This will in turn assist universities and the Commonwealth to achieve their objectives with greater efficiency.

In summary, the measures put forward in this bill are part of the Government's overall strategy for enhancing the efficiency and effectiveness of the higher education sector. These measures seek to expand opportunities for Australians while recognising that there are limits to the contribution available from the tax-payer. They aim, in addition, to stimulate Australia's diverse higher education sector to maximise its capacity for providing a high quality product that meets the needs of its students and the nation as a whole.
I present the explanatory memorandum to this bill and commend the bill to the Senate.
STATES GRANTS (PRIMARY AND SECONDARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: This bill proposes to amend the States Grants (Primary and Secondary Education Assistance) Act 1992 to give effect to initiatives announced in the context of the 1993-94 Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill proposes to establish a pilot program for transition support for students with disabilities for an initial period 1994 to 1996 at a cost of $5.1 million.

Additionally $3.6 million developmental funding is to be provided over three years from 1994 to 1996 to support existing and developing hostels for rural school students. The Students at Risk program, which was due to cease at the end of 1994, will be extended for a further two years, with funding of $13.5 million.

This bill also finalises the full implementation of the National Equity Program for Schools for 1994, including the broadbanding provisions endorsed by the Australian Education Council which provide financial assistance under four elements focused on access, equity, national priorities and incentives. Following agreement with school authorities these new provisions will replace the interim arrangements that existed in 1993.
The bill provides for a number of other changes :

PARA.TAB: strengthening the Commonwealth's New Schools Policy for funding new and changing non-government schools; and
limiting eligibility for Commonwealth general recurrent funding to those students enrolled at non-government schools and attending those schools on a regular basis.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, this bill will provide funding schedules for programs under the National Equity Program for Schools and joint programs to support primary and secondary education for the remainder of the 1993 to 1996 funding period. I believe this will provide State and non-government school authorities with greater certainty in their future funding and facilitate a better planning basis over the medium term.

The bill sets grant levels for schools in the 1994 program year which are estimated to be $2.901 billion. Funds appropriated by this bill for the 1994 program year are estimated to be some $2.286 billion for general recurrent grants to Government and non-government schools, $303.7 million for capital grants to Government and non-government schools, $286.0 million for national equity programs, $18.0 million for the School Language Program and $6.5 million for other joint programs.

CUSTOMS AND EXCISE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: This Bill is part of a package of Bills introducing the following measures:

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, amendments to the Customs Act 1901 and the Excise Act 1901 to amend the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme to restrain the escalating costs of that scheme by:

PARA.TAB: establishing a time limit of three years after the purchase of fuel for claims for rebate.

introducing an annual adjustment of the rebate rates because of indexation of the duty rates applying to diesel fuel. This is considered to be an improvement to the previous system which adjusted the rates of rebate twice yearly (in February and August) but then averaged out these increases through the use of a six-monthly moving average. It is considered that the proposed improvement will, in addition to restraining costs under the scheme, simplify its administration; and finally
imposing an administration charge of 1% of the value of the rebate payable to claimants.

SPEECH.PARA: Secondly, amendments to the Excise Act 1901 (together with amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921) to address revenue loss due to the practice of brewing beer with the aid of commercial facilities in unlicensed premises (known as "microbreweries") and , in particular, to ensure that beer produced at microbreweries is subject to both customs control and to duties of excise. While the excise revenue loss is relatively minor at present, overseas experience indicates the potential for substantial revenue erosion;

Thirdly, amendments to the Excise Act 1901 (together with amendments to the Excise Tariff Act 1921) to address substantial revenue loss through the substitution of excise free or low duty products for petroleum fuels. Resolution of this issue involves ensuring certain blended petroleum products and crude oil or condensate delivered for use otherwise than as refinery feedstock are excisable products, and that the excise duty payable on the blend, the crude oil or condensate will be payable at a rate equal to either the diesel rate or the leaded petrol rate, depending upon the composition of the petroleum product;

Fourthly, amendments to the Excise Act 1901 to provide that where either blended petroleum products or crude oil are duty paid at the rate applicable to diesel fuel and where the products are for use in an eligible manner for the purposes of the Diesel Fuel Rebate Scheme, then a rebate of duty under that scheme is payable; and

Finally, amendments to the Excise Act 1901 to allow payments to certain producers of naphtha from oil shale where certain conditions have been met. These payments are intended to encourage the demonstration of new oil shale processing technologies, recognising that full scale commercial development needs to take place on its economic merits.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CROWLEY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Family Services and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women)

TALK.START.PARA: —I table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

PARA.TAB: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
The Childcare Rebate Bill 1993 will provide for the payment of rebates for expenses incurred for work-related child care as announced by the Prime Minister on 9 February 1993.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill realises a key election promise to the families of Australia.
It is another promise made and kept.
The cash rebate is a major plank in this government's commitment to increase the number of child care places, to make child care more affordable and increase the choices for Australian families.
It is an investment in our future.

This government recognises that women are unable to participate actively in the workforce unless they have access to affordable child care. The skills of women with workforce experience are extremely valuable in an economy dependent on the training and flexibility of the workforce.

The Cash Rebate will substantially increase the ability of women to work and to undertake further study and training. In short, it will allow them to contribute the full wealth of their talents and abilities to national growth and prosperity.
Child care is no longer a welfare issue. It is an economic issue and is now an integral part of the government's approach to building a highly skilled and adaptable workforce.

The Childcare Rebate is part of the Labor government's comprehensive child care policy. It recognises that most parents need quality child care at some stage of their working lives and that they need help with the cost of child care.
The rebate will significantly improve the affordability of child care for working parents.
It builds on this government's outstanding record of assisting families with dependent children through its support for child care.
When the Labor government was elected in 1983 there were just 46,000 operational child care places.
There are now more than 208,000 child care places in Australia. Budget funding for an additional 29,000 places will lift the number to approximately 237,000 by the end of this financial year.
This government has also promised to meet all demand for work related child care by the year 2001.
This will mean an increase in places to more than 300,000 by 1996-97.
And we have put money where our mouth is.
Commonwealth outlays have grown from $65 million in 1982-83 to over $550 million this financial year.
And as the places have grown, we have ensured that ordinary Australian families can afford to use the child care facilities.
This year alone, an estimated 170,000 low and middle income families will benefit from Long Day Care Childcare Assistance of up to $108.50 a week.

As well, the government has extended the more generous long day care Childcare Assistance to directly Commonwealth funded Occasional Care Centres from 1 July 1993. This has benefited a further 20,000 low and middle income families.
In February 1993 the Prime Minister announced further initiatives to build on Labor's child care commitment to families. These included:

PARA.TAB: the establishment of a care for sick children program. This will help employers establish sick care facilities and provide for suitable separate sick care facilities in child care centres and Family Day Care schemes.

to keep child care affordable, the Fringe Benefits Tax exemption was also extended to approved employer sponsored Family Day Care, Outside School Hours Care and Vacation Care services on 1 July 1993. The 1993 Budget legislation includes sales tax exemptions for goods used by child care services.

to ensure quality care for Australian children, the new Accreditation and Quality Assurance System will be implemented in child care centres from 1 January 1994. This fulfils yet another election commitment.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1993 Budget provides funding to implement these initiatives.
The Childcare Rebate Bill 1993 is another important step to ensure that child care is affordable for all working families.

Many families do not currently receive any government financial assistance for child care because their joint family income exceeds the threshold for child care assistance, or because they use informal care.
From 1 July 1994, parents using child care while in employment, training, studying or looking for work will be able to claim a rebate for part of their child care expenses.
An estimated 230,000 families with 358,000 children will benefit from the scheme.
As the Prime Minister said in Investing in the Nation, the childcare rebate recognises that the cost of child care is a legitimate expense for parents earning an income.
Just like other concessions for expenses incurred in earning an income, it will not be means tested.
Tax deductions of $4.9 billion each year are provided for work-related expenses such as subscriptions for professional associations and trade unions, car expenses and professional libraries.
The introduction of the child care rebate is a long overdue recognition of the costs of child care borne by parents and particularly mothers, in earning an income.
This bill recognises that all working families are entitled to some recompense against the cost of work related child care.
And to ensure that the benefits flow on to low income families, the government took the more equitable decision to provide this assistance as a cash rebate.
This will assist low income women and families because the rebate will be able to be claimed as the expense is incurred.

A deduction would have forced many families to carry these costs for more than a year before they could claim any benefit. It would also have provided greatest benefits to higher income earners. People below the tax threshold would not have benefited at all.
Instead, the use of a rebate ties the level of the benefit to the cost of child care incurred by the parent and not to the level of taxable income.

The Rebate will be payable fortnightly through Medicare Offices of the Health Insurance Commission. Eligible families will pay the first $16 of weekly child care costs and then be able to claim 30% of their costs up to a fee ceiling of $110/week for one child in care or $220/week for two or more children in care.
The maximum weekly rebate will be $28.20 per week for one child ($1,466/year) and $61.20 per week for two or more children ($3,182/year). The cash rebate is paid over and above Childcare Assistance.

The rebate will be paid for all work-related child care expenses for children aged up to twelve years of age. Child care expenses incurred by working parents in Long Day Care centres, preschools, Family Day Care, Outside School Hours Care, Vacation Care and in private child care arrangements will be eligible for the rebate.

Child care expenses incurred in care services not eligible for government assistance have also been included in recognition of the fact that almost two thirds of working families use these care arrangements, either by choice or because formal care is not available.
Care can be provided either in the child's home or another person's home. Carers must be over 18 years old and parents are excluded from claiming the cost of caring for their own children.

Child care providers, whether in formal child care services or at home will be required to register with the Health Insurance Commission through Medicare Offices and provide proof of age, proof of compliance with relevant State licensing requirements and a declaration that they have a Tax File Number. Carers will be given a Child Care Provider Number which must be quoted when issuing receipts for child care payments.
To address the privacy concerns of parents and care providers, the Minister for Family Services, Senator Crowley has been consulting with the Privacy Commissioner.
Let me stress that at no time will parents or providers be required to give details of their actual tax file number to the HIC. All they have to do is state whether they have a tax file number.

The registration form for care providers will require a declaration that the care provider has a tax file number. If a carer provides a tax file number, the Health Insurance Commission must not record the information. Carers who advise that they have a tax file number will be given a Care Provider Number which they must quote when issuing receipts for child care expenses.

Families will be required to substantiate their workforce status and the birth dates of their children. Families will have the option of allowing the Health Insurance Commission to use Medicare enrolment details to verify birth dates of children. Families will register with the Health Insurance Commission and be issued with a Family Registration Number.
Families will be able to claim the rebate by mail or in person at one of 240 Medicare offices around Australia, in a similar fashion to the Medicare rebate.

This will mean they will be able to get the rebate immediately across the counter. This arrangement will not only be familiar to many families, it will reduce the need to establish a separate service.
To enable the Health Insurance Commission to begin preparations for the Childcare Rebate, the Health Insurance Commission Amendment Act 1993 was passed during the Autumn sittings earlier this year.

This government is committed to enabling parents to fulfil both their work and family responsibilities by ensuring that quality child care is affordable and accessible. The Childcare Rebate is a central part of that commitment.
I commend this bill to the Senate.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will now add a few brief remarks to the second reading of the Childcare Rebate Bill 1993, as agreed. Firstly, this is a very appropriate time for this bill to be introduced as this is children's week. Secondly, it is also very appropriate because this is an election promised made and an election promise kept. The child-care rebate recognises that the cost of child care is a legitimate expense in earning an income. The government, in recognising that, does not intend to means test the rebate because it is like all other expenses associated with the earning of an income—they, too, are not income tested.

PARA.TAB: This child-care rebate, taken with the other child-care initiatives, means that Australia becomes the first nation to put together a coherent and integrated program which caters for the needs of working parents. We recognise in Australia the importance of women having the opportunity to participate, particularly in the labour market. This child-care rebate contributes to that package of child-care measures to allow women real choices when it comes to work and family. In summary, we accept the reality that child care is a crucial support to the labour market and to labour market participation and recognises that it is a cost necessarily incurred by parents in the earning of an income.

SPEECH.PARA: On 20 October 1993, the Senate referred eight Bills relating to the wool industry to the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs for consideration and report. These Bills reflect many of the recommendations and conclusions contained in the report of the Wool Industry Review Committee, which was chaired by Professor Ross Garnaut.

PARA.TAB: The Bills establish two organisations. The first organisation, to be known as Wool International, will assume responsibility for discharging the $2.28 billion debt and disposing of the 3.9 million bales in the stockpile, currently held by the Australian Wool Realisation Commission. The second organisation, the Australian Wool and Promotion Organisation will be responsible for generic wool promotion and wool research and development.

The Committee held a public hearing last Friday, 22 October 1993, and received oral evidence from seven organisations and two individuals. The Committee was particularly pleased that Professor Garnaut made himself available, not only to give evidence to the Committee, but to participate in a round table discussion with other witnesses and members of the Committee. The Committee also received twenty submissions on the Bills.

The report of the majority of the Committee outlines many of the issues raised at the hearing, particularly the fixed disposal schedule and the role of Wool International, as provided for in the Wool International Bill 1993. The Committee's report recommends to the Senate that the eight wool industry bills be agreed to without amendment. However, the Committee also urges the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy to consult fully with the industry on the further development of Wool International and to give further consideration to the Government's position on the future funding of wool promotion. I should indicate that the document that I have just tabled includes a dissenting report from Senator Woodley.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I indicated in my speech on the second reading, the amendments moved by the government to the Customs Legislation Amendment Bill are acceptable to the opposition and we do not wish to debate them.

—I would like some assurance from the minister that, as the old provisions are in effect being left in place, he will issue instructions that the report be published by the Anti-Dumping Authority before the minister makes his or her determination. The problem arises that once the minister has made the determination, it can only be overturned by court action.

PARA.TAB: The problem that has arisen in the past is that many of the reports from the authority have contained wrong or inadequate information on which the minister has then made a determination. The applicants in the anti-dumping action were precluded from drawing this to the minister's attention because time simply ran out. The only course of action open to them would be to go to the court. The provision as its stands, `as soon as practicable', in reality meant very often after the minister made his determination. This is why I prepared the amendment that the report be published at the same time as it is given to the minister.

Unfortunately, the opposition saw fit not to support me on that and the government indicated that it would not support such an amendment. So we are left with the status quo, with the old position, and that is unsatisfactory. I wonder what comfort the minister can give me in assuring me that the spirit of the legislation, that phrase `as soon as practicable', will actually be observed by the authority?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.TIME.STAMP: (Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: (5.24 p.m.)—Senator Spindler has spoken to me privately about this matter. I cannot give the categorical assurance that Senator Spindler would like. I am only in my first six months in the job on Customs and the Anti-Dumping Authority and am still coming to terms with dealing with 40-page reports about the whole procedure which technically is extraordinarily complex. However, one of the things I have quickly come to realise is that whichever way one jumps in relation to these reports, invariably someone will challenge and make complaints if they are on the losing side of a decision. Therefore, I am very cautious at the moment in making any commitment such as Senator Spindler seeks.

PARA.TAB: When the reports come from the Anti-Dumping Authority at the completion of its inquiries, I shall try to deal with them as expeditiously as possible, so that the time I sign them is about the same time they are being distributed to the public. However, if Senator Spindler wants to set in concrete the situation that, before I sign and agree to the initial report from Customs or to the authority's report, they are released and circulated, that means that people will lobby me not to sign or they will put information for me to argue the case that I reject the authority's recommendations.

That raises the issue that there is much more chance that the minister will be challenged in the court about why he made certain decisions. Then he will have to explain that company A, B or C came along and disagreed with the information. It then comes to the stage where the minister would have to argue that he has rejected information provided by the authorities for which he is responsible—namely, Customs and/or the Anti-Dumping Authority—after they have gone through a process of investigation, et cetera, and that he has taken advice separately from a company which may feel it is being hard done by in the report.

Judging by my limited experience so far, I would say that is somewhat of a Pandora's box. In my assessment of what Senator Spindler raised here in the chamber today, it would mean that there would be much greater emphasis on trying to convince the minister to overturn either Customs' initial report or the Anti-Dumping Authority's report later on, rather than relying on a process that this parliament has established with very clear-cut legislation about a transparent process. On balance, I would rather stick with the transparent process laid down in the legislation than try as a minister to second-guess before I sign or am lobbied. I think that would open up another argument about the political pressures, lobbying by sectional groups and so on.

I do not think this issue is as clear-cut or as advantageous as Senator Spindler may say it is. I am not saying that because I wish to avoid hearing representations or arguments. I hear them anyway because people who feel aggrieved by reports lobby all the time to have a re-hearing and so on, which is a process that is available under the legislation.

Although I cannot give Senator Spindler the assurance he would like, I think that in the circumstances the wording `as soon as practicable' is reasonable. The authority, the bureaucracy itself, very much would like me to make it clear-cut. That is why they put the suggestion to me that it only be released clearly after I have signed it so that there is no doubt, which has some merit in my view in making the process very clear-cut. However, because of the views in the Senate, we are not proceeding with that. We are staying with the status quo. If Senator Spindler asks me the same question in six months, I may be willing, with a bit more experience, to chance my arm on some of this. I warn anybody that dealing with dumping inquiries is not a game for new players or for people to do things off the cuff.

Each decision that one makes substantially affects industry, investment and employment one way or the other. Senator Spindler knows that because he has argued the case here so often. But I think any minister of the crown has to be very careful about that responsibility. I take on board what Senator Spindler says. I will discuss it with my officers in the Customs Service and the Anti-Dumping Authority. I cannot give the honourable senator the categorical assurance he needs, but I do take on board what he has said.

TALK.START.PARA: —I take on board what the minister has said, but I would like to pursue it just a little further. It is not so much giving them a chance to lobby the minister; it is giving them a chance to put right wrong statements or wrong information that may be part of the report from the authority. Firstly, I wonder whether we should cut that off or force people to go to court. Once the minister has made a determination, the only way to do that is to initiate court proceedings.

PARA.TAB: Secondly—and the minister might like to respond to both these questions: if the authority's representatives, through the department, are here, could they advise what the normal practice is when they provide the minister with a report? What is `as soon as practicable to the public'? Is it within an hour of delivering it to the minister's office; is it within a day; is it within a week; or is it waiting until after the minister has made a determination to cut off any influence or any attempt at rectification by the people concerned?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as the Customs Service is concerned, it does it as soon as practicable and does not wait for my signature. As I understand it, determinations have been made available before I have actually signed them.

PARA.TAB: Of course, recently—I know this to be a fact—I had the experience while visiting Devonport, Tasmania, of finding that a very significant customs report on paper dumping had just been published the day before—before I had even seen it. As a politician and minister for customs, I would have been very happy to be in Devonport announcing it myself. But the process took its normal course before I even saw the report.

The Anti-Dumping Authority, as far as I can recollect, by and large, does wait for me to sign. I would not want to be held absolutely to that. But, from my recollection of six months, the authority puts them to me for reading and signing before it releases them. Of course, I have the option not to sign a dumping authority. I have not refused to sign any; I have not rejected any so far. Again, the consequences of rejecting a report by the Anti-Dumping Authority would probably mean that I, as the minister, would very rapidly be in court trying to explain why I rejected the authority's report. As far as I can recollect—and I cannot be absolutely exact on it—Customs gets a determination out as soon as it can, irrespective of the minister's position, and the Anti-Dumping Authority, by and large, publishes or circulates it after I have signed it.

Senator Spindler raised the question—as he would know, I am sympathetic—of lawyers and people having to go to the courts to get rectification of something they see as an error in the report and which they would like to get fixed, if they could, before going to the legal expense of taking recourse in the courts. Again, I think that is a reasonable point. All I can say is that is one point to which I am sympathetic because of my experience on the Senate cost of justice inquiry. I will raise that with the officers.

However, if we try to give people the opportunity to check the draft report, so to speak, I suspect there will be some hooks in it. There is then a question that some people may check and get something corrected and other protagonists may not have checked or had the same access in the same time. Arguments of natural justice may then occur about whether the process was even and transparent to all the parties concerned—whatever. But, because of Senator Spindler's and my concern about keeping legal costs down, I will raise that matter with both the Customs Service and the Anti-Dumping Authority.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not wish to delay the chamber unnecessarily. But, in response to what the minister said, if the Anti-Dumping Authority waits for the minister's signature, as a general rule, before it publishes a determination to the general public, I would submit that that is certainly against the spirit of the legislation, and it may be against the letter of the legislation. If the legislation says that it is to be published generally to the public `as soon as practicable after providing the minister with a copy', it does not say `publish it after the minister has signed it'. It says `publish it as soon as practicable after the minister has received it'.

PARA.TAB: I suggest to the minister that the practice that the authority engages in is certainly contrary to the spirit of the legislation and, possibly, to the letter of the legislation. I would like the minister to provide an answer to the chamber. If he is not able to do so today, I ask him to take it on notice, because I think it is totally unsatisfactory.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think the authority is acting in contravention of the spirit of the act, which says `as soon as practicable' after I have received it. I try to deal with determinations in a matter of a few days. I often get them on a Friday and they are my weekend reading. I try to let them know by the beginning of the next week that I have signed them.

PARA.TAB: My recollection—and I have been quite frank about it; I was not going to obfuscate and say I cannot remember or go generally around the place because I do not want to give misleading information—is that this is the way in practice. The authority believes that this is in the spirit of `as soon as practicable'. There is no great delay that affects people. But, again, I will take the point Senator Spindler raises and discuss it with the officers.

But my own view, after the discussion we have just had across the chamber, is that I think those determinations are within the spirit of `as soon as practicable after receiving'. If they were sitting on my desk for a month or something, then I think people would have every right to jump up and down. But we try to get these things done within a matter of two or three days.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: BOUNTY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I asked to be briefed on the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill, the legislation seemed relatively uncontroversial. We looked at the impact on the book industry. Some of our contacts in Western Australia felt that the bounty was virtually useless. Because it was so small, it was considered that it would not have an effect and it would not be missed.

PARA.TAB: I was curious about the effects that the bounty, as set out in the legislation, would have on the computer industry. Australia

SPEECH.PARA: being involved as a `clever society' with high-tech value added production sounded like a good idea. However, my curiosity got the better of me and I tried to find out exactly who was receiving the bounty. I have a list of companies which have received the computer bounty. I seek leave to table this document and incorporate it in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—

TALK.START.PARA: —The list showed that of $36,501,750 worth of bounty, $23,753,974—that is, 65 per cent—was paid to industries involved with the defence industry. I will give some examples. Alcatel is associated with STC Cannon, which has sold to the United States under schedule 13, which covers military equipment, electric and electronic components. AWA Defence is in the thick of military production and support. It sells more than the average TV set.

PARA.TAB: Boral Johns Perry—this is bad news for the forests of New South Wales and Queensland—has a 98 per cent monopoly on woodchipping on the north coast of New South Wales and a similar percentage for sawlogs. Along with another large corporation in south-east Queensland, it has a huge operation. It buys out small mills. The result in this case is bigger equipment and fewer jobs.

British Aerospace is another huge player in high-tech weaponry. Electro Optic Systems, the third or fourth biggest military exporter in Australia, used to supply lasers for medical use. Since 1989 it has been promoting MUGShots—that is, multiple purpose guns with laser ranging. Ericsson has a military subsidiary which is into radar, electro-optics, lasers and encryption-decryption devices.

GEC Marconi deals in anything from communications systems through to nuclear bombs. It may have stopped its nuclear activities recently, but in Australia electronic and communications equipment is exported overseas. GEC Marconi represents Marconi in the United Kingdom, which sells C3 systems—complete systems of command, control and communication—and systems for electronic warfare, including stealth technology, radar shielding, scrambling technology and doppler wave technology. It is possible to use sound as a weapon and cause pain and injury. GEC Marconi also represents Marconi Canada, which sells Amiga airborne navigation systems. Marconi promotes itself as a leader in electronics for anything from the seabed to 22,000 miles above the earth. GEC has an avionics division. Another company is GEC Marconi Defence.

IBM—well, the big blue would have to be involved—has marketing defence sections. In 1989-90 it sold various items to Hong Kong and encrypters to Thailand and South Korea. Northrup is a major military industry player in Canada. NEC is massive, supplying such things as field support services, shelters, space payloads, satellite microwave and optical technologies to Papua New Guinea, New Zealand, the Middle East and South-East Asia.

Wormald and Mayne Nickless work closely with the CIA in security. They are massive companies, with subsidiaries which are military contractors. They promote themselves as safety companies. In Australia they specifically work on damage surveillance and electronic monitoring systems for the military. Many of these are not only military industries aiding repression but also companies with huge overseas connections. Where is their money going? Overseas—into overseas death and destruction at that.

The legislation continues some degree of bounty for books. Instead of there being a very abrupt reduction, the legislation slows down the bounty from 1993. However, I could not help noticing that the bounties on computers—and I have mentioned some of the companies—are continuing until 1995. We are not sure exactly what the government or the opposition will do to support these kinds of bounties after that time.

Whilst the legislation does not specifically relate to reducing or keeping these bounties, I express our strongest protest that community funds are being used to sponsor this kind of industry. Although we will be voting for the legislation, we will be watching to see whether this immoral public subsidy of the arms industry continues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have to say to Senator Margetts that, whilst I anticipated a number of queries concerning this legislation, one of them was not an attack on the immorality of the arms industry. Senator Margetts read out a list of companies in respect of the computer bounty. The bounty is within industry policy and is not defined in terms of being specifically for defence industries. It meets the requirements of the general industry—
—They don't preclude defence industries either.
—Of course it does not preclude the defence industry. This government will always defend having a self-sufficient defence industry in Australia.
—These are multinational organisations.

—I agree with that. Some of them clearly are multinational, but some of them are also contributing to providing an adequate Australian defence force. Some of them are totally Australian owned. The biggest one that gets the computer bounty is AWA Defence Industries—it gets $4.3 million. That is a totally Australian owned company.
—This is a good thing to put community finances towards!

—I believe that it is a good thing to develop our own computer industry in Australia; that we encourage this development so that we can build our skills base in this very important industry—an industry of the future in Australia.

PARA.TAB: I also point out that, by and large, the spin-off from the necessary defence expenditure will very much flow into civilian applications. Senator Margetts has been talking about such things as satellite sensing and surveillance. Overwhelmingly the biggest market in the future within our own region is for quite benign civil application of such technology. For example, the remote detection of changes in sea levels will be done by satellites with sensing equipment developed first of all for a military application. There will now be a spin-off and this equipment will be used to do something that I would think the Greens from Western Australia would be very pleased to see; that is, monitoring for environmental reasons such things as the height of the oceans, land degradation and changes in the use of land.

I think I understand the principles the Greens argue for and their opposition to defence expenditure. But it is not all beer and skittles; some very good civilian spin-offs are being developed. We will have an application to develop Australian industry and create Australian jobs and Australian skill. So I am more than happy to defend the computer bounty. Section 9(5) of the Bounty (Computers) Act 1984, which deals with the bounty on computers, states:

SPEECH.PARA: Where:
(a)bountiable equipment is manufactured pursuant to a contract to which the Department of Defence is a party; and
(b) that contract:
(i) for reasons of defence strategy, requires that equipment to be manufactured in Australia; and
(ii)provides, by way of cost premium or otherwise, for the compensation of a manufacturer of the equipment for compliance with the requirement that the equipment is to be manufactured in Australia;
bounty is not payable in respect of that equipment.
I think that makes reasonably clear the regulations we have in place.

PARA.TAB: Senator Margetts mentioned the book bounty. I would point out to her that the book bounty has been extended but is still being wound down. Again, this measure is designed to help Australian industry. But an agreement was reached with the industry to extend further the wind-down in the book bounty. In both cases these are reasonable pieces of legislation in line with the government's philosophical position of reducing assistance and tariffs, where necessary, while providing bounties to assist and maintain an Australian indigenous industry that we all support.

I note Senator Margetts's view about the so-called immorality of computer bounties being used for the defence industry. I do not agree with that view. I believe that, in the long run, there will be a use for them not only in the good defence of Australia but also in civilian applications that will be good for all Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —In passing, I note what I regard as the hypocrisy of Senator Margetts's comments. A bounty is nothing more and nothing less than a form of protection. The Greens are clearly in the protectionist camp and believe in protecting Australian industries. We join with the government in supporting the controlled, ordered reduction in protection of industries. There have been attempts through these bounty procedures to look after and protect the domestic computer industry. It is a furphy and is hypocritical for the Greens to suggest that particular industries should not be protected because of the morality of other activities that a particular company might be involved in.

PARA.TAB: We congratulate the government on tightening the computer bounty. In fact, the measures in the Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill will result in savings to the taxpayer of $30 million over the next three years, a move that we applaud.

TALK.START.PARA: —Predictably, the opposition has jumped to the defence of the government's policy to rescue our economy on the basis of becoming armaments manufacturers and arms pedlars in the region. I would have thought it would be clear by now to the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) as well the opposition that the cold war has ended, that there is supposed to be a new world order and that we are supposed to be turning swords into ploughshares. I would have thought it is not beyond the wit of our government and of our industries to start with the civilian uses of high tech rather than use that spin-off as a pretext for engaging in weapons manufacturing and arms peddling. The lack of morality in that stance has been well and truly established over the centuries. I really do not see how with equanimity we can tolerate a government that says that our economic salvation depends on the manufacture of arms.

PARA.TAB: Certainly the argument that we need to be self-sufficient does not hold water. To be self-sufficient, we need patrol boats to ensure that our coastline is guarded; we need to be self-sufficient in the equipment that we need to guard our shoreline. We do not need equipment to become involved in so-called forward defence, which is part and parcel of other nations' global military strategies. I would have thought that the government would consider the changed strategic situation in the world and desist from supporting an industry that will drag us deeper and deeper into the mire of arms manufacturing and peddling on the pretext of producing some civilian spin-offs.

Industries in the United States and Europe, which have so far been engaged in the manufacture of war planes, tanks and other armaments, are finding uses for high technology and their equipment to produce material and goods which are useful in peacetime and advance the social aspirations of their communities. I find it extremely disappointing that our government is prepared to shrug off these arguments and say that there is a buck to be made in making arms and peddling them to the region. I believe it is something that needs to be considered. In currently providing succour and assistance to these industries for these purposes, the government needs to conduct some careful examination and to make some adjustment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to comment on Senator Minchin's claim that in standing up on this issue the Greens were being hypocritical. I want to make quite clear the Greens' position on tariffs and tariff reductions. We have been opposed to the across-the-board removal of tariffs where it occurs, despite the implications for communities, equity, the environment—and for the general welfare of Australia, which is never measured.

PARA.TAB: However, this is exactly the reason that I questioned why the government chose this industry as an exception. The exception is an industry which is involved with arms manufacture and arms exportation. Why are these things important? Why are other industries, which are being squeezed to the point of destruction, not considered important to support in terms of employment and the kind of revenue that they provide back to the government—revenue which many of these other multinational industries do not generate?

My question queried the mindless economic rationalism which generally has set an across-the-board reduction in tariffs, no matter what the cost to employment and equity. Yet here we are making an exception—and what an exception!

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to delay the committee, but I have to make a couple of further points, particularly after Senator Spindler's contribution. I find it a little strange that Senator Spindler, who consistently argues for government intervention and support to develop industry, refers to the fact that the range of industries that are listed are definitely involved in defence. All the industries have civilian application and all provide work in Australia and employ Australians. However, Senator Spindler believes that this industry has to be wound down and that people have to be removed from it because the Cold War has ended. I certainly agree with Senator Spindler that the Cold War may have ended, but for the sake of public security there is still a need to maintain a sufficient defence force for Australia. Future consequences, which we cannot judge at the moment, may change.

PARA.TAB: We have a modest defence force in Australia that is adequate for our needs. Part—not all—of the computer bounty is defence related and exists to help us have a self-sufficient defence force. What I find particularly strange is that the Australian Democrats have argued for a decade or more that they want a neutral position for Australia in defence matters and that we should not have any alliances. If that position exists, one then has to argue for a strong defence force because one will have no international alliances. An independent defence force would be needed to show the Australian people that we could completely defend ourselves against all contingencies without our having any alliances.

The Australian Democrats is the last party in here which should be criticising a bounty system that is encouraging the development of Australia's defence industries because, if anything, it fits the Democrats' long-term defence policy. If one took the Democrats' policy to the ultimate by getting rid of all alliances, we would need to have these sorts of high-tech industries so that we could have an independent defence force.

I listened with great interest to Senator Spindler's comments, which were generally about industry development and an interventionist role. I may disagree or agree with aspects of his argument, but on this aspect I do not think he ought to get his fingers jammed in the door by saying, `Let's knock all this over because it is contrary to the Australian Democrats' defence policy which envisages an independent defence force for Australia'. That policy needs the development of these industries.

His comments were generally against his own philosophy of developing Australian high-tech industries with government encouragement and development. I would have thought that, if he was going to attack us, he would have said that the bounty is not big enough for these computer industries, rather than that it is too big. Again, I emphasise that these companies do not get the bounty if they do not comply with the requirement that the equipment has to be made in Australia. Compliance with that requirement makes them eligible for assistance. As a result, I am advised that there may be less in this list that is actually purely defence related than the list that Senator Margetts has tabled would indicate.

I conclude on this philosophical point: we do not as a government—previous governments have had the same position—try to define within a category, be it computers or books, whether it is a good book or a bad book or a good computer or a bad computer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Maybe you should start.

—I cannot imagine a more horrendous process for the parliament or a government to start determining, from time to time, whether a computer is good or bad, whether a book is good or bad. Take the book bounty, for example. We do not attempt in any way to say that because we dislike the content of this book—
—We haven't raised that.
—The principle is the same.
—No, it is not.
—My word it is. The principle across the whole area of the bounties should be that we define the industry application, not the content.
—If you are talking about books for mass murder, you may have a point.

—Take the example of books. We will end up having in this place one of the most rip-roaring censorship debates of all time with, I would have thought, about 30 different views on the morality or otherwise of what books should be eligible for the bounty. This is a production bounty; it is not a content bounty. That is the principle for the book bounty; it is the principle for the computer bounty; it is the principle for the ship bounty.

PARA.TAB: I say to Senator Spindler and to the Democrats that we agreed, in negotiations on the budget, to introduce a $20 million bounty for the production of ethanol. I think that is a very good outcome for the industry portfolio. If, in the longer term, we can get ethanol to replace lead—even though I have some constituents in Port Pirie who make good quality lead at the Port Pirie smelter—that would be good for Australian industry. Above all else, it would be good for Australian kids. It is a bounty for ethanol production. We will not be selective about who is eligible for bounty, as long as they meet the production requirement. That is the way it ought to be.

I say to Senator Margetts and Senator Spindler: the day we try to be selective on quality of content, we are in for a terrible argument. In the list I have, 30 companies—many of them Australian owned—are getting the computer bounty. If we start to argue with them about the content of their computers, we are going to be in for a terrible argument and we will not get a satisfactory outcome, to say nothing of the argument we would get about censorship on books.

TALK.START.PARA: —I obviously cannot let the Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science (Senator Schacht) get away with some of the distortions that he has indulged in. Taking his example of books, if the government ever has the guts to introduce the racial vilification legislation, the minister could well have to face the question of whether a book that is contravening that particular legislation should or should not receive a bounty. Perhaps that is a question for another time when, and if, the government ever has the guts to introduce that legislation.

PARA.TAB: As the minister has acknowledged, the Australian Democrats have consistently argued for intervention by the government to assist Australian industries to become more competitive and to give them the same sorts of advantages that other governments who have not relied solely on the free market economy have given their industries. We have never said that this should be done for the armaments industry. We have always exempted the armaments industry from that request. We did that at the Aidex exhibition.

I would not have thought that there was a need to remind the minister of that. When we say that Australia should be self-sufficient and independent in defence matters and should be able to defend its shoreline, we are not saying—or implying—that Australia must produce each and every item of defence equipment that it requires. That is clearly not feasible for a country of 17 million people. We are saying that Australia should be independent and that it should not become a weapons manufacturer or an arms pedlar, either to the region or to the world at large. We should not buy economic recovery and industry development at the expense of adopting that particular position.
Bill agreed to.
Customs Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 reported with amendments; Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill 1993 reported without amendments; report adopted.
Bills (on motion by Senator Schacht) read a third time.

DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PARA.TAB: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendments made by the Senate to the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 3) 1993.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Consideration of House of Representatives Message

PARA.TAB: Message received from the House of Representatives acquainting the Senate that it had agreed to the amendments requested by the Senate to the bill.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) proposed:
That this bill be now read a third time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst I support the motion that the Taxation (Deficit Reduction) Bill (No. 1) be read a third time, I would like to take the opportunity to say how appalling it is that it has taken this government over two months to recognise that to retrospectively tax accrued annual leave is not in the national interest.

PARA.TAB: On this side of the chamber we have had, for good, sound taxation policy reasons, a strong attitude against the retrospective application of tax laws. But this government, anxious to rip the last dollar out of the taxpayers' pockets, decided in this regressive budget—designed particularly to hurt most the poorer paid members of our community—to impose a retrospective tax on both accrued long service leave and accrued annual leave.

A few weeks ago the government was forced by the reality of numbers to abandon its tax on accrued long service leave, but nevertheless it refused to take the hint and fought on to try to sustain its proposed new retrospective tax on accrued annual leave. I am pleased that the reality of the numbers in this place has finally brought it to heel and that ultimately it has had to accept the request of the Senate and, therefore, has abandoned this tax. That is a sound decision. It is regrettable that it has taken it so long to reach a conclusion that should not have been necessary in the first instance because it should never have been applied.

I do not want to stray too far, but I understand that it is unnecessary for the third tax bill to come back because it was in the form of an amendment rather than a request. The government has accepted an amendment that withdrew the linkage between part of the tax cuts that had been promised—in fact, written into law before the last election—and the new and extended taxes that this government was imposing by this budget. I am pleased that ultimately again the government has been forced to the reality that it was not going to be permitted by the parliament to maintain that linkage—a linkage which was absolutely contrary to promises that were made at the last election. I remind the Senate that the promises were for tax cuts, but what the people of Australia got was reduced tax cuts, plus—

TALK.START.PARA: —But early.

—They were brought forward a month or two and more than 50 per cent of the tax cuts, in effect, were put off forever. Not even Senator Schacht would argue that that was other than a breach of an election promise—l-a-w, law. `They are not just a promise, they are tax cuts that we guarantee to the extent that we have written them into law.' What was the first thing we got after the election? `We are going to abandon those tax cuts. Not only are we going to abandon those tax cuts but by the budget we are going to extend indirect taxes, we are going put up the fuel taxes, we are going to put up the sales tax on wine and we are going to put up wholesale sales tax'. Did we hear anything about linkage reform in the election campaign? Of course not.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! We are straying a bit.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did the government seek a mandate for increased taxes? Of course not—quite specifically the contrary. The government said it did not need it because this was the government with the magic formula. It was going to put down income taxes, it was not going to require any alternative taxation and it was going to reduce the deficit as well. It was all a load of nonsense—election lies—and the government got away with it. Members of the government laugh at us because they know that they were able to lie their way into office. Senator Schacht is proud of that. He thinks that is all part and parcel of the politics of this nation. He has this particular standard of political morality.
—Order! Could I indicate that we are straying a little from the motion that is before us.

—This is the third reading of the first tax bill, Mr Acting Deputy President. You will remember that that was the bill in which the government intended to increase tax on credit unions. It has been limited to some extent by a request of the Senate in that regard. It was another exercise of how a Senate committee—in that instance I moved for that, I think—served a useful purpose. The government has had to respond to the numbers in that regard.

PARA.TAB: It is also the bill that included the government's intention to extend the fringe benefits tax in a way that would have detrimentally affected the tourism industry without any real research as to whether there was an abuse which needed to be countered at all, which was the interesting thing in that regard. We would support avoidance measures, but the government had not done the work and it came along with this astonishing notion that people were being subsidised to take more expensive hotel beds in lieu of salary. It did not make sense. When the government was asked to justify it, we found that it had not thought it through. It was just another revenue producing measure, but the government had also made a mistake in that it was unlikely to produce the revenue it had anticipated. The government has had no choice but to take that one away and rethink it. I doubt whether we will ever see it again because, I think, quietly, it recognises that it was not a very smart idea.

Australia needs capital injection to build its tourist infrastructure, particularly as the Olympic Games approaches. What government in its right mind would impose measures that would have the contrary effect of reducing the incentive to put capital into speculative, as it always is to some extent, major capital infrastructure for tourism? These tax measures were not properly thought through. The third measure was the one that I started out with which was the retrospective taxation of accrued long service leave and accrued annual leave. The government has now been forced to back away from both of those as well.

This is an exercise where at least the Senate has been able to fulfil a useful function and, to some extent, bring this government to heel. There is no doubt that we would have liked to have done it to a much greater extent. We were very anxious to defeat 1.4 per cent of the government's revenue in these taxation packages. There is no doubt about that because the government did not seek the mandate that it should have at the last election and as Senator Schacht's leader in this place, Senator Gareth Evans, said in this place in 1981 in relation to our sales tax bills, `It is legitimate that we oppose them because you did not seek a mandate at the last election'. Not only did the government not seek a mandate but also it lied to the Australian people about its taxation intentions. We, therefore, had every right to oppose those taxes. If we could have persuaded the minority parties in this place to support us, we would have defeated them and then Australians would have been even better off.

Why would they have been even better off? Because the regressivity would have been overcome and because taxes on business—taxes that will be a disincentive to growth of business, investment in business and, therefore, the production of jobs—would not have been allowed to go ahead. But we were unsuccessful, I regret to say, in persuading the minority parties. To that extent, we only got them part of the way but at least the parts that I have mentioned are worthwhile changes and I am pleased that ultimately the government has had no choice but to therefore accept the request.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

PARA.TAB: I understand that Senator Hill felt the need to leap up and salve some wounded pride from the fact that the opposition set out to achieve one objective and failed and the government has overwhelmingly got the legislation that it wished passed with some amendments, some with which we agreed. DEBATE.TITLE: VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1993NATIONAL HEALTH AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1993

PARA.TAB: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Schacht) agreed to:
That these bills may proceed without formalities, may be taken together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Science and Small Business and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Science)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That these bills be now read a second time.
