SPEECH.PARA: I table a revised explanatory memorandum relating to the Vocational Education and Training Funding Laws Amendment Bill 1993. I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: VOCATIONAL EDUCATION AND TRAINING FUNDING LAWS AMENDMENT BILL 1993

PARA.TAB: The amendments in Part 1A of the bill are being introduced as a precautionary measure pending implementation of all the essential elements of the new arrangements based on the Australian National Training Authority, ANTA. In particular, the Commonwealth is concerned that most States and Territories have not yet introduced the complementary legislation which Heads of Government agreed would be necessary to give full effect to their July 1992 agreement on the National Vocational Education and Training System.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments provide that, if the Commonwealth Minister determines that a State or Territory has not met its obligations under the 1992 Heads of Government agreement, the Minister could direct ANTA not to pay any, or only a limited amount, of Commonwealth funds to that State or Territory. This new power is tied explicitly to the provisions of the Heads of Government agreement and could not be used by the Commonwealth to impose additional requirements on the States and Territories.

In introducing this legislation, there is no intention to undermine the ANTA arrangements and there is no criticism of the operation of ANTA itself. Indeed, the objective is to ensure that the ANTA arrangements are put on a firm footing by ensuring that the States and Territories meet their obligations from the outset. For this reason, the legislation provides that the new power to withhold funds would be available to the Commonwealth Minister only until the end of 1995. There would be no ongoing power for Commonwealth intervention in the allocation of funds through ANTA.
Part 2 of the bill amends the States Grants (TAFE Assistance) Act 1989 and the Vocational Education and Training Funding Act 1992.

These amendments provide for the appropriation of a total of $638.96 million in 1994; $719.741 million in 1995; and for an additional $10.872 million for capital purposes in 1993, in line with cost supplementation arrangements.
I present the revised explanatory memorandum for the bill.
NATIONAL HEALTH AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1993

PARA.TAB: This bill proposes an amendment to the National Health Act 1953 to complement amendments made last year to the nursing home benefit payments scheme by the National Health Amendment Act 1992.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill is related to the Nursing Home Charge (Imposition) Bill 1993 and should be read in conjunction with that bill.

The National Health Amendment Act 1992 was enacted to address inequities in the recovery of unspent Commonwealth nursing home benefit when a nursing home is sold. These problems flowed from a quirk in the legislation which meant that amounts of unspent benefit were not legally characterised as debts to the Commonwealth. Where a nursing home proprietor accrued a liability and sold the nursing home, that vendor could not be pursued for the money after the sale. The purchaser became liable for that amount.

Whilst the Commonwealth nevertheless had a statutory duty to recover such amounts, they could only be recovered via an offset or ongoing "negative fee loading" to the approved daily nursing home fee and, by extension, the amount of Commonwealth benefit payable each month. This sometimes resulted in the purchaser acquiring a home subject to a liability accrued by a former proprietor. Although the industry was well aware of these arrangements and usually made appropriate provisions in contracts of sale, problems still occurred.

The National Health Amendment Act 1992 addressed this situation by providing that amounts of unspent benefit were characterised as debts recoverable from the vendor on sale. It contained a number of key measures to support its purpose, including a requirement for vendors to give 90 days notice of a sale. This period of notice enables the vendor's claims for Commonwealth benefit, books and records to be examined so that, prior to completion of the sale, a fair estimate of any overpayment can be made.

However, these changes only apply prospectively, applying to benefits paid after the commencement of the National Health Amendment Act 1992 on 1 July 1993. Benefits paid prior to the commencement of that Act are not subject to its provisions and the pre-existing system of recovery by fee loading continues to apply in respect of benefits paid up to 30 June 1993.

The two bills tabled for consideration in the current sittings together allow for the debt recovery measures to extend prior to 1 July 1993. The Nursing Home Charge (Imposition) Bill 1993 imposes a "charge" on the vendor of a nursing home on sale, equal to the amount of any benefit unspent by the nursing home up to 30 June 1993. The National Health Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1993 sets out the administrative arrangements for the collection and recovery of such amounts from the vendor on sale of a nursing home.

This latter bill also provides that where the Commonwealth holds monies in trust for the benefit of the vendor pending completion of an investigation of the nursing home accounts, and on completion it is found that money is repayable to the vendor, the Commonwealth is liable to pay interest at commercial rates on the amount repayable.

These measures complement those in the National Health Amendment Act 1992. They provide, effectively, that amounts of unspent benefit paid prior to the recent prospective amendments, are recoverable from the vendor as debts on sale.

The National Health Amendment Act 1992 received the support of both the nursing home industry and the coalition, as expressed in the House by the honourable member for Bradfield, Mr Connolly and in the Senate by Senators Newman and Patterson. Those who spoke did, however, express a concern, shared by the industry and the Government alike, that there was a need for those measures to be applied prior to 1 July 1993.

The National Health Amendment Act (No. 3) 1993 addresses that need by complementing the National Health Amendment Act 1992 to augment the protection already given to the rights of purchasers of homes, provide a more equitable system and enable the Commonwealth to recover unspent moneys in a more timely manner.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Senator Panizza) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 2 September, on motion by Senator Sherry:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raced down to the chamber on Thursday night at two minutes to nine to speak on the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). I was told I had two seconds to get here. It has been an awfully long two seconds. But I suppose two seconds in politics can be as a long as a week.

PARA.TAB: Earlier this evening the Senate was debating the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 which deals with five separate social security matters. First, the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) seeks to give effect to the government's election promise of a senior's health card. This card will be available to retirees with incomes below the part pension threshold who are not eligible for the pension.

The coalition does not oppose this beneficial initiative but notes that the government has postponed its commencement until July 1994. The Australian public ought to be reminded—and I will continue to remind older Australians—that they were promised during the election campaign that the card would commence in April 1994. So yet another promise of this government has been broken. Older people were promised to be taken out of the taxation system by 1995 if they were on a pension. That promise was dismantled five days after the election because of some feeble excuse of the Treasurer, Mr Dawkins. In fact, the opposition believes the government knew before the election that it would not meet that promise. This is yet another promise that was broken after the election.

To date, the government has given no adequate reason why it needed to postpone this promise. It also should be noted that the coalition's extension of the pharmaceutical benefits concession card in our policy entailed a more generous income test with higher cut out incomes.

This bill provides for foreign income to be taken into account in the income test for family payment from January 1994. The coalition supports this initiative. In a needs based system there is no valid reason why income earned overseas should be treated more leniently than income earned in Australia.

As a result of this bill, foreign currency conversions will be undertaken fortnightly rather than quarterly. An advanced pharmaceutical allowance for the chronically ill will continue until the end of 1994. The coalition supports all of these quite reasonable initiatives.

The most contentious change in this bill is the decision to include certain employer funded fringe benefits, namely, motor vehicles, housing loans, school fees and private health insurance in the income test for family payment and the parental income test for Jobsearch and Newstart allowees aged under 18. This initiative, which is due to commence on 1 January 1994, is based on the premise that taxable income is not always a fair indication of disposable income because it includes a range of non-monetary benefits for which employers pay fringe benefits tax. The planned income test will apply when the total annual fringe benefit exceeds $1,000.

The main bone of contention in relation to this provision has been its application to the Australian defence forces. Members of the defence forces are eligible for rental subsidies and low interest housing loans. It is contended by representatives of the forces that these benefits are compensation for remote postings and frequent dislocation.

It is also argued that defence personnel are underpaid and that this provision will result in a further reduction in their standard of living. In response, the government claims that defence personnel are not a special case and other professions are in a similar position.

When considering this contentious proposal it is beneficial to examine the history of these social security payments. It was the Menzies Liberal government that introduced child endowment in 1941. Senators on this side of the chamber should be justifiably proud that their Liberal predecessors had the foresight to introduce such an important financial recognition of the costs of raising a family. It was also another Liberal government, the Fraser government, which in 1976 replaced the child endowment with a non-income or assets tested family allowance system. The current family payments system, which comprises a basic family payment which has replaced family allowance and an additional family payment, is both income tested and assets tested.

The main rationale for imposing these incomes and assets tests is the fact that in a needs based system of assistance finite revenue resources should be targeted to those families which are in greatest need. However, it is equally important in a needs based system that people with equal financial needs receive equal financial assistance. This is the principle of equity.

It has become very apparent, both in the family payments system as well as in other payments such as Austudy, that the current income and assets test do not ensure that the finite cake is distributed equitably. People with notional incomes that are sometimes well above the cut out limits or thresholds are able to receive assistance because these notional incomes are not taken into account in the current income test.

The coalition has recognised in its welfare policy that if Australia is to continue to pursue a needs based system of assistance then that system should be effective in ensuring that assistance is targeted to those who are most in need. With this initiative, the Labor government is belatedly recognising the fact that some people have been able to circumvent its family payment income test because it does not take such notional benefits into account.

Hence, the coalition is in favour of the initiative generally because it will provide a better targeted needs based family payments system. However, its application to our defence and police forces is an entirely different matter. In both cases, the application of this provision would affect housing related assistance provided by the beneficiary's employer. However, in neither case could such assistance be reasonably considered to be a fringe benefit. On 2 May 1986, the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, who was then the Treasurer, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: There has over the years been a very strong movement towards the remuneration of employees—especially higher income earners—by fringe benefit packages which allowed income tax to be avoided on substantial parts of the overall remuneration. So called tax-free perks came to dominate salary package negotiations and packages were openly advertised in the market place.

There is no possible way that the housing assistance that is provided to our defence and police forces could be considered to fit the ex-Treasurer's definition. The defence and police housing assistance is certainly not confined to higher income earners, nor is it an attempt to avoid tax.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, we were talking about people in the defence forces and the police forces. Most importantly, there is absolutely no way that assistance by the provision of housing could be considered to be a `perk' in that normal meaning of the word. On the contrary, in both the defence forces and the police forces such housing related assistance is compensation for what we would call job-peculiar hardships that these employees must endure.

PARA.TAB: I have no doubt that if any service person or police person was asked whether he or she would prefer to live permanently in one place without the constant burden of dislocation, the answer would be a very loud yes. I believe that this is the test that must be applied when deciding whether non-financial assistance is a fringe benefit or merely compensation.

In the case of the defence forces and police forces, it is obviously compensation—but do not just believe me. The specific goals of the government's own policy in relation to housing for the Australian Public Service and the Defence Force include, firstly, compensating personnel for housing related disabilities consequent upon frequent relocation where this is required as a condition of service; secondly, providing adequate accommodation for personnel who are required in the course of duty to reside in locations where suitable alternative accommodation is not available, or who are required for essential operational reasons to reside at Defence Force or APS premises; thirdly, minimising financial disabilities of personnel required to relocate frequently, which are due to interregional differences in housing costs; fourthly, providing that an APS or Defence Force member not be out of pocket from reasonable expenses incurred in changing houses; and, fifthly, minimising housing related detriment to morale of personnel and families when personnel are required to relocate frequently.

The common theme that runs through each of these specific goals is the fact that such payments are compensations for conditions of service endured by the person who receives the payment. This fact was reiterated in the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on personnel wastage in the Australian Defence Force, which stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Defence force members are required to serve, when, where and as required, often in the most hazardous circumstances . . . Family moves are regular, sometimes seemingly random and frequently stressful . . . The ethos of service remains paramount.

While the concept of service, in the context of this provision, is secondary to the overriding fact that these payments are not fringe benefits but are compensatory in nature, it nevertheless figured strongly in the evidence provided to the Senate committee by the police representatives. Senior Sergeant O'Gorman's evidence is very telling. He stated:

If you are transferred to a remote or disadvantaged area, which is usually where the highest majority of our people are provided with housing, you have no choice about where you live; you will live in the house that is attached, sometimes physically attached to the police station where you will perform your duty. You are usually operating in areas where you are the lone police officer, or one of two.
Later in the same address he said:

When the police officer is away from the residence or away from the station performing duty . . . the police officer's partner or spouse is required to remain at the residence/police station and continue the operational functioning of that police station.
I would have liked to have said this to the Greens and the Australian Democrats. Senator Woodley is here, and I would like him to listen carefully to what Senior Sergeant O'Gorman said:

When people are arrested and placed in cells, the cells are usually in the yard of the police residence, usually within 20 metres of the house. The incessant abuse and the type of abuse that issues from those cells should not be inflicted on anybody. Police officers themselves can deal with it, but the families are required to deal with it. The families are required to feed these people and attend to their needs if the police officer is absent, and these are the families that this legislation is asking to pay a higher level of tax for the `privilege' of serving in those sorts of areas.

This is not a fringe benefit. We are saying that it is compensation for the fact that they have to live in those places and also that their families have to deal with the sorts of things that Senior Sergeant O'Gorman was talking about. It is obvious that the application of this initiative to the housing assistance that is provided to members of our defence forces and police forces is a significant departure from the normally accepted definition of `fringe benefit'. In the committee stage, I will be moving to remove both the defence forces and the police forces from the relevant definition of `current employee' in the bill. This will have the effect of precluding the application of this fringe benefit income test from assistance that is totally compensatory in nature.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments to the Social Security Act contained in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993 before us today will impact in five areas. Firstly, they will make foreign currency provisions more responsive to market exchange rate fluctuations. At present, the exchange rates used in assessing overseas income for the purpose of determining pension entitlements are adjusted four times a year. With the daily fluctuations of the Australian dollar against other currencies, this system may not give an accurate indication of a person's entitlement. This bill proposes to have a new exchange rate for each nominated currency to be determined each and every pension payday.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats acknowledge the problem and accept this proposed change. My only concern with the move is that in response to the overseas income adjustments, a person's entitlement may need to be adjusted fortnightly. My concern is that this could lead to an absolute barrage of letters of advice going out to people. As anyone who has been a social security recipient would tell us, the number of letters they receive can be phenomenal. We hope this measure does not exacerbate this situation.

A second amendment in this bill seeks to extend the period of payment for the advance pharmaceutical allowance for a further 12 months to 31 December 1994. While I understand the number of people taking advantage of this up-front payment facility is relatively small, for those people it is a valuable allowance and the Democrats support its extension.

A third amendment seeks to ensure that foreign income is included in the income test for family payment. I understand that this amendment is necessary to apply to those cases where there may be one parent who is a non-resident for taxation purposes working for an overseas company and being paid a high salary. At present, this salary is not being taken into account in assessing eligibility for family payments. The Democrats support this change.

The three measures I have just mentioned—the foreign currency provisions, the extension of the advance pharmaceutical allowance and the inclusion of foreign income in the family payment income test—are all measures the Democrats agree with, and I do not intend to go into them in any further detail. I would, however, like to spend some time discussing the remaining two changes; that is, the inclusion of fringe benefits in certain social security income tests and the introduction of the seniors health card.

As honourable senators will be aware, the issue of inclusion of certain employer provided fringe benefits in a number of social security income tests was the subject of an inquiry conducted earlier in the week by the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs. The underlying issue which was the subject of the committee's considerations was whether or not taxable income is really an adequate measure to use when assessing a person's eligibility for certain social security allowances. The bill before us today seeks to include certain employer provided fringe benefits in the income test for family payment and in the parental income test for those aged under 18 applying for jobsearch allowance or sickness allowance. The Democrats support this change.

The inclusion of these fringe benefits reflects the recommendation of the 1992 Chapman report on Austudy, and a similar change to that which we are now discussing for social security will shortly be effected to Austudy through regulations. The argument behind these changes is that, by including such benefits, we get a better picture of people's real income level and their need for government assistance. Under the current system of income testing, some recipients have real incomes which would normally exclude them from eligibility.

The benefits to be included under this legislation are employer provided motor vehicles, loan benefits, school fees, subsidised housing and private health insurance. The value of these benefits to a person, and to that person's partner, will be added together and that amount which exceeds the $1,000 `free area' will be counted as income in the social security income tests.

The primary focus of the community affairs committee's considerations was to decide whether or not it was justifiable to include the benefits I mentioned before, particularly as they apply to service families and to police, in these social security income tests. The committee received representations from various service groups and the Police Federation of Australia and New Zealand. These people argued that there is a distinction between fringe benefits and specific conditions of service and that the rental subsidy provided to our service families and police is not a fringe benefit, but rather a condition of service which partially compensates for the disadvantages and difficulties inherent in service life. In particular, we are talking about the operational need for postings to various locations.

The Democrats understand these arguments. However, we believe the overriding issue that needs to be considered is people's ability to meet living costs and their associated need for government assistance. At the moment, the income cut-off for basic family payment is $64,938 per year with $3,249 for each additional child, combined with an assets limit, exclusive of the family home, of $600,000. These figures will be reduced next year to $60,000 and $550,000 respectively.

At the inquiry the Department of Social Security indicated that it believes the majority of Defence Force personnel—about 70 per cent, I believe—to be affected by this change would be in the position of losing their basic family payment; in other words, those for whom the inclusion of fringe benefits will take their income above this $60,000 a year limit. This seems to be a large number of our defence personnel earning just short of $60,000, which surprises me somewhat. I am not sure that I agree with the assumption the department used in arriving at that figure, but I will leave that to one side for the moment.

The income cut-off for maximum rate additional family payment, and the health care card that goes with it, is $20,950 a year with an additional $624 allowed for each extra child. The allowance begins to cut out at around $25,000 with an additional $3,800 allowed for each extra child. So a family with three children is allowed an income of around $36,000 a year before its additional family payment is withdrawn totally. The Department of Social Security estimates that around 30 per cent of defence families affected will see a change to their additional family payment entitlement.

The opposition's dissenting report on this issue makes much of the fact that certain allowances received by defence personnel and police are paid as a result of various conditions these people work under. The Democrats have no argument whatsoever with the need to provide such allowances. The issue at stake here, however, is whether the allowances should be included in determining a person's eligibility or need for government assistance through various social security benefits.

Here I want to reply to Senator Patterson who asked me to listen carefully to the police evidence which she quoted. I can tell Senator Patterson that I found the police evidence very unconvincing and I am aware that in some parts it was simply inaccurate. I have personal experience of this, for my daughter was married to a policeman and I have lived in many of the towns which were quoted as having substandard accommodation for police. Although I have quite a deal of sympathy for defence personnel, I must say that I do not have the same amount of concern for police, even though I acknowledge that they, too, suffer some hardship. It is a pity that the police evidence presented was not as convincing, for me at least.

That does not alter the principle that people living side by side in the same town, whether it be a provincial city or a remote country village, ought to be treated equally in terms of social security benefits. In this instance, the proposed Greens' amendment does not help much either because the inequity between people would still exist. Although the Greens certainly catch up more people in their amendment, there are still people left outside, and even more left outside of the proposed opposition amendment. The principle with which we agree is that people should be treated equally when making an assessment for these payments.

I will give the Senate one or two examples. I visited the town of Woomera in South Australia. The proposed coalition amendment would say to us that civilians living in Woomera and service personnel living in Woomera should be treated differently in assessing their need for basic family payment and additional family payment. As was indicated in the government's paper on this issue, although the Greens catch up a number of other groups in their amendment, there are still people left outside such as the clergy. I certainly would not want to say, `Well, let's include them too', because I believe that the same principle applies, and that is, we ought to treat everybody in the same way on this issue.

One of the problems I have with the Greens' amendment is that it is so hard to assess the same kind of evidence presented on behalf of the people they have spoken about because most of the groups did not appear. In the teachers' case there was only a written submission and, in any case, the principle of equity remains. The Democrats have given much consideration to this issue and we believe that it is justified to include these allowances for assessment of the level of basic family payment and additional family payment and the other issues.

I reiterate that the Democrats believe that the overriding consideration in this issue is identifying the best means by which to determine a family's need for government assistance. In this regard we believe that a family receiving a fringe benefit is indeed better off than a family not receiving a similar benefit, and as such we support this change.

I wish to spend a little time on the final change proposed in this bill for it relates to the Australian Democrats' long held concern for self-funded retirees. From 1 July 1994 all people of age pension or age service pension age with an income below the pension cut off point will be eligible for a seniors health card. The legislation before us today will provide holders of that card with concessional pharmaceutical benefits and hearing aid concessions, and legislation to follow soon will provide card holders with certain dental and optometry services.

The government has estimated that around 200,000 people will qualify for the card, including many who have been previously precluded from pension eligibility on the grounds that they are holding too large a level of assets, even though those assets may have been yielding only a very modest income. Self-funded retirees have often been behind the eight ball in this regard due to the level of the assets they hold. Those assets are funds that these people have put away throughout their working lives in order to provide for themselves in their retirement. What may seem like a high level of assets is in fact the fixed sum these people have to live off for the rest of their lives.

The value for these people of their assets, while sometimes seemingly large, is seen purely in terms of the level of income generated by those assets. Of course, as a direct result of this government's policies, many self-funded retirees have had their incomes more than halved in the past few years.

The introduction of a seniors health card is in accordance with the Democrats' long held and often espoused belief that retirees on the same level of income as pensioners should be entitled to the same benefits regardless of the source of that income. The Democrats recognise the uniqueness of the situation these people are in and have always argued that self-funded retirees on the same level of income as pensioners should be entitled to all benefits available to pensioners on the same level.

It has been part of our aged persons policy for many years to extend the fringe benefits currently available to age pensioners to all retired people who have the same level of income as those pensioners who qualify for the concessions. As such the Democrats would not only provide these people with health cards but also with the public transport concessions, reductions in telephone and electricity costs, as well as car registration fees and household rate concessions that age pensioners are able to claim. Further, we would extend the existing age pensioner tax rebate to all retirees, provide a savings incentive in the tax system by paying a rebate on the first $1,000 of interest received by all taxpayers, including self-funded retirees, and would be looking to increase the tax-free threshold from its currently low level of $5,400 to a more reasonable figure of around $7,000.

Independent retirees have the same needs as pensioners and to treat them less favourably is clearly unfair and acts as a disincentive for people to provide for their own retirement. The need for equity in this area becomes even more crucial as we are now moving into a period when almost everyone will be involved in superannuation. The Democrats welcome the seniors health card, but urge the government to consider extending those benefits even further.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to enter this debate on the basis that I want to represent the interests of the Australian Defence Force since the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) and the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel (Senator Faulkner) have quite clearly abdicated their responsibilities to their charges in this regard. The government collectively has just walked away from the interests of the Australian Defence Force on this particular matter. I do not wish to debate the large part of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2), but the way the ADF will be cut to ribbons financially over this is something that I will not tolerate without protest.

PARA.TAB: I suppose that at one level the real problem is the socialist Minister for Social Security, Mr Baldwin, who has a well-known hatred of the defence forces, which is shared by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). That is in contrast to the previous Prime Minister, Mr Hawke. While he was not prepared to give any money to the defence forces, at least he stood up for them against the Left-leaning members of his cabinet. Mr Hawke saw that the defence forces were not reduced to impotence in the way that they have been under the present incumbent, Mr Keating.

What is proposed here in the bill has caused huge morale problems in the Australian Defence Force. Defence votes have fallen every year this government has been in power. That has meant shrinking budgets for operational training and all the things that people join the defence forces to do. Members of the defence forces are reduced to being clerks, sitting down painting bricks white and all the other pointless things that do not cost much money for a government to keep them there.

At the heart of this matter is the abdication of leadership. The defence forces turn on leadership. The private looks to his corporal to look after his interests and, in turn, the corporal knows that the private will look after him; and it goes all the way up the line to the chief of the Defence Force. Everyone in the services expect the minister, or in this case the ministers, to look after their interests.

We know from the evidence that was given at the estimates committees that the ministers did nothing. If both ministers had come out of cabinet reeling and bleeding and saying that no more could be done by anyone, the defence forces would be in a totally different frame of mind. But they know that there was not even the weakest of protest when the left wing rolled over them on this issue.

Senator Patterson has dealt with this bill very eloquently, and I do not propose to recount the argument that she has put forward. I want to deal with the part of the bill that deals with fringe benefits as applied to the ADF. It is very clear that the government meant the ADF to be included because the definition section of the bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: `current employee' means: . . .

PARA.TAB: (c)a person who is otherwise in the service of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory (including service as a member of the Defence Force or as a member of a police force). . .

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the things I am saying, of course, apply equally to the police forces. Why were the defence forces included in this? Quite simply, it was a shoddy, money-grubbing exercise—in exactly the same vein and mind-set which led to the cutting back of the allowances to the troops in Cambodia.

PARA.TAB: The government misled the troops in Cambodia. It called for volunteers and got 150 to stay behind for five weeks in the belief that they would be paid the allowance of $65 a day tax free under which they had served their 12 months. The day after the main contingent left—surprise, surprise—the allowance was cut back from $65 tax free to $40. Why? It was as a result of money-grubbing and the government's attitude of cutting the defence forces all the time.

What fringe benefits does the Defence Force get? The government clearly states that such benefits are employer provided—motor vehicles, housing, loans, school fees and private health insurance. If one goes back to the days when the Prime Minister was Treasurer, one sees that he said income received as a fringe benefit was `one of the most rutted tax shelters and the most untouchable income of all.' He also said:

SPEECH.PARA: There has over the years been a very strong movement towards the remuneration of employees—especially higher income earners—by fringe benefits packages which allowed income tax to be avoided on substantial parts of the overall remuneration. So-called tax-free perks came to dominate salary package negotiations and packages were openly advertised in the market place.

It is impossible to reconcile that with the members of the ADF. For a start, the government never gave conditions of service to the ADF as a tax shelter. That is nonsense. They are there as a form of compensation. Secondly, the great majority of service personnel who will be affected by the inclusion of these conditions of service as fringe benefits for the purpose of the social security family payment income test are not in any circumstance high income earners. Finally, Defence Force personnel do not negotiate salary packages with the government. Is the government really saying to the Senate that it created tax havens for members of the ADF?

PARA.TAB: By doing what it is proposing to do, the government is reneging on its obligation to compensate Defence Force personnel and their families for their conditions of service. That comes about because the conditions of service under which the Defence Force serve really are unique. It is quite wrong for Senator Woodley to preach a level of equity. I will come to that argument later, because members of the Defence Force are not senators; they are not members of parliament; they are not civilians in any sense at all. In 1989, the government put it this way:

SPEECH.PARA: Conditions of service are the elements of ADF remuneration that recognise, in a tangible way, that the profession of arms is a unique profession. Specialist allowances recognise special skills, and other allowances make up for disadvantages or difficulties inherent in service life, most of them clustered around the operational need for postings.

So the benefits that the members of the defence forces are paid are compensation for what they do, particularly for the turmoil of being posted from one town to another. I was deputy chairman of the defence subcommittee which did an investigation into personnel wastage in the Australian Defence Force. One of the passages in that report reads:

Conditions of service thus should encompass not only pay and allowances but also a comprehensive range of compensation relating to family and social issues, superannuation, hours of work, housing and operational privileges.

It is quite wrong for the government to turn on the defence forces in the way it has in this bill, particularly in relation to their rental assistance. Housing at a subsidised rent is provided to Defence Force families who have no choice at all but to go where the government posts them, to fulfil the needs of the nation as they are seen from time to time. That is why it is classified as a condition of service, a point that the government itself has made time and time again. As far back as 1986 the government made it clear that:
. . . defence housing is a very important condition of service—
Hansard is full of such references. The defence committee report that I quoted from earlier states:

Few Public Servants would move more than several times in a career because of employment-generated requirements, whereas for Service men and women at least 10 moves in 20 years is common and 15 or more not uncommon.

One of the witnesses we had before that inquiry spoke of being in 11 houses in 16 years, having one child attend five primary schools in five states and in Papua New Guinea, and another attend four schools in four states in five years.

PARA.TAB: Whoever in the bureaucracy thought this proposal up has to be an ignorant fool. It is to the eternal disgrace of this government that it went along with the proposal. It is quite absurd to penalise defence families for accepting compulsory postings imposed on them by the government through the Department of Defence. Another statement of the government in 1986 was:

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, operational questions are involved in the need to provide adequate housing. Those operational questions are related to a requirement to make absolutely certain that the armed forces are readily available in circumstances in which they may need to be deployed and are also readily available for the purpose of training.

It is in the interests of the armed forces and the government to ensure that its members are adequately housed. One of the great successes of this government in its 10 years in office has been setting up the Defence Force Housing Authority, which has provided excellent accommodation for the defence forces and has lifted them from the squalor of the run-down state housing commission estates. But in addition to penalising them for their rent subsidy, the government is going to penalise them for their educational allowance, which is, in the words of instruction 0501:

. . . payable to assist in defraying costs incurred when, on long term posting within Australia, a member wishes to leave his or her child in his or her present school or education system in order to prevent serious interference to the child's secondary education.

The allowance for defence dependents is considered a condition of service. Finally, the Hamilton report of 1985, commissioned by this government and entitled Supporting Service Families, stated that education was the most worrying problem for most of the groups Hamilton spoke to.

PARA.TAB: When we look at what the government is proposing, we have to ask: where is it going to end? Are we going to see the health service provided to troops as a fringe benefit? Are we going to see troops going overseas to Somalia or Cambodia having their free service of a medical examination and inoculation classified as a fringe benefit? Where will it end? What happens if they get treatment for an injury? Is that a fringe benefit of their service?

The government initially suggested that around 4,000 Defence people would be affected by this legislation. The revised figures from the Department of Social Security put the figure at around 7,000 families, and those figures may well be conservative.

A woman phoned me to talk about her own family. Her husband is a private at level six and they have four children under 10 years of age. To survive, this family gets almost $7,000 of assistance from the Department of Social Security, assistance given in recognition of their parlous financial state, a level of assistance which will be significantly cut back by this proposal. This family, which receives an income below the Australian average, gets a family payment of $90.60 per fortnight, additional family payment of $151.10 per fortnight plus rent assistance, a health care card, medical assistance, medications, access to a dental clinic and assistance with heating and gas bills.

If this bill is passed, this family will lose most of its additional family payment. If they move to another area of Australia where the housing rents are higher and therefore their fringe benefits will be regarded as more substantial, they will lose the additional family payment with the health care card. This is really an absurd situation. Because of the low salary the government pays the lower ranks, they are dependent on family income support measures from Social Security to survive.

I would like to deal briefly with the amendment that has been proposed by the Greens. The opposition is not prepared to support it because it widens the group and, unfortunately, at this stage, on the matter of definition the Greens cannot assure us precisely which groups it will apply to. It is an open-ended commitment and on that basis we are not prepared to consider it at the moment.

I listened with great interest to the Democrat case being put by Senator Woodley. His theme was that it all should turn on a person's ability to pay, to meet their financial outgoings. I can tell Senator Woodley that there are over 7,000 members of the Australian Defence Force who cannot pay their way. We have a large proportion of people in the Australian Defence Force who are way below the average income earnings for Australians and they cannot survive. They will leave the Defence Force if this bill goes through.

The other argument Senator Woodley put is absolutely fallacious. It is all very well to talk about equality of people before the law and beat the drum about equity, but the defence forces are not equivalent to civil servants. They live in a highly authoritarian society. They give up a lot of privileges when they put that uniform on. They are under orders the whole time. At the end of the day, the men and women of the Defence Force die on orders and there is no civilian, least of all Senator Richardson, who will die on orders from a superior officer.

TALK.START.PARA: —You're dead right about that.

—He would run, and he would run fast, along with various members of the ministry. That is why such things as conditions of service are granted to the men and women of the Australian Defence Force—to compensate them for the duties that are placed on them that no other member of this community bears.
—You didn't listen carefully to what I said.

—I listened very carefully. So we come to the situation where the government is committing to financial misery a large number of those members of the Australian Defence Force. During the estimates hearings I put several questions about this to the department. I asked:

SPEECH.PARA: Was Defence consulted or asked for any input into this proposal?
The answer was:
Apart from being asked to provide detail of certain defence conditions of service and their application to ADF members, Defence was not consulted nor asked for any input into the proposal.

So Defence was not consulted. But the ministers must have had some idea when this matter was raised in cabinet. I was advised by the department in writing that consideration was given to granting the ADF an exemption from the intended provisions. However:
Cabinet decided on 18 August 1993 that these provisions were to apply to all and the ADF is a part of the wider Australian community. Therefore no such exemption would apply to the ADF.
This is exactly the same argument as the Democrats are using to support their refusal to support us on this motion.

PARA.TAB: The ADF is not part of the civil community. This is all part of a consistent move towards conditions which fail to reflect and properly compensate the profession of arms for its uniqueness. One of the sad things is, because the defence forces have been successful and we have lived in a period of peace for many years, the uniqueness of the profession of arms is lost on the Senator Richardsons, Senator Rays and Senator Faulkners of this world. Because the profession of arms has been successful, its reward is to join the ranks of the poor of Australia.

This legislation has already had a major effect on morale, recruitment and the wellbeing of defence families and, of course, it must have an effect on the effectiveness of the ADF. With these concerns in mind, the opposition referred this to the Senate standing committee. It is a matter of record that the committee sided with the government point of view, although in that report there was a very eloquent and cogent dissenting report put in by the senators from the opposition.

I strongly recommend to the Senate the amendment to be moved by Senator Patterson. In so doing, I put into the hands of the Senate the wellbeing of our Defence Force personnel, an estimated 30 per cent of whom, with their families, receive less than the average Australian wage of $30,680 per year.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with great interest to Senator MacGibbon's passionate contribution.
—You were talking to other people!

—Senator Reid will now hear just how much I listened; I can listen and chew gum at the same time. I heard Senator MacGibbon say that this was nothing more than `a shoddy, money-grubbing exercise', and that Senators Ray and Faulkner, to whom he referred quite often—and he even included me at one stage—would run when he, Senator MacGibbon, would stand and fight. We may not be in the VC category—I do not know; we will see if it is ever tested—but Senator MacGibbon said that Senators Ray and Faulkner `uttered not a word of protest'. I think those were his words.
—Quite right.

—I thought about that. I wondered. I thought, if they would run and defy the orders of a senior officer, as Senator MacGibbon said, when he would stay and fight, and they had uttered not a word of protest, then I wondered what Senator MacGibbon's contribution must have been. I can recall a document called Fightback. A lot of people have been trying to forget this document, as well they might. It was a pretty costly document if one were in the opposition: it cost government. But I do recall it.
—Are you speaking to the bill?

—Yes, I am, as a matter of fact, as Senator Patterson will soon become aware, much to her chagrin. I know there was a measure in Fightback that was far harsher than the one that we are debating tonight—far harsher. In fact, in Fightback, the family payment income test would take account of `total remuneration'. Total remuneration includes superannuation and all fringe benefits, not just the categories that the government has included tonight. There was no mention of a $1,000 free airing. No families, none, not one defence family was deemed to be excluded from this measure. What is more, Fightback estimated that this would save $250 million, three times the estimated savings from the government's measures tonight.

PARA.TAB: When I contemplated all of that, these things came to mind. Firstly, if the savings were $250 million and three times what we are asking for tonight, either there were going to be some extraordinarily harsh measures that would wring from every defence family, every family possibly connected with a fringe benefit or within a mile of it, an enormous percentage of their income, or Fightback's figures were shonky—or I suppose, as another possibility, a combination of both. But, either way, where was Senator MacGibbon? Where was his voice of protest? How often did it ring through the corridors outside the opposition party room? Answer: he was silent—mute—he said nought as usual. He gets up here and he criticises Senator Ray and Senator Faulkner when he himself failed every test dramatically. He passed nothing. Where was the courage last year? The courage went the way of all flesh when all those opposite got so carried away with this great Fightback document—it disappeared and so, no doubt, will they.

TALK.START.PARA: —At least we were quite honest about what we were going to do; you lied your way to office.

—This question of honesty is another one which fascinates me. There are a number of topics here tonight which do grip me and this honesty question is one of them. There is a person in the House of Representatives called Phillip Ruddock, the honourable member for Dundas—that is what his electorate used to be; I am not sure what it was called after the last redistribution—it may still be that. He is the shadow spokesperson for social security, as I understand it. He criticised the government for not announcing this in the last election campaign, and Senator MacGibbon is echoing these criticisms tonight.

PARA.TAB: This measure was announced in the 1992 budget, seven months before the last election. Where was Senator MacGibbon when the budget was delivered? Where was this voice of protest? Nowhere as usual, nowhere. The hide of Senator MacGibbon—his extraordinary gall—to stand up and criticise Senators Ray and Faulkner boggles the mind. Senator MacGibbon has been absent on each and every occasion when courage was called for on this issue.
Senator MacGibbon has referred to ADF incomes. He has talked—

TALK.START.PARA: —Ha, ha, what a joke.

—I beg Senator Patterson's pardon. I could probably take offence at that if I were in a different frame of mind. Senator MacGibbon has talked about the salaries of defence families and how all this money will be ripped away from them. In the submission put to the committee, to which Senator MacGibbon referred earlier, from the Service Families Association, concern was expressed about the situation of a soldier with three children, earning $27,000 and receiving $167.94 in additional family payment per fortnight and a health care card in 1993, being likely only to receive basic family payment in 1994. Senator MacGibbon exaggerated this position; he was saying that such a family would lose everything.

PARA.TAB: In that situation the family's total additional family payment entitlement was, according to that, something like $4,366 per annum. To lose all of that through this measure, the family would need to be receiving almost $10,000 per annum in assessable fringe benefits. This family obviously was not receiving the maximum rate of additional family payment which would have been $185.70 per fortnight for a non-renter, much more than the quotient that Senator MacGibbon mentioned earlier.

Since the family does not receive the maximum rate, they would be entitled to a health care card only under a savings provision which has applied since January 1993. If that were the case, they would retain their health care card in 1994 if they remained eligible for even some additional family payment. So Senator MacGibbon's example and his suggestion that they would lose all of their additional family payment stands up to no analysis whatsoever. It certainly cannot be concocted from anything that is before us tonight in the bill. I find that quite disturbing.

If one looks at the incomes of Defence families and compares them across the board, one can make some interesting comparisons. A private with about six months of recruitment and initial employment training receives an annual salary of $26,711, including service allowance but not including other benefits such as for housing or health and additional compensation if on peacekeeping, hazardous or active service. People who join the Public Service after three years of tertiary study have starting salaries of between $20,677 and $25,550—far less than what we are talking about for a private. Corporals in the defence forces earn an average of $32,000 per annum. The average earnings of working families receiving additional family payment at June 1993—and that is really the critical point here—were $17,652 per annum, and 85 per cent of them had incomes less than $25,000.

It is pretty hard to work out how this is some terrible punitive measure wreaking havoc upon Defence families. It stands up to no analysis whatsoever. It certainly gives the lie to the statement of Senator MacGibbon that this measure forces Defence families to join `the poor of Australia'.

While mentioning that Defence families are disadvantaged because they are frequently posted around the country to lots of different places, it should be noted that they do still manage to find a way to own their own homes, because the rent subsidies that they get can be quite generous. In fact, the 1991 census suggests that Defence Force families have a home ownership rate of around 71 per cent, which I think honourable senators would agree compares pretty favourably to the national average for families of 74 per cent. The figures are virtually indistinguishable. I cannot see how that disadvantage of which Senator MacGibbon speaks actually applies.

In the light of all of that, there can be no doubt that the government rejects the amendment of the opposition. In so far as any amendment the Greens may move is concerned, they have not been in the chamber and I will address it if and when it is moved.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 4, page 3, proposed subsection 10A(2), definition of "current employee", paragraph (c), line 30, omit "including", substitute, "other than".

This amendment gives effect to the argument I put in the second reading debate that the defence forces and the police ought to be excluded from the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). I do not think Senator Richardson convinced any of us on this side that we ought to change our minds. In fact, he has made us even surer that we ought to go ahead with what we are doing.

PARA.TAB: I am a little concerned that the Greens senators, Senator Chamarette and Senator Margetts, indicated earlier that they were going to move an amendment which included those people whom we have included—members of the Defence Force and the police force—but also extended to people in essential community services, including teaching, emergency services and public works services. In our negotiations behind the scenes we said to them that we did not believe we could support the amendment being extended to the teaching service, an emergency service or a public works service, given the way that they had put the draft amendment. One draft amendment read:

SPEECH.PARA: Clause 4, page 3, proposed subsection 10A(2), paragraph (c) of the definition of "current employee", omit "including service as a member of the Defence Force or as a member of a police force", substitute "other than service as a member of the Defence Force or as a member of a police force or as a member of an essential community service including a teaching service, an emergency service or a public works service".

The Greens had another amendment which broke that amendment into two forms. We were not sure which one they were going to move. In the event, they moved neither of them. We had indicated to them that we could not support that amendment because we did not know what the definition of a teaching service was and we did not know what they meant by an emergency service or a public works service—or, really, what were the extent and the ramifications of that amendment.

PARA.TAB: The Greens said to us, `If you can't support that, we really can't support your amendment'. I hope they will come down and support our amendment. They included the Defence Force and the police force in their amendment, agreeing with part of our amendment. Because we cannot go the whole way with them, they say, `We are not going to support your amendment'. I think the people in the police force and the Defence Force ought to know that.

We did not see good evidence in the committee. As a previous speaker from the Australian Democrats said, there was a 1 1/2 page submission to the committee from the teaching service which really was not very convincing. We have not had people coming to us from any of the other services saying that they had had a problem. We have had people from the Defence Force and the police force bringing their point of view and also presenting submissions to the committee. That is what led the senators on this side to put in a minority report.

It seems odd to me that the Greens senators cannot come to a decision tonight to support our amendment, which includes part of their amendment, and to address the concerns that we have about the Defence Force and the police force. In fact, as we have said over and over again, we see the provision of housing as a compensation rather than a fringe benefit. We believe that argument has been put.

I ask the Greens to reconsider, when they come into the chamber—and we hope they will be here and not absent without leave—and to support us and support the Defence Force and the police force, as they intended to do in part of their amendment. If they vote against it, it will be rather odd. When they come down here, I would like to see that they can make a mature decision and support us and support what was part of their draft amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by Senator Patterson. It is not unusual that we hear a speech characterised by such profound ignorance and delivered with such bombast as we have heard tonight from the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson), who is at the table. I advise him and counsel him quite earnestly to go and read Fightback! when he gets a few minutes and to try to quote parts from it accurately. Even if he can quote them accurately, it is last year's news. We move forward; we do not live in the past, worshipping icons such as Gough Whitlam and Ben Chifley the way Senator Richardson does. We live in the present and look to the future with confidence.

PARA.TAB: I would also counsel Senator Richardson to read the Hansard. He would then realise that I was talking about a private with four children, not three children. And I was really amazed to learn that the average rate of pay for a corporal in the Australian Army is in excess of $32,000 per year. Who would want to be a general if a lowly corporal is paid as well as that? The figures I have for a corporal—and they are the latest ones from the Department of Defence—range from $21,651 per year up to a maximum of $28,328. But what is $5,000 for someone with the rich friends that Senator Richardson has? It is neither here nor there.

Here we have a government which is grinding the faces off the lower ranks of the ADF, yet running off with the ridiculous notion of performance based pay for those at the top of the scale who, by their own admission, are well rewarded. What a curious dichotomy of standards we have here. Thirty per cent of the members of the Australian Defence Force, in their family incomes, earn less than the average Australian family.

The government thinks that situation is fine. It has no sense of responsibility for those people. It is proceeding in the face of united opposition from the Australian Army, from the CGS downwards, with the obscenity of performance based pay—an element which cannot be measured for the Defence Force and which is completely corrosive for discipline and morale in that service.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —Always one to take up a challenge, I wish to quote chapter 16 of the Fightback document on page 280, which Senator MacGibbon said I did not read correctly. Under the heading of `Tightening up of Income and Assets Tests', it states:

SPEECH.PARA: Many the Government's income tests are poorly defined. They invariably leave out various types of income which allow people a higher standard of living than suggested by taxable income. The result is poor targeting with scarce welfare resources going to the better off.

Examples of income not included as taxable income for Social Security purposes, are fringe benefits and superannuation contributions which are made over and above employment contract, award and legislative requirements. These will be included by a Coalition Government.

I do not think I went outside that in any way. In fact, I quoted exactly from it and stuck to it in what I said. I repeat that if the opposition is prepared to cop that, it is extraordinary that it would be seeking to oppose what is happening here tonight.

PARA.TAB: I hope that we are now in a position to adopt what is a sensible bill which gives something like an equitable outcome. Certainly there will be an outcome and not a possibility out of Fightback—which, according to the opposition leader, Dr Hewson, last Sunday has a very different status from the one Senator MacGibbon has given it tonight.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the opposition amendment moved by Senator Patterson and supported by Senator MacGibbon. I am not speaking in the hypothetical; I am speaking about this piece of legislation on which we are voting tonight. I was told in Estimates Committee B by Senator Ray, the Minister for Defence, on 31 August this year that in excess of 3,400 Defence Force personnel are currently receiving additional family payments. The figures that were put to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs put the figure slightly lower than that. But I have no reason to doubt the figure that the defence department brought to the estimates committee.

PARA.TAB: These additional family payments are defined in the government's propaganda—the leaflets that it put out—as a welfare benefit paid to parents in `low paid work' to help support their children. We know that at least 3,400 Defence Force families are being required to seek these additional family payments because they are in low paid work and it is necessary for them to basically support their parents. I regard that situation as disgraceful.

In this legislation, the government is putting those Defence Force families in an even worse position. That is the issue that the minister has to address. By deliberate policy implementation, the government is lowering the standard of living of those Defence Force personnel whom it already describes as being in low paid work. That is what justifiably enrages Senator MacGibbon.

The people who are prepared to give their lives in service to our community in, as Senator MacGibbon said, a unique form of work—they are certainly at a unique risk—put themselves in a position that requires many relocations during service life. Disruption follows to their families and, particularly, children, who have to move from school to school. In all these circumstances it is not surprising that some service allowances and other compensations have been provided in the past.

For the past six years, there has been no adjustment to service allowances. This government has not pursued a case before the Defence Force Remuneration Tribunal to adjust service allowances. They are therefore well out of date. That is one reason why, at the lower ranks of the Defence Force, they are now finding themselves paid at a level that the government, as I said, describes as low paid work. In that situation, additional family payments become critical to them. Yet this government, by its decision tonight, is removing from them some of those benefits, and that is what we object to.

If the minister had come in here and said, `I have an alternative, such as other payments or whatever', I would have listened to that argument. But that is not being presented to us. What is being presented to us is a situation where these families that are already suffering—families that give so much to our community through their service and loss of the sort of family life benefits that we have—will suffer more.

Senator Patterson's amendment will exclude defence personnel and policemen, who are in exactly the same situation, particularly when they are forced to live in remote areas and receive some sort of educational allowance for their children or some housing allowance. Those people will be removed from this category so that they will not suffer more as a result of the government's policy decision. It is a reasonable amendment for us to move.

I will be astounded if the Greens come in here and vote the other way on it. I hope that Senator Chamarette, if she has the conduct of this matter for the Greens, will explain to me why she thinks lowly paid police families or defence families should suffer more as a result of the government's policy implementation when it is unnecessary and they do not deserve it. We have a role to play in determining the level of support that these people should receive from the community—which generally gets shown up in the form of remuneration—and determining why they should not receive more equivalent benefits to recognise the type of sacrifices that they give in service life.

If we have interpreted correctly the Greens' hint earlier in the debate that they will not be supporting our amendment in this regard, I hope that they reconsider their position. I listened to people such as Senator Chamarette telling me that the Greens are particularly interested in the lower paid sectors of our community. If that is so, that is commendable. This is another opportunity where they will get put to the test and we can see whether they are prepared to support these service families.

The same principle applies to the Australian Democrats. How will they vote in this instance? Will they vote to further reduce the standard of living of Defence Force and police families who are already employed in what the government describes as low paid work? I hope not. I hope we do not find that the Liberal and National parties in coalition are the only parties in this place that are prepared to stand up and fight for these people. I hope that is not the case. I hope that the Greens and the Democrats will be with us on this occasion, will realise the amendment that Senator Patterson's is just, support us and at least give some benefit to these people who deserve our support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak briefly on this matter. I had intended to speak in the second reading debate, but what I want to say relates to a specific clause in the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993. When I first read the provision, I thought it was a misprint. Any reasonable person reading this bill—a man on the Action bus travelling home to Tuggeranong—would assume that this was a misprint. I will read it out so that the Senate knows what I am referring to. This is the definition of `current employee' for the purpose of further taxing the lower income police and defence service personnel:

SPEECH.PARA: a person who is otherwise in the service of the Commonwealth, a State or a Territory—
We would have expected it to stop there, but it does not. In brackets it states:
(including service as a member of the Defence Force or as a member of a police force)

If we are talking generally about persons in the service of the Commonwealth, a state or a territory—government employees—we would have expected the definition to say just that: `a person who is otherwise in the service of the Commonwealth, a state or a territory'. But it does not; it goes on to refer to two specific classes of government employees—defence personnel and police—who we know get sent all over the country and quite frequently have to move into pretty poor accommodation. The definition includes, within brackets, those employees. We are entitled to expect that the definition would say, `a person in the service of the Commonwealth, a state or a territory, excluding service as a member of the Defence Force or as a member of a police force'. I put it to you most seriously, Mr Chairman, that that is what most people would have seen. We would expect Senator Patterson to come in here and assist the government in correcting it.

PARA.TAB: I find it extraordinary to sit here tonight and hear the minister tell us that the police and defence force personnel are so well paid that they are effectively ripping off the system by getting some compensation for the dislocation they suffer. They are sent to places to which they do not choose to be posted; they are required to live in out of the way places; and they suffer dislocation in respect of schooling and housing.

Personnel have to change curtains. Perhaps the minister does not realise that a set of curtains in one police house does not always fit the next police house. They either have to put sheets on the windows or go to the expense of putting up different curtains. The legislation shows a total lack of understanding of the role that is played by these people, of the sorts of places they have to live in, and of the impact that this has on them.

The minister spouted a bit of Fightback. He obviously has not read the whole document. Someone printed out a page and a half of the document from which the minister read out some rubbish about the fringe benefits tax. We are not talking about that; we are talking about compensation for dislocation—frequently moving house; living in houses all over the place. That is what we are talking about here and the minister knows it. He knows precisely what we are talking about and he knows that the word should be `excluding'.

I invite the minister to accept that and to accept this amendment. I invite him at least to acknowledge that a lot of police are not well paid and that those in the lower echelons of the defence forces are not well paid. He might know a couple of those people who are more wealthy, who perhaps have an independent inheritance; they are able to buy a house and go off and serve in another place. I know a great many more who do not have a home of their own and who have precious little prospect of getting one. They are happy to serve as defence force personnel and police personnel.

Surely the minister would not take this last vestige of help away from them. He obviously has no comprehension whatever of the difficulties they have managing in the way that they do and fulfilling the role they fulfil. The word clearly should be `excluding' and just about everybody but the minister in this chamber tonight knows that that is what it should be.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that the Greens of Western Australia have had considerable difficulty with this issue and with the opposition's amendment. Initially, our view was to oppose the amendment and support the government on the basis that if one group is excluded from the measure, then every group in the community should be excluded. While we felt that the argument that defence force fringe benefits are an offset for frequent moves required of members of the forces, we knew that the same could be argued by teachers and police officers, and by clergymen and people in private industry, such as bank employees.

PARA.TAB: The extremely persuasive arguments of an opposition adviser encouraged us to look at this issue more closely. It is true that, while we felt it was inequitable to single out a particular group of people to support in terms of this amendment, maybe there was a hope of broadening the base if we voted on this amendment and then sought to vote for the other categories later on. We have changed from that position. It is not that we do not believe that this amendment carries weight. We do understand the argument that this is a compensation rather than a fringe benefit; that people who are transferred or relocated to remote areas do suffer disadvantage; that their children suffer disadvantage from changes in schooling and other changes that are required. We have not been able to ascertain with complete confidence whether it is mainly the lower paid groups within the defence forces and the police force who will be penalised by this removal, or whether it will apply right across the board.

We prepared an amendment which we hoped we could support within the opposition's amendment; that is, we felt happier about not singling out two particular groups for an exclusion from this measure when there were other groups that could equally claim all those disadvantages of relocation, poorer income level, and dislocation of children in schooling. I accept Senator Patterson's criticism of our proposed amendment. I believe that our amendment required a more thorough definition for those opposite to be able to understand the point we were making. I thank them for looking closely at our amendment. I understand that, at this late stage, it is difficult for them to support our amendment, which had such a wide definition. To clarify the position for the chamber, this is the reason why we have not moved our amendment.

Equally, we do not feel very comfortable in supporting the opposition's amendment which is piecemeal in that the issue of equity in these circumstances extends well beyond defence and police force personnel to teachers and to other sectors of the work force. There is a very good argument for why we should not support an amendment which singles out two professions—defence and police—for special treatment. We would be willing to support an amendment to make the whole measure more equitable. We put the government on notice in respect of that.

We understand that the government sees that this measure will cause the agencies to re-work salaries and wages for their personnel rather than provide relocation allowances—subsidised housing in a manner which quarantines them from assessment. We repudiate that argument. We believe it is spurious. The government may be attempting to use an illegitimate mechanism to exact change.We accept that there are significant costs for people who, by virtue of their jobs, are required to move around the country. An adjustment of people's wage and salary structures to offset the costs of moving may compensate these people satisfactorily, but this may then force them to lose their additional family payments anyway.

We do not intend to agree to the opposition's amendment, but we will be happy to entertain any amendment proposed to any future social security legislation bills which addresses the wider equity issues and which includes these two particular professions. In the meantime, we urge the government to look more closely at this measure and to iron out all the equity issues before this chamber takes action to amend the definition of `current employee' in future bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very sad to hear Senator Chamarette speak. I wish I had a chance to speak before her. Maybe then I could have explained the ins and outs of the position, which I do not think she quite understands. Before Senator Chamarette came to the Senate and when the employment situation was very much better in Australia, there was a very serious problem of wastage in the Defence Force—that is, people leaving. These were people in whom an enormous amount of money had been invested in their training. They were leaving because of low morale and the wages structure. As Senator Hill mentioned a few minutes ago, they had gone through a long period when their allowances had not been brought up-to-date and where person management generally was inadequate and needed attention. The Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, led by Mr Manfred Cross, brought down a most excellent report which contained a large number of recommendations aimed at improving the morale in the Defence Force and trying to do something to retain these expensively trained people in Australia's service.

PARA.TAB: The situation has changed since then. We now have massive unemployment. We also have a Defence Force full of people who are very unhappy but who no longer have the option of getting out. A lot of the training that they undertake is very specific to the Defence Force and is not easy to transfer into civilian life. My experience is that many civilian employers are suspicious and lacking in understanding of what skills Defence Force personnel can offer them when they transfer across to civilian employment. So it has not been so easy for them to get work as it was when employment prospects were much better.

Tonight I listened to the discussion about compensation.
