It is very important to understand that such things as the secondary education allowance and subsidised housing, et cetera, are very much forms of compensation for the requirements of Defence Force service. In saying that, we also have to remember that the government has been trying to deal with artificial salary packages where people get a much lower income but where they get side benefits in lieu of income. It is a way of avoiding taxation, of course. I do not have a problem with attempts to deal with that, provided they distinguish between artificial salary packages and measures such as the ones in the Defence Force which were in place long before this rash of artificial salary packages became fashionable and were genuinely put into place because of compensation needs.

When I was the shadow minister for defence science and personnel, for several years I tried to pursue the granting of the secondary education allowance—through asking questions in estimates committees and in the chamber. It is monstrous that tens of thousands of Defence Force families, many with secondary school children, are required to move at least every couple of years. Sometimes in a service lifetime, families might face up to 30 moves. We should think about what that means for a family. Taking all that into account, only 90 secondary school children who are the dependents of service personnel are eligible for these secondary education allowances. That is the way in which the criteria are written and it is the way in which the eligibility is determined.

There is no suggestion that it is any kind of artificial contrivance. It is very hard to get that secondary student allowance. It is very helpful and very important for children who do not transfer well from one school to another and whose educational aspirations are going down the drain because of the difficulty of making new friends, the difficulty of adapting to new schools, having problems with new teachers and curriculum changes. These things which we as parents understand only too well, we try to avoid for our own children. But only 90 children in the whole of the defence forces are eligible for that allowance at any one time. One cannot describe that as any kind of artificial contrivance.

There was some talk earlier about housing of Defence Force personnel. I would like Senator Chamarette to understand that from the time the Defence Housing Authority was set up by the government, the opposition has given its solid and consistent support, as I hope Senator Richardson would acknowledge. At every step of the way the opposition has supported that organisation. We have tried to see that it was properly funded and we have encouraged the improvement of Defence Force housing. Successive governments have neglected Defence Force housing and I am delighted to see it improve, as it definitely has. But there is still a long way to go.

Subsidised rents have two justifications: firstly, there is still a considerable amount of substandard housing that Defence personnel must live in. I say `must' advisedly because frequently they do not have an opportunity to choose. They may be posted to an area where there is little or no real alternative, either because of cost in the private sector or because of lack of availability of rental housing in the private sector. So they are left with substandard housing. That is one reason why we would have subsidised housing.

Secondly, the teachers, the clergymen and the bank people to whom Senator Chamarette just referred can choose whether they go on postings. They can knock them back or they can actually apply for them. Defence Force personnel rarely have that luxury. They are under discipline and they must go if the service says they must. That is a very important distinction because that is the basis on which some of this compensation is payable. It is payable because they do not have control over their lives or the lives of their families in relation to where they live, how they live, in what they live and the amount of family time they have or otherwise.

That discipline on Defence Force personnel is extremely extensive and requires people to spend long periods absent from their family. Frequently young children are being raised with the father—sometimes the mother—away for quite long periods. These are things which we should be considering in trying to determine whether these are artificial contrivances designed to avoid income tax, which, after all, is what I thought fringe benefits tax was meant to be about.

I hope that the minor parties will give further consideration to this issue. It is pretty serious at the moment because people cannot march with their feet out into civilian life and take another job if their present arrangements do not suit them. They are slipping behind in terms of pay and allowances compared with the wider community. They are not unionised—they do not have a union to speak for them. All they can do is bide their time until the economy improves and they can leave the defence forces. That is not really in the nation's interests.

As I said at the beginning of my speech, we have invested a massive amount of money in defence personnel. We have an interest in keeping them there if we can keep them happy in the service. I think this is the most pettifogging, mean-spirited measure. I find this quite incredible when the government knows full well that it adopted all of the recommendations in the joint committee's report. To some extent, it has implemented them; it has dragged its feet on others. But to turn around now and allow this measure to go through is undoing any good work that it did in trying to improve the conditions of service for Defence Force personnel. I am sure Mr Manfred Cross would be appalled to know that the work that went into that massive inquiry and the excellent recommendations that came out of it, which were adopted by the government and the opposition, are starting to be unwound by this sort of nonsense that we have before us now that has hurt people and worried people so much.

I do not know whether the minor parties have received the sort of correspondence that I have received on this issue. They well recognise that I am no longer the shadow minister responsible for this area, but they know that many of us on this side of politics are very concerned for their well-being and we have done what we could to try to save them from this measure which the government, in such an incomprehensible and mean-spirited fashion, is imposing upon our defence forces.

I beg the minor parties to think again. They will not have it rubbed in their faces if they recognise that this is a special case. These people are receiving compensation. It is not an artificial device. They are under discipline in their lives, which changes the situation very dramatically compared to most other people who receive what might otherwise be designated as fringe benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to make a few comments particularly in response to Senator Chamarette who, I presume, is not pressing her amendment.
—No.

—I think that is wise. I was certainly attracted to her amendment, but for the reasons she has already outlined it still does not go far enough. If the amendment were to knock out the issue altogether, then we would look at it. However, that would be another debate altogether. We would have to come back and go over the issue again.

PARA.TAB: For the Democrats it is a question of equity. I hear the appeal being made by the opposition but I believe that that appeal needs to be made in other ways. This is not the way to compensate for all the problems that the defence forces face.

The other problem with the opposition's amendment is that it has argued eloquently about the Defence Force but its amendment catches the police up with the Defence Force and the two positions are not the same. I have already argued that the evidence given by the police was unconvincing and I do not want to spend a lot of time pulling it apart, even though I could. The police evidence was most unconvincing. The two services in this particular instance are not to be compared and so therefore there is a question of equity between those two categories. This is apart from the question of equity which is the fundamental principle for us in this whole debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a couple of questions that I would like to ask the Democrats and Senator Chamarette, and I hope they will answer them. Firstly, my understanding of Senator Woodley's comments is that, if the amendment were to be split and we had the Defence Force in one amendment and the police force in the other, he would support an amendment pertaining specifically to the Defence Force. Would the Democrats support that sort of amendment? I presume if they did support such an amendment they would not support the police force being included in our amendment.

PARA.TAB: Senator Chamarette indicated that she was putting the government on notice that the Greens would move an amendment to a further social security bill to do what our amendment was going to do plus expand it to include those groups that they indicated in their draft amendment. I ask Senator Chamarette: when are we likely to see that amendment? People from the Defence Force and police force gave evidence in that committee. We did not see people coming forward from the groups that Senator Chamarette would like to include in her amendment.

I believe the Defence Force and police force would like to know when they could expect that amendment to appear in the Senate. Will it be an amendment to the next social security bill that comes before us? We have another one coming before us tomorrow. I presume the Greens do not mean tomorrow. When can we expect to see the Greens' amendment?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thought it was a rather interesting comment of the Democrats that the amendment we are proposing really does not go far enough and even the Greens' amendment does go far enough. Logically, the Democrats ought to be voting against the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). There is no other tenable proposition that the Democrats can put to this chamber.

PARA.TAB: If we are trying to extend the boundaries and the Greens are trying to go over the horizon both ways and yet the Democrats say the bill is not going far enough for them, what sort of people are we dealing with? It ought to follow that they vote the bill down. We will see what they do at the third reading stage. I will deal with the Greens' proposition in a minute.

I do not have the stomach to spend time debating or discussing matters with the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson, because it is a futile exercise. But I cannot let stand on the record the statements he has made on two occasions that in our election publication we proposed to make this dastardly attack on the conditions of the ADF. The minister cannot extrapolate from the generalities of what we proposed under social service conditions and say that, therefore, we would have done that to the ADF. The Liberal Party and National Party would never have cut the heart out of the ADF the way the minister is implying. Let us have no more of that nonsense, Senator Richardson.

I would like the minister to show me where in our publication we said that we would subject the ADF to the income propositions that the government is doing in this bill. It is not true and it was never true. Senator Richardson should not waste the time of this chamber any more with the misrepresentations that are his stock in trade.

I would like to read into the record for the benefit of the Greens a passage from a briefing paper from the Department of Social Security. This is Senator Richardson's old department so we can be assured that the paper is correct. In the part entitled `Background on costing' it talks about the impact on Australian Defence Force families. The paper states:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Faulkner estimated that 3,400 defence force families received AFP. This estimate has been criticised as being too low by the RSL and by the national Consultative Group of Service Families. The Armed Forces Federation of Australia has estimated that 4,000 to 6,000 service families receive AFP.
DSS does not collect employer details from clients (or partners) and can not identify how many AFP recipients are serving members of the Defence Forces.
The Department of Defence has advised that 30% (18,600) of serving members earn below the Australian average wage of $30,680 per annum.

The Department of Defence advised on 6 September 1993 that there were 12,000 privates, corporals and sergeants and their equivalents with incomes up to $25-26,000 and with entitlement to married quarters or housing assistance. Assuming that 60% of these have children, our estimate is that on these figures, there would be about 7,200 defence force families entitled to AFP. It could be expected that not all these families would have taken up their entitlements to AFP.
Our estimate is that 7,000 defence force families will be affected by the change. Assuming that this group have broadly the same characteristics of other family Payment families:
.70% (4,900) are expected to lose basic Family Payment entitlement at a full year saving of $5.16 million. (the average loss for each client is $1052pa);
.30% (2,100) are expected to lose some or all of their AFP at a full year saving of $3.13 million (the average loss for each client is $1490pa or $28.70 per week).
In total, we expect that providing an exemption for the Defence Force families would lower savings by 22.3% or $3.98 m in 1993-94 and $8.29 m in a full year.
I rest my case.

TALK.START.PARA: —I need to respond to Senator Patterson and Senator MacGibbon. The point that we have been making all along is that it is a question of equity between different groups of people. The fact that the opposition is going to knock out the police and bring to us an amendment which just mentions the Australian defence forces does not alter the problem of equity between the Australian defence forces and other groups of people. For example, the opposition says the defence forces are the only people under orders to move when they are told to move. I can certainly mention a number of other categories of people who also have no choice in the matter. I suppose the most significant of those would be Salvation Army officers.

PARA.TAB: There is still a question of equity. Even if the opposition splits its amendment into the two categories, the question of equity remains. If we were to knock out the whole issue, as Senator MacGibbon has indicated, that would be another debate altogether. We have not engaged in that debate. Until that proposition is put to us, we really do not have a position. That is not the debate that we are engaging in here tonight and that is not the logical extension, as Senator MacGibbon is pushing, of what I said.

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Patterson's question, an amendment is being drafted at this point in time for the committee stage of the next bill. It will depend on whether the opposition has the same kinds of concerns about it or feels better about the way in which it is describing the categories that we wish to address.

—I do not know whether I misheard what Senator Woodley said, but he seemed to be saying to me that if we had only had the Defence Force in our amendment the Australian Democrats would have supported it. When that is put to the test—
—No, I didn't say that. I said the opposite of it.
—He didn't say that really.

—That was what I heard him say. Obviously, that was not what he meant to say or I misheard what he said. I was putting that to the test because that is what I thought he said. If that is not what he said, then it is important for the Defence Force people who read the Hansard to know that. When I read the Hansard, maybe I will see that he did not imply what I thought he implied.

PARA.TAB: I look forward to seeing the amendment that Senator Chamarette comes up with. I hope she can address the concerns we have had. I am not sure that she will. If she is unable to address those, the test will be whether she will still support our amendment about the defence forces and the police force. I hope she has listened to the arguments that we have put to her this evening. It seems odd that if she does put up an amendment with which we cannot agree, she would sacrifice the Defence Force and police force members because she cannot get all of her amendment through. That will have to wait for a later day. I leave the debate at this point with my amendment on the table and I presume that we will be dividing on it in due course.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate has been well canvassed, and I want to address only one point which harks back to Senator Hill's contribution, which seems so long ago now. He was saying that this was a measure which acted primarily against the lower paid and, similarly with Senator Newman, from the way she described the purpose of the Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1993, there seems to be a misunderstanding as to what the bill is about.

PARA.TAB: This bill affects those whose incomes are already at the margins of family payments; that is, either the basic family payment or the additional family payment. That is what it is about. By exempting the first $1,000, those receiving relatively less in fringe benefits are obviously less affected. In fact, the Department of Social Security expects a far greater number of families to receive the basic family payment, the cut-off of which is about $60,000, than those who have additional family payment, which starts to phase out at about $21,000. In fact, 22,000 of the total of 31,000 families who may be affected come from the basic family payment category, something which seems to have been lost in tonight's debate, but does put it in some perspective.

That the amendment (Senator Patterson's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the negative.
Bill agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell Sen I.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The main effect of the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill 1993 is to overcome the Commonwealth's self-imposed deadline to ensure that the sale of Qantas proceeded by December 1993. I guess the purpose of the deadline was to show the market the bona fides of the government in relation to the programmed selling of Qantas, which has now been somewhat of a saga for at least five years. Indeed, with the prime motive of this bill being to delay the final sale of Qantas until June 1995, it seems as though the saga will continue for at least the next couple of years.

PARA.TAB: The government has put forward a number of reasons as to why the sale has been delayed. The main reason, which we have no reason to doubt, is the state of the world aviation market broadly. The other reasons in more specific terms are the state of Qantas's profitability, the bedding down of the merger between Australian Airlines operations and Qantas's international operations and, finally, the bedding down of the 25 per cent stake in Qantas which was sold to British Airways for just in excess of $600 million. These are the range of reasons why the sale has yet to proceed.

The coalition would argue that a number of the objectives of privatisation are not being met, and that the sale price and a number of other excuses made by the government are not the central core considerations of a government when it is seeking to privatise an entity as large as Qantas. If the government is waiting for the market to ripen for such a sale, what happens come June 1995 and we are in a position where international airline profits are still bubbling along in a subdued international market of high competition and where the world stock market has yet to fully recover from various uncertainties about the international aviation market? If the government decides then that it is still not appropriate to sell Qantas, we may well be coming back here and passing yet another bill to delay the sale again. Let us hope that does not happen.

The point is that if we are always second-guessing the stock market, always second-guessing the state of the international aviation market and not proceeding on some other clearer objectives of privatisation, then the potential investors in that sale will begin to go off into other markets and wonder whether the sale will ever proceed.

I am quite sure that the new chief executive officer of Qantas, James Strong, who we are told sat at his new desk for the first time yesterday morning, will be very keen to see this privatisation proceed as quickly as possible. One of the main objectives of that privatisation has been ably communicated by such pro-privatisation people as the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe). He told the House of Representatives that one of the important considerations of the Australian Labor Party when it supported the sale of Qantas at its Hobart conference a few years ago was the need for capital expansion within the airline.

Clearly, an operation as large as Qantas cannot compete internationally in such a competitive and growing market if it is relying all the time for its capital requirements on the diminishing resources of the Commonwealth government on the one hand and borrowings on the other. Of course, running an international airline is a heavily capital intensive business. Capital items such as aircraft are hugely expensive, requiring masses of maintenance money as well as operating expenses. To rely on government funding and funding by borrowings is not a way to go when one is operating in such a competitive, cutthroat, international marketplace.

The need for infusion of equity capital is absolutely crucial. I am sure that the new chief executive James Strong will be working very hard on a range of priorities. I am sure that one of them will be to ensure that Qantas is made ready for sale at the earliest opportunity. James Strong has returned from a corporate mission in New Zealand to turn around the ailing—that is a bit of a pun—the failing DB Brewing group in New Zealand into which he infused some of his undoubted management skills, and particularly his skills in getting people to work together as a team to achieve a corporate objective.

As probably the first parliamentarian who has spoken on Qantas since James Strong actually took up his appointment, I am sure that I say on behalf of all honourable senators and members that we wish him well in his new role as the chief executive officer of Qantas; that is, both in trying to maximise Qantas's involvement in the international airline traffic and more specifically getting Qantas ready for a successful sale.

One of the worst features of this government in terms of asset sales is its record. I am sure the Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services (Senator McMullan) and his advisers on this matter are getting well and truly sick of members of the coalition quoting the failure of the government's budget forecasts on asset sales. But I would imagine that the more times we relate an account of the government's failure of its sales programs, the more careful and strident the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) will be in trying to assess for annual budgetary purposes the projected income from sales.

Rather than going over the annual figures, I would seek the indulgence of the minister to incorporate in Hansard figures extracted from the budget papers which show the shortfall in revenue from the asset sales programs during the past five years. For example, in the year 1988-89 it shows a 24 per cent shortfall where the government forecast $700 million in income and received only $528 million; in the year 1991-92—a more recent year—the government set out to raise $625 million and indeed made a $302 million loss, which was a 148 per cent shortfall in that year; and last year—the most recent budgetary year—the government anticipated sales of $1.6 billion and received only $800 million, which was a 50 per cent shortfall. They are fairly unimpressive figures.

I think it is reasonable for people to doubt—and let us all hope we are wrong for the sake of the budget—that the proceeds from this year's privatisation figures, which I understand are $2.4 billion, can be achieved. I think there is significant doubt in the marketplace, around this place and certainly in those of us in this chamber who are interested in privatisation, that $2.4 billion will be received. There is doubt that the sale of the Commonwealth Bank will be a success. It will raise a lot of money and of course the sale of the extra shares in the Commonwealth

SPEECH.PARA: Bank will help to make that figure look more realistic.

PARA.TAB: I said on budget night that I would predict that the asset sales for this budget will fall short by about $1 billion. I very much hope I am wrong. I described, Mr Acting Deputy President, in words that you would understand that the $2.4 billion that the government predicts for asset sales includes what our friend David Stockman from the Office of Budget Management in the United States administration under Reagan described as the magic asterisk.

David Stockman was always perplexed by the way that Treasury officials in the United States would make forecasts for out year budgets and have these little asterisks on figures for projections. They were usually to do with growth. But I think in the Australian context, the magic asterisks of this Treasurer and the Treasurer before him include not only outrageous growth projections but also outrageous projections for privatisation proceeds. I seek leave to incorporate the table in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: DIFFERENCE $172M $132M $838M $927M $799M

TALK.START.PARA: —That leads to the next issue when it comes to considering privatisation, and that is, the use of the proceeds. This government continues to use proceeds for annual expenditures and annual revenues as is described in language that the public understands. It is very much analogous to selling the silverware to pay for this week's groceries. The coalition takes a very different stance to that. Our stance is that when we sell a national asset like Qantas the proceeds should be used to offset debt and, therefore, improve the budgetary situation not only in the current year but also in the out years as well.

PARA.TAB: There is no doubt that Australia should learn from the experience of the Thatcher government, which this government so often compares the coalition to. One of the great criticisms of the Thatcher government's privatisation program is that it made some of the mistakes that this government is repeating; that is, it used proceeds for current expenditure. It sought to privatise government trading entities without seeking to enhance share ownership or have a better competitive environment—but, basically, it sought to sell things for the once off proceeds to help with the current year budget problems.

The objectives which the coalition seeks for all privatisations are to enhance competition so that people get a better service, have more choice as to where those services can be derived, and better quality service from private sector provision of the service; and to have greater economic efficiency, which is a very important argument for the earlier privatisation of Qantas rather than the later privatisation. While the efficiencies of the marketplace are acting upon Qantas in a way that they cannot do while it is owned by government, it increases the international opportunities for Qantas. While it is restricted in its capital base the way it is now, while it is restricted in many of its management decisions and in terms of its share ownership, it does not have the full benefits of economic efficiency that privatisation would give it, particularly in the marketplace in which it operates.

Importantly, when it has that restriction on its capital base it makes it that much harder for Qantas to break into new markets. It just does not have that flexibility to quickly get new equipment, set up new marketing links and so forth, even though—and I stress this—Qantas has been extremely successful, given the restrictions that it has. It is very good at opening up new products and markets. But one wonders at what Qantas could achieve if it was a private body and, clearly, the government has made the decision that it needs to be.

I think I have covered most of the issues that I wanted to cover. However, I wanted to raise—and it is a matter that I did raise with some people from the asset sales task force in a briefing I received this afternoon—the status of employee share ownership schemes within Qantas and a number of the other privatisations which the government is undertaking this year. The government has been, in its public statements, fairly quiet about employee share ownership schemes. One of the objectives of the coalition in privatising these Commonwealth-owned bodies is to ensure that the employees of those bodies can gain a significant stake in the enterprise by which they are employed.

It is quite crucial, in maximising the performance of a company or a business, that all of the employees have a very real feeling that what they contribute to the business is very important to the success of that business. There can be no better way of achieving that than the employees actually having a share in that business. I think in a people business there could be no better example of a business that so much replies on its people as an airline business like Qantas—from the people who check in, to the people who service the aeroplanes, to the people who handle baggage, to all the in-flight service people and the pilots; all the people in the airline business are crucial to making the airline successful. To maximise the performance of the airline, it is clearly desirable for Qantas employees to have a significant stake in their own airline. They will, of course, work that much harder at serving their customers if they have that stake.

I am aware from the briefing I received this afternoon that Qantas management is working very hard on coming up with an employee share ownership package. I was very pleased to hear that because the politicians who have spoken on this matter have yet to describe it. I do understand that the package that the Qantas management is discussing is one that will be very beneficial to the employees and therefore beneficial to all of us who are privileged to use Qantas for our international or domestic travel.

The sales process of Qantas and a number of other major government trading entities has become a bit of an international embarrassment for Australia. I certainly hope that the problems of bedding down the Qantas-Australian merger and the problems of getting Qantas's own books in saleable shape, are resolved very quickly. I would caution the government in waiting for a better marketplace to sell Qantas. The actual level of proceeds of the sale should be one of the minor considerations.
The Economist magazine did a feature on privatisation—one of the features it runs from time to time—on 21 August this year. The feature article states:
Whatever the circumstances, two over-riding aims are usually involved—

SPEECH.PARA: this is talking about privatisations across the world—
One is to shrink the state, in pursuit of greater economic efficiency; the other is to raise cash. These hopes are often in conflict.
When the article discussed the conflict between raising cash and increasing efficiency and competition, it concluded:

Like nationalisation, however, privatisation works better in some places than others—and best of all in the countries that make efficiency and competition, rather than short-term revenue, their goals.
I think that is the lesson for this government.

PARA.TAB: It will always be a temptation to wait for the perfect time in the market to sell Qantas for the best price, but if we proceed down the track and make the major objectives of privatisation greater efficiency and better competition, we will all be served better in the long run. That is why I genuinely say to the asset sales task force, the Minister for Finance (Mr Willis) and the government more broadly that trying to second-guess international stock markets will be doomed to failure. Much greater minds than the Minister for Finance or the asset sales task force have come major croppers trying to second-guess the stock market.

The final point is that the government does argue that one of the reasons for the sale is that the stock market in Australia has far too many floats on it at the moment. This is another reason why a sales program that has some definite end to it is important.

The market is always looking at who is floating what. In the last few months there has been an enormous number of floats. There are something like 25 or 30 floats of varying sizes coming onto the market. If the market knows when Qantas is going to come on, then it will adjust the other floats to it. If the government keeps saying, `We will put Qantas on when it suits us', the market will say, `Well, the government is never going to make up its mind. We had better just go ahead with our plans'.

So in a healthy market for floating, as we have at the moment, the market will of course put more and more stock onto the equity market and there will never be a window for Qantas. Qantas is a large sale. The government needs to commit itself to achieving the objectives of economic efficiency and better competition and make the size of the sale revenue a lower consideration in its priorities.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —We might have thought that the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill 1993 was a little fan club act on how wonderful Mr James Strong is and that it had nothing to do with other Qantas employees. In fact, it has a lot to do with other Qantas employees. That is the point I want to get to.

PARA.TAB: The purpose of this bill is to amend the date of the automatic repeal of the unproclaimed sections of the Qantas Sale Act from 31 December 1993 to 30 June 1995. In December last year, when that act was passed, it was expected that the divestment of the Commonwealth's interest in Qantas would be completed by October-November of this year. The bill contained a provision that any of its unproclaimed sections would be repealed if they had not been enacted by 31 December 1993. The government has since announced that the initial public offering of shares will be deferred under 1994-95. In the absence of any legislation, the provisions intended to commence on dates on which 50 per cent and 100 per cent of the airline is sold will lapse.

There are employee related provisions of the Qantas Sale Act which are planned to come in on the 50 per cent sale day. They `save' certain existing employee entitlements and rights arising from pre-sale service or else they remove airline employees from the ambit of legislation applying only to Commonwealth owned or controlled entities. It is necessary to do these things to protect employees. We support these measures.

I am also interested to hear that Senator Campbell has made inquiries about employee share ownership. If he is right and they are working on that, it seems to me that that would be quite a benefit, maybe one of the few benefits to come from this sale.

Senator Campbell has chosen to revisit the privatisation debate; I will too. He quoted something which said that privatisation does not always work, that it works best under certain conditions, and the criterion I think he quoted was efficiency. But I do notice that the opposition is still pursuing the sell everything course—not a selective course of asset sales, but sell everything—maybe not the Reserve Bank but everything else, right down to the forests.

Have those opposite observed the Thatcher experience, the Reagan experience? Have they learnt anything? One thing I think we do know is that there is still no evidence which says that governments do everything badly and the private sector does everything well.

TALK.START.PARA: —But no-one is arguing that.
—You want to sell everything that is publicly owned—
—No, we don't. You are setting up a straw soldier and knocking it down. It is quite untrue.
—What do you want to maintain in public ownership, Senator Kemp? Name one thing.
—The Australian Democrats.

—Good. That is very healthy for Australians. I am sure they would consider it a great investment. The fact of the matter is that it is not a function of whether a business is government owned or privately owned. It is, as the opposition said, whether the business is run efficiently that is significant. It is not, therefore, an automatic connection that the only things that are run efficiently are those which are privately owned and privately run.

PARA.TAB: Member of the opposition ought to listen to their colleagues in New South Wales. They start with the theory of, `Let's get all these things off the books. They are an embarrassment sometimes if they are not making money' and then extend that to the others because of the philosophy that all privately run business has to be better. But in New South Wales the opposition's colleagues have thought twice about selling Elcom. They like the idea of having something which produces huge profits actually on the books as a revenue raising measure. They can use that revenue for other things of their own choice, which is what this federal government ought to be doing.

I think it is time for a big balance sheet on how we have measured the costs and the benefits of privatisation because I do not think we have done that seriously as a nation. All we see is outlays, money we have to find now. Why are we in that predicament? Because for successive decades Liberal and Labor governments have starved Qantas of the necessary capital injection. We know that and again we get to the end point where the most convenient solution is to sell it off, get it off the books, to say, `Don't worry about what it represents, don't worry about the whole argument of foreign equity and don't worry about stemming the flow of profits offshore. Don't worry about any of that—let's just get it off the books'.

I pointed to the lack of capital but another issue is, I think, the broad question of foreign ownership of Australian enterprises. Is it really in the national interest for six digit profit figures to go offshore? The question of limits of foreign ownership, which the Democrats raise regularly in this place, also applies in this debate about Qantas. Do opposition senators not think we could argue that something which is fully Australian owned and controlled is more likely to act in the national interest? I think it is.

Qantas has very special role in the Australian psyche. It has been a major earner of foreign currency and this is something we welcome as one way of stabilising our foreign debt. One thing we do know is that a significant transfer of wealth occurs during the privatisation process. Privatisation tends to involve underpricing of share issues, as we saw in the Commonwealth Bank share issue and the privatisation of both British Airways and Air New Zealand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Name one area in which you supported privatisation.
—I voted for deregulation of the airlines.
—Privatisation.
—No. I think there are horses for courses. We said that we could come down to majority ownership. Those opposite want to sell off the lot. They want to just get rid of it all.
—We don't.

—Yes, you do. You just want to sell it off because you think in the short term it will raise revenue. In the long term, those opposite do not care about the consequences. Senator Campbell talked about the silver, but what if we want to buy Qantas back? What about if we see the error of our ways and want to buy Qantas back one day? It is sensible to limit the amount of foreign ownership so that people can start from a smaller base in wanting to buy it back.

PARA.TAB: I do not oppose the notion of Australians buying shares in Qantas or Qantas-Australian, but the Democrats want to take the opportunity yet again to say that the jury is still out on privatisation. Privatisation has not delivered all of the wonderful benefits to the Australian economy that the opposition claims it has. It is horses for courses and it is not necessary for us to sell off 100 per cent of our national carrier in the interests of balancing the books.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are selling it to Australians by and large.
—No, we are not. British Airways is already bidding in there.
—That is not a majority shareholding.

—It is enough. It is a significant chunk. We want to make sure that in any sale we do not again lower our own safety standards or our own work practices to the lowest common denominator. All of these things are involved in the privatisation debate. I hope I am around in the next few years when we do the analysis of where privatisation has led this nation because I can tell honourable senators that Australians are very uncomfortable with wholesale asset sales.

—I approach this debate this evening with some degree of personal interest because I was employed by Qantas in the 1970s and early 1980s. During the time of my employment it was a feature of Qantas that its employees never considered themselves public servants. We were not classified as such because of a loophole involving the board members of Qantas being the only holders of shares. But we were very proud of our company. We were proud of the very high standards that Qantas was known for worldwide. Staff training was of a very high standard. We were highly regarded by the travel industry and performed a large servicing role for the Australian travel sector.

PARA.TAB: Qantas was also known internationally for the special care and attention it gave to carrying sick, disabled and young people. Our national airline does not gain a lot of profit from such a service. Passengers are not charged for the cost of providing proper, correct and advised care. However, that is the kind of service that Qantas provided. Qantas was very famous also for its very high safety standards. This, of course, was the position in the days when Qantas was not being asset stripped. I can only wonder how Qantas rates in these areas today.

While the Greens do not support privatisation, we do not refuse to support the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill. This legislation does not alter the fact that Qantas will be privatised. We wish to flag clearly, since the government seems uncertain in its ability to hear what we say, that we oppose the privatisation of the basic social infrastructure. Industry is not good at ensuring equity; that is not a part of its purpose.

Government ownership of public infrastructure, education, water, power, communications, public transport and finance institutions or companies providing basic structure in a mixed market is designed to ensure that services are available in an equitable way and that the needs and desires of the community are represented. The only alternative to public ownership is strict regulation, as we find in the privately owned energy and communications industries in the United States of America. Private industry sets it own agenda; this is often not the agenda for the future that the wider community would wish. For this reason, it is important to support publicly owned service companies.

We also wish to say something here about asset sell-offs: they may address some of the immediate problems of government, but assets are limited and will run out. In selling them off, we are selling off the Commonwealth's savings. It does not address the structure of the economy in the long term.

We will support this amendment because in this case the amendment will have the effect of protecting the rights and conditions of employees, which are part of the conditions that will be extended. It may also allow for a more orderly and profitable sale of shares rather than a `fire sale'. We think the government may be right about delaying the sale, although the current market boom may not last. Certainly, the market has not been good, nor has recovery proceeded as predicted.

I conclude by repeating that it is sad to see that the only standards we seem to value in such areas are profitability and efficiency in very limited terms. We should be concerned about the general quality of service and equity. I consider these to be some of the most important aspects that a national carrier should provide to the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the Qantas Sale Amendment Bill. I wish to put on the record some comments in relation to arguments put down by Senator Kernot. Of course the costs and benefits of privatisation should be assessed and assessed carefully; equally, the costs and benefits of not selling commercial assets owned by the government should also be the subject of careful analysis. I have no particular argument with that because I believe that, in most cases, particularly with large commercial bodies like Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank, consumers and taxpayers will be shown the strong advantages of a sensible privatisation program.

PARA.TAB: Senator Kernot raised the concern of foreign ownership. That is an appropriate concern, and no-one on this side of the chamber argues against that. But the point I would make is that the vast amount of shares that will be owned by Qantas will, in fact, be owned by Australian shareholders.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many Australians can take it up?

—There has been a sale to British Airways. So I put it to Senator Kernot that foreign ownership is an argument to mount, but I think there are rules in place in most of the privatisation areas to ensure that Australian interests are protected.

PARA.TAB: My final point is that it is a bit rich for Senator Kernot to get up here and argue strongly for the need to assist Australian industry when the Australian Democrats have joined with the government to increase taxes of $2.6 billion, most of which are imposed on Australian industry. I share with Senator Kernot a very strong interest in wanting to promote Australian industry to make it competitive. The worst way to do that is to do what Senator Kernot and her party did last week—raise taxes on a whole range of Australian industries.

TALK.START.PARA: —And start a new industry, ethanol, in this country.

—Senator Kernot says that she wants to start a new industry in this country. We are all for doing that. But the way to encourage that is to make sure that we are a cost-competitive country, that we keep our taxes down on industry and that we support sensible labour market reforms. We do not introduce a major bill to this parliament to remove major barriers to union power and privilege in relation to sections 45D and 45E. We will be looking very closely at the sorts of arguments Senator Kernot mounts in those areas.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMULLAN
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Arts and Administrative Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would love to make some second reading comments because several of the speeches seemed to me to be a triumph of ideology over analysis. I will not do so because we want this bill to be passed by 10.30 p.m. I will have plenty of other opportunities and I look forward to doing so then. I thank everybody for their support for the second reading of the bill.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
The bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise during the committee stage of this bill to respond briefly to three points which were made by Senator Kernot. Firstly, I stressed in my speech during the second reading debate that the coalition does not have the fire sale, cash benefit, once-off revenue as its objective; that we seek to ensure that there is wider share ownership and that average Australians can own some shares in some institutions.
—That is a new one.
—It is not new; it has been stated since 1986.

PARA.TAB: That point is reinforced by the fact that the sale proceeds of Qantas are estimated to be around about $1.8 billion to $2 billion. One should understand that the average monthly expenditure on social security in Australia in any given month is roughly $2 billion; so the sale of Qantas will pay for one month's social security. Therefore, the sale proceeds are only a small consideration.

The second point relates to the economic benefits. A cost benefit analysis of the economic benefits of privatisation across the world has been done by bodies such as the World Bank. The World Bank found that in 11 of the 12 cases studied—countries such as Britain, Malaysia, Mexico and Chile—there were `big economic gains' and that across the world the efficiency improvements brought about by privatisation are in excess of 20 per cent.

The last point I want to make is that the coalition's agenda for privatisation is carefully considered, and carefully programmed and set out. It has been set out before each election, naming the bodies that will be sold and the specific years of those sales. It includes something like four or five items each year. We will, of course, issue again, before the next election, a manifesto setting out those sales. It is a well thought out program.

Those points need to be made for the record because Senator Kernot keeps building a straw man of misrepresentation about our position on privatisation. I am pleased to see that the government has adopted, at least in part, our privatisation program, if not the methods by which we would go about selling things.
Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.
Bill (on motion by Senator McMullan) read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —This evening I intend to outline to the Senate how a letter I wrote to the editor of the Courier-Mail was emasculated before its publication. I am mentioning it in the Senate in case my colleagues on both sides of the chamber think that my letter writing ability has suddenly vanished.

PARA.TAB: On 16 October the Courier-Mail ran an editorial in which it criticised Senator Graham Richardson for expressing a view that the Queensland government policy in relation to the regulation of prostitution was incorrect. Senator Richardson's comment was made in the context of the fight against AIDS. The editorial implied that Senator Richardson should keep out of the affairs of Queensland. One part of the editorial, which was entitled `Local rules—Stick to your turf, Senator', read as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . social regulation is a state matter. Senator Richardson's attempt to intervene is unwarranted.
Later the editorial went on to assert:

PARA.TAB: The governance of this country is—apparently to Senator Richardson's distress, but that is also irrelevant—substantially split by the Constitution into matters that fall within the purview of the Commonwealth and those which are administered by the states. This system is far from perfect. It is a system that is continually muddied by politicians who seem unable to remember which side of the fence they are on.

SPEECH.PARA: The editorial also remarked:

If Senator Richardson is determined to worry about the extent of illicit sex and consequent disease, there are plenty of areas within his own federal portfolio upon which he can spend his time and effort.

The clear implication was that Senator Richardson should not comment on matters that are the responsibility of the states, even if he considers the policy pursued by those states to be at odds with what he as the federal Minister for Health perceives to be in the best interests of the nation's physical wellbeing.

PARA.TAB: I took issue with this stance of the Courier-Mail. I thus wrote a letter to that newspaper suggesting that Senator Richardson had every right—indeed, an obligation—to speak out on matters relating to health and to make suggestions about shortcomings which he perceives in health related issues, even if this means commenting on state government policies. My letter to the editor ran as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: How churlish of your editorial (The Courier-Mail, October 16) to criticise Senator Graham Richardson for offering his opinion that prostitution should be legalised in Queensland.
Senator Richardson is, after all, the Federal Minister for Health. As a conscientious Minister, he is concerned about the spread of AIDS and methods by which that spread may be arrested.

It is all very well for your editorial to suggest that there are delicate constitutional matters that should keep Senator Richardson at bay. But there is no evidence that State borders are barriers to the AIDS virus.
As a responsible Minister for Health, Graham Richardson is correct in commenting on what he regards are incorrect State policies and actions in the fight against AIDS.
By all means, argue against his propositions if you disagree with him. In this way, community debate can be fostered about policies to deal with a grave threat to public health.

But do not suggest that he keep his suggestions to himself or air them only in Canberra. Senator Richardson's responsibility for health policy and delivery is a national one. If he did not make suggestions about shortcomings which he perceives in health related issues, he would not be fulfilling his duties as Minister for Health.
He certainly cannot be accused of being derelict in his duty towards the massive problem of AIDS and for that he should be applauded.

Unfortunately, the Courier-Mail saw fit to publish only the first and the last sentences of my letter—altering the last sentence, incidentally, so that it read as two sentences. This is what the Courier-Mail printed:
How churlish of your editorial (C-M, October 16) to criticise Senator Graham Richardson for offering his opinion that prostitution should be legalised in Queensland.

PARA.TAB: He certainly cannot be accused of being derelict in his duty towards the massive problem of AIDS.
For that he should be applauded.

SPEECH.PARA: So of 12 sentences in my original letter, two were published. The whole thrust of my argument was lost, and it appeared as if all I was doing was writing a brief comment to agree with Senator Richardson's view on prostitution. One wonders at the ethical standards of a newspaper which decides to print the first and last sentence of a letter to the editor and leave the other 10 sentences unprinted. Then again, apart from those professional journalists who work for the Courier-Mail, I have never thought that ethics have loomed large in the ethos of this particular newspaper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen C.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise this evening to bring to the attention of the Senate an issue which relates to the independence and sovereignty of our nation. I think it is true to say that there is growing awareness and concern about the enormous enthusiasm of the ALP for UN conventions and UN committees.

PARA.TAB: First, Australia's independence is being undermined by the government's action to allow UN committees dealing with human rights issues to involve themselves in Australian domestic activities. Secondly, these UN committees are already having a significant impact on Australian law. Thirdly, the UN committees themselves do not meet appropriate standards of independence and judicial process.

I believe the decision to allow UN committees to have a role in Australian domestic disputes is wrong in principle. I happen to think sovereignty is important and should not be compromised by international treaties without very good reason and, above all, without demonstrable benefit to the nation. Nevertheless, those who support Senator Gareth Evans's so-called new internationalism should at least insist that the UN committees meet the highest possible legal standards.

In relation to my first point, Australia's independence, there is no argument, even from the most passionate advocates of UN conventions, that Australia's sovereignty is eroded by the government's decisions on UN human rights treaties. For example, Senator Schacht is an enthusiastic advocate of UN human rights treaties. He was the Chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade when it produced the report entitled A review of Australia's efforts to promote and protect human rights. This Schacht report pointed out:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . there has been a tendency for the United Nations to limit national sovereignty. This evolution, therefore, increasingly demands a reconsideration of the principle of national sovereignty. United Nations conventions, now covering a wide range of activities, inevitably change the character of domestic institutions, affect domestic legislation and extend accountability beyond the usual domestic constituency.

Senators will recall that this is the same Senator Schacht who ceaselessly argues the independence line when promoting his other great passion of the need for Australia to become a republic. The problem with this argument, as far as our constitution is concerned, is that we are already an independent country—at least we were until the Hawke and Keating governments acquired a fascination with UN treaties.

PARA.TAB: The Australia Act 1986, among other things, abolished appeals to the Privy Council. With all the rhetoric about independence, one would have assumed the last thing any government would do is involve foreign bodies in Australia's legal system. After all, it was Gough Whitlam who said:

SPEECH.PARA: ". . . the High Court of Australia (must be) the final court of appeal for Australians in all matters . . . It is entirely anomalous and archaic for Australian citizens to litigate their differences in another country before judges appointed by the government of that other country".
In 1986, Mr Hawke's Deputy Prime Minister, Lionel Bowen, suggested that the abolition of appeals to the Privy Council reflected Australia's status as an independent and sovereign nation.

PARA.TAB: After all these fine words, it took Labor five years to reverse the philosophy of the Australia Act. In 1991, the government ratified the so-called first optional protocol of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, which enabled Australians to take complaints to the UN human rights committee. In February 1993, the Keating government further opened the doors for Australians to litigate their differences before the UN by recognising the competence of two other committees—the Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination and the Committee against Torture—to consider complaints from individual Australians.

I believe most Australians would not know that the government has taken these actions. If my recollection is correct, there was no debate in the parliament. No approval was sought from the parliament. What an irony of Australian history! The great advocates of UN human rights conventions were able to make major decisions affecting the legal system of this country without consulting the Australian people or their representatives.

Now to my second proposition. The willingness to involve UN committees in domestic activities is of major significance to our legal system. Senator Gareth Evans, when questioned about the significance of these decisions to open up Australian domestic disputes to UN committees, becomes, in my experience at least, often abusive and ends up arguing that the findings of the UN committees are only exhortatory and advisory. A number of points can be made about this statement.

There is no doubt that the UN human rights committee is having an impact on our legal system. We need go no further than the famous Mabo case. As Justice Brennan said in the case of Queensland v. Mabo:

SPEECH.PARA: "The opening up of international remedies to individuals pursuant to Australia's accession to the Optional Protocol to the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights brings to bear on the common law the powerful influence of the Covenant and the international standards it imports. The common law does not necessarily conform with international law, but international law is a legitimate and important influence on the development of the common law".
Justice Kirby, the President of the New South Wales Court of Appeal and a most respected Australian, has stated:

"Several of the trailblazing decisions (of the High Court in 1992) were influenced by the fact that what Australian courts decide can now be scrutinised (and criticised) by the UN body (the United Nations Human Rights Committee).

These statements alone demonstrate the great importance of the decision to ratify the first optional protocol. Our highest court is already paying close attention to the fact that Australian cases may end up at the UN human rights committee.

PARA.TAB: But there are other ways in which UN committee findings can be of great significance in Australia. For example, a decision of a UN committee can provide the basis for action by the federal government to override a state government. Once the committee gives a view that a particular complaint is justified, the government would have the power to act even if it related to a state jurisdiction. For example, under current political circumstances it would be untenable for the federal government to legislate to override the criminal law in a state. However, if the UN human rights committee were to publish a decision stating that Australia is in breach of its international obligations because of state legislation, the federal government would not only have an excuse to act but would probably be obliged to act.

The Canadian experience with the first optional protocol is instructive and provides a pointer to what will occur in Australia. Canada signed the protocol in 1976. An analysis of the cases which have been heard by the human rights committee shows that their determinations have clearly had an impact on government policy in Canada. There is no reason to expect that a similar experience will not arise in Australia.

Senator Evans must have expected that the decisions on UN committees would have a significant impact. Why else would he take this decision in the first place? It is disingenuous to pretend that the government has not taken a highly significant act in allowing domestic disputes in human rights areas to go to the UN. There has been virtually no attempt to argue the case publicly for this decision to justify why our legal system needed this change.

The UN committees are simply not appropriately structured to carry out a significant role in our legal system. If our highest courts are going to pay attention to the views put forward by the UN committees, surely we should at least insist that these committees have the standards of independence and due process that we require from our tribunals.

There is no doubt that the UN is in need of major reform. Senator Evans and most observers have readily conceded this point. Nor should we forget that of the 185 nations that are members of the UN, 117 are classified by Freedom House as being either not free or only partly free. It is hardly surprising, then, that the UN committees concerned with human rights are also in need of major reform.

The independence of the committees is compromised by their method of appointing members; the short-term nature of the appointment, with the option for reappointment; their dependence on the UN for funding; and the attitudes of some of their members. The procedures of the committees do not meet standards that Australia would want for high level tribunals. Critics have pointed to the fact that the short sitting times of the committees inevitably means that much of the work must be done by their secretariat. At times, I understand that there has been a failure to produce comprehensible reasons for a particular judgment.

I will quote some expert views. In a recent book edited by Professor Philip Alston entitled The United Nations and Human Rights—A Critical Appraisal, the activities of various UN committees are reviewed. On the issue of the membership of the human rights committee, one writer, Mr T. Opashl, has written:

SPEECH.PARA: Inevitably, however, independence is relative and varies with the backgrounds of the members and practices of their governments. It is not unique to this body that some experts seem to have been in closer contact with the authorities of their own countries than other members, if they have not acted directly under instructions; others have at the same time as their Committee membership been serving their governments in an official capacity.
Another observer, Louis Henkin, in a book entitled the Age of Rights, has said:
The Committee is composed of independent experts but, as other bodies of international experts, some are not independent in fact but subject to substantial control by their governments.
It is hardly comforting to know that our High Court pays such close attention to a committee based so far from our shores. I suggest that Sir Owen Dixon would turn in his grave.

PARA.TAB: Similar complaints on issues of independence have been raised in relation to the UN racial discrimination committee. I seek to incorporate in Hansard a short analysis of the membership of the UN racial discrimination committee and the tables which list the membership of the three UN committees concerned with human rights to which Australians can make complaints.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows—

PARA.EMPHASIS: Comment on the UN Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination by K Partsch

SPEECH.PARA: (article in "The United Nations and Human Rights", edited by P Alston)

"Because a Committee member serves on a part-time basis, honorary basis, usually he must simultaneously maintain a separate profession. Only rarely do these dual roles create conflicts; judges, university professors, retired diplomates or diplomates dealing only with bilateral relations are unlikely to receive directives from their authorities with respect to their work on the Committee. However, for a minority of members, primarily those belonging to the permanent missions of States Parties at New York or Geneva, such conflicts can be significant. They may find themselves in the awkward position of having to disregard their superior's directives while at the Committee table. Clearly, it is incompatibly with the Member's solemn oath of impartiality if his attitude is dictated by a member of his country's permanent mission. Nevertheless, it seems that not all the States Parties attach the same importance to these proprieties".

TALK.START.PARA: —Members are nominated by their governments and elected by a secret ballot of the countries that have ratified the relevant conventions. So Australian human rights cases which go before the committee are determined by a membership which includes nominees from countries that have an appalling record in human rights.

PARA.TAB: In relation to the UN Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination, there are government nominees from Cuba, China, Romania, Russia, Ghana, Nigeria, Peru, and Egypt, to mention just some of the countries. None of these countries could be described as free societies. Yet Mr Keating and Senator Evans seem to believe that it is appropriate that a committee so composed should have the ability to rule on human rights cases in Australia.

One other function of the UN committees is to review reports from member countries about domestic human rights developments. I recently received a report from the government entitled The ninth periodic report of the government of Australia under article 19 of the International Convention on the Elimination of all Forms of Racial Discrimination. This report was presented to the United Nations Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination, the membership of which I have just referred to. The report seeks to demonstrate: firstly, how serious the problems of racial discrimination are in Australia; and, secondly, how effective the government is in dealing with these problems.

I do not pretend Australia is perfect. There is clearly more that we must do to assist disadvantaged groups. But compared to many of these countries whose government nominees are considering our record, Australia would be a gold medal winner in creating a fair and tolerant society. Nothing in this report provides any real sense of balance.

I wonder what Michael Banton of the United Kingdom, Carlos Hevia of Cuba, Ivan Garvalov of Bulgaria, Sangu Shuhua of China and Regis de Gouttes of France thought when they read this government report which quoted sources that `racist attitudes and practices (both conscious and unconscious) against Aboriginal people pervade Australian institutions'. Anyway, Australia regularly makes reports to this committee so it can check out our performance and ask further questions.

It is really beyond the pale that the Australian government reports and is answerable to such a committee. I wonder whether, in the 1920s and 1930s and 1940s, Billy Hughes, Jim Scullin, Joe Lyons or Ben Chifley would ever have felt they would have to report to the British Colonial Office on any matter in the way Paul Keating and Senator Evans report to the UN. Let me put a further proposition to the Senate: the affection that any pre-war Australian monarchist may have felt for the British Empire is nothing compared with the adoration that Senator Evans and Mr Keating feel for the United Nations.

Australians must enjoy the highest possible human rights. Where human rights infringements occur they must be addressed quickly. That is why we opposed Labor Party initiatives such as the Australia Card and banning TV political advertising. We continue to oppose special privileges for trade unions and so forth. Indeed, Australia is in the forefront compared with virtually any other country, by any measure, on human rights. There is a high level of agreement between all parties on the major principles in relation to human rights. There is, however, inevitably controversy about human rights applications in particular circumstances, for example, the right to privacy versus the right to freedom of expression, rights of children versus rights of parents, rights of women versus ethnic rights, property rights versus community rights.

The real question goes to how these judgments should be made between competing rights. Should the balance be determined by local courts or international committees? The balance determined by local courts in Australia will be affected by local social circumstances and mores. The balance determined by a UN committee may be different and quite alien to Australian society. Often very fine and sensitive judgments are involved in human rights cases. They are far better made, in my view, by a local body with an understanding of Australian society which is accountable to the Australian people. It is also important that decisions which have such a significant effect on the rights of individuals are made in an open court which follows fair procedures and gives full reasons for judgments, rather than behind closed doors and far from public scrutiny. The UN committees do not meet the tests.

I believe it was a serious mistake to involve UN committees in Australian domestic human rights disputes. If our human rights laws and courts need reforming, the democratic way to do it is through our parliaments, involving our people and their representatives. The wrong way to do it is to address domestic human rights problems through the UN by opening up avenues of complaints to UN committees.

TALK.START.PARA: —The new Labor member for Leichhardt, Mr Dodd, often makes completely uninformed comments, some of which in recent times, have been directed at me. I would not normally bother responding because Mr Dodd is such an irrelevance—a recent blow-in from Sydney to North Queensland. SPEECH.PARA: We do not hear him—
referring to me—
talking much about local government—

PARA.TAB: Following hot upon the heels of Mr Dodd's first inaccuracy that I do not talk much about local government is his claim that I am not talking to local government. Again Mr Dodd proves the old saying that if you are ignorant, it is better to keep quiet than open your mouth and prove it. Since my election I have personally visited over 300 of Australia's 915 councils in all the states, including just about every council in Mr Dodd's electorate. I have written to all councils. PARA.TAB: Last Thursday in the House of Representatives Mr Dodd outdid himself with his inaccuracies by his reference to a complaint made by the Liberal Party to the Electoral Commission about the conduct of the election in various polling booths in Cape York. Mr Dodd claimed in the House of Representatives that I ran `a slur campaign' against Australian Electoral Commission workers. That was not the case at all.

I use this opportunity to put on the record some of these low lights of democracy which were recounted in a press release issued by the Liberal Party candidate following the election. I will read from this press release to tell honourable senators some of the things that were complained about in this so-called democracy of ours. It said:

SPEECH.PARA: Statutory declarations obtained gave details of the following irregularities. At Lockhart River on at least 15 occasions, Liberal scrutineers saw voters place blank ballot papers in the ballot boxes, yet when the votes were counted in Cairns there were no blank ballot papers at all amongst the votes. Secondly, at Lockhart River electoral officials were clearly seen to be directing voters to vote Labor by pointing to the Labor box on the ballots as they were handed to voters. Complaints about this were ignored by the returning officers.

PARA.TAB: Electoral officials at Lockhart River accompanied voters without invitation to the booths to assist them with their votes. Further, ballot boxes were not sealed at the Weipa South booth and were opened during the day to retrieve mistakenly placed absentee votes. Further, on four separate occasions, the returning officers' assistants at Pormpuraaw were seen as picking up blank ballot papers off the floor, filling them in and then placing them in the ballot box. The returning officer made no record of the complaints by the Liberal scrutineers about these particular incidents.

On at least eight occasions the returning officers' assistant was seen escorting voters without invitation and filling out ballot papers on behalf of the voters. Again, complaints by Liberal scrutineers were not recorded. On two occasions Liberal scrutineers observed spoilt ballot papers being removed from a drawer and filled out by certain officials.

At Pormpuraaw the returning officer was granted permission to photocopy 10 extra ballots. The returning officer said that these were invalid and elderly voters unable to come to the polling booth. Protests were made from Liberal scrutineers that such votes should be cast by postal ballots and that the ballots should not leave the booths. When the votes were checked in Cairns 13 photocopied ballots were counted at the Pormpuraaw booth.

Returning officers at Weipa south were seen to be putting blank ballot papers into rubbish bins rather than retaining them and also returning officers were seen allowing ALP how-to-vote cards to be left on the official tables and in the polling compartments.

SPEECH.PARA: A series of statutory declarations were obtained to justify those complaints and they were all handed to the Australian Electoral Commission. Last Thursday in the House of Representatives Mr Dodd asked why the Liberal Party had not apologised. I will tell him why. There is no official apology from me or the Liberal Party because no-one, including the Australian Electoral Commission, has adequately shown that the statutory declarations made by our scrutineers are false. In fact, the investigation by the Australian Electoral Commission leaves a lot to be desired.

PARA.TAB: Mr Dodd then went on to accuse our scrutineers of racism, but he has provided no evidence whatsoever of what. He just threw some mud in the hope that some of it would stick—a disgusting tactic against people who have no means of defending themselves in this parliament.

It is a shame that the honourable member for Leichhardt is so inaccurate in his comments—comments which few people take any notice of. I would normally not bother to respond to them but they are so inaccurate in such a wide range of fields that I thought that it was important on this adjournment debate that I acquaint the Senate with the gross inaccuracies made by the honourable member for Leichhardt.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 5 May 1993:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the answer to Question on Notice No. 1720 (Senate Hansard, 26 March 1992, p1266) which states that "Persons who enlisted in the permanent Australian Defence Force after 1 July 1947 are not eligible for benefits in respect of their service in the British Commonwealth Occupational Force (BCOF)" and with reference to the answer to Question on Notice No. 2188 (Senate Hansard, 14 October 1992, p1857) which states that "Only those who enlisted after 3 January 1949 in the Permanent Defence Force are not covered under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 (VEA) for their service in Japan:
(1) Why is there a discrepancy between the two statements and which is correct.
(2) Which date has the Department been applying when assessing eligibility for compensation.
(3) How many Australians who served in the BCOF are not covered under the VEA for their service.
(4) Of those who are not covered under the VEA, how many are covered under the Commonwealth Employees' Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The answer provided in response to Question No 2188 gave information for eligibility under the VEA and this is the correct answer. That is, a permanent member of the Defence Force who enlisted prior to 3 January 1949 is eligible under the VEA for disability pension in respect of service in Japan as part of the BCOF.
The answer provided in response to Question No 1720 was incorrect. The Department of Veterans' Affairs regrets this.

(2) The Department has been applying the relevant date appropriate at the time. That is, prior to the introduction of the VEA in 1986, the legislation required enlistment prior to 1 July 1947. After 1986, the VEA required enlistment and service with BCOF in Japan, prior to 3 January 1949.
