TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 16 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: Should petrol company subsidies for regular substantial discounting of petrol in metropolitan areas be extended to rural areas in the light of significant price differences between rural and metropolitan areas; if so, what measures will be taken to ensure that oil company subsidies to metropolitan petrol stations and their customers are extended to rural retail outlets and their customers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The Prices Surveillance Authority has conducted regional fuel pricing investigations, and has observed that there are usually legitimate reasons why some markets have lower retail fuel prices than others. In the PSA's view, price variations can, in the majority of cases be attributed to the normal operation of competitive market forces.

While differences between rural and metropolitan petrol prices can be expected as a result of freight costs, in the past year or so price variations have been, as the Honourable Senator suggests, exacerbated by the extent of discounting by oil companies at the wholesale level. The PSA influences petrol prices by endorsing a maximum wholesale price for each company, but it has no power to stipulate when, where or by how much oil companies should discount their petrol.

Discounting has occurred mainly in major capital city markets, and certain strategic locations on highways, and has largely resulted from strong competition initiated by aggressive independents. Pump price competition can lead to reduced gross retail margins, increasing the pressure on oil companies to discount their wholesale prices.

The difficulties inherent in attempting to narrow the city/country price gap are illustrated by events in late 1988, when Shell posted a state wide wholesale rack price which allowed for lower wholesale prices in country areas, thus transferring the benefits of city competition to non-competitive rural areas. In response, many retailers in the country simply increased their profit margin, denying country consumers the benefit of lower retail prices. Shell's subsequent wholesale pricing approach generally excluded country markets from such discounting.

Regulatory attempts to eliminate price variations between metropolitan and rural areas run the very real risk of eliminating discounting in the city, with no benefit to country people. In the Government's view this would be an unacceptable result. The Government considers that the most appropriate measures to address regional variations lie in preserving retail competition to the extent possible, through the provisions of the Trade Practices Act, and in exerting pressure on oil companies through the Prices Surveillance Act, to adopt reasonable wholesale prices.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 27 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the best estimate of the percentage of Australian women affected by osteoporosis.
(2) What is the best estimate of the percentage of Australian men affected by osteoporosis.
(3) What is the best estimate of the annual cost to the community of osteoporosis.
(4) What is the best estimate of the percentage of total Commonwealth health expenditure devoted annually to osteoporosis in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) & (2) A workshop of osteoporosis experts, convened by the Deputy Prime Minister and the then Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, the Hon. Brian Howe MP, was held on 14 August 1992. One of the issues the workshop considered was the significance of osteoporosis in Australia in terms of its incidence and costs. The workshop reviewed available data sources and concluded that it was difficult to estimate accurately the extent of osteoporosis in Australia because of the lack of comprehensive national data. It was agreed that osteoporosis could affect up to one in three Australian women and a smaller proportion of men. It was also noted that two community-based studies which are being conducted would provide more direct estimates of the incidence and costs of osteoporosis in Australia: namely the Dubbo Osteoporosis Study and the Geelong Study.
(3) On the annual cost of osteoporosis to the Australian community, the osteoporosis workshop noted that this had been estimated as ranging from $200 million to $500 million.

Currently, the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) Working Party on Preventive Activities in the Health Care System is undertaking, as part of its activities, a systematic costing of the proportion of health expenditure in Australia attributable to particular health conditions including osteoporosis. The Working Party was formed in 1990 to develop a guide on preventive activities for distribution to all medical practitioners and other health care providers. The project will provide comprehensive and up-to-date estimates of the costs of osteoporosis in Australia.

(4) Estimates of total Commonwealth Government health expenditure by area of expenditure (e.g. hospitals, medical services, pharmaceuticals, nursing homes etc.) are collated annually by the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare. However, differences in definitions and collection and reporting arrangements make it difficult to derive overall estimates of Commonwealth expenditure on particular diseases such as osteoporosis. In the case of osteoporosis, the problem is exacerbated because of difficulties in diagnosing the disease and its associated fractures.

The costing framework being developed by the NHMRC Working Party on Preventive Activities will provide a firmer base than is currently available for deriving estimates of the Commonwealth and other government health expenditure on osteoporosis and other health conditions.

(4) When the program is fully implemented, how many Australians will be screened annually.
(5) Will all Australians be eligible to receive a Medicare rebate for bone densitometry tests or will eligibility for the rebate be limited in some way; if so, how will it be limited.
(6) Will the program target a particular group of Australians; if so, how will it target them.
(7) Will the Medicare rebate cover the full cost of bone densitometry tests; if not, what percentage of the total cost of the testing will it cover.
(8) Will the Government provide annual reports on the number and characteristics of Australians claiming the Medicare rebate for bone densitometry tests.
(9) How will the Government monitor the program.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. In the 1993-94 Budget, the Government has committed funds to improve access to bone densitometry testing through the provision of a Medicare rebate. As funding arrangements for bone densitometry testing will be provided through the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS), cost-sharing arrangements with the States and Territories are not applicable.

(2) The Government is not intending to establish a population-based screening program using bone densitometry testing. Osteoporosis experts in Australia and overseas agree that bone densitometry, a test for measuring bone density, is not an effective screening tool for developing osteoporosis. Experts, however, agree that bone densitometry is a valuable test in the diagnosis and management of established osteoporosis and other bone density related conditions. It is on this basis that the Government will improve access to bone densitometry testing in Australia.

(3) The specification of a Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) item(s) for bone densitometry has been referred to the Medicare Benefits Advisory Committee (MBAC) for advice. MBAC is an independent statutory body of medical practitioners which advises the Government on the application of Medicare benefits to specified health services.

In providing a Medicare rebate for bone densitometry, the Government is keen to ensure that the technology is used appropriately. Consequently, MBAC advice has also been sought on the safeguards required to promote appropriate and quality use of the technology, on suitable supporting information to be provided to the medical profession and consumers and on monitoring the implementation of the MBS item(s).
Introduction of the MBS item(s) is dependent on MBAC advice. It is anticipated that this will occur in the next three months.
(4) The specific conditions and, therefore, number of Australians to benefit from the provision of an MBS item(s) for bone densitometry is dependent on MBAC advice.
(5) Eligibility for the Medicare rebate for bone densitometry testing is dependent on MBAC advice.
(6) This is dependent on MBAC advice.

(7) Through the MBS, the Commonwealth subsidises medical services provided by private practitioners on a fee-for-service basis by covering 85 per cent of the MBS fees for private out-of-hospital services and 75 percent for private in-hospital services. MBAC is providing advice on MBS fee(s) to apply to bone densitometry testing.
(8) Annual statistics on the use of the items listed under the MBS are available routinely from the Medicare statistical systems.
(9) The Government will monitor closely the use of the MBS item(s) for bone densitometry. MBAC advice on the best way of monitoring item(s) usage has been sought.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories, upon notice, on 28 September 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why is there a delay in obtaining details pertaining to specific mortality rates for koalas in Japanese zoos as referred to in part (6) of the answer to Senate Question on Notice No. 341 (Senate Hansard, 30 August 1993, p.608)
(2) When will the answer be forthcoming.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) & (2) The information sought from Japanese zoo authorities to enable a response was received on 12 October 1993. The advice received indicates that from October 1984 to December 1992 eight Japanese zoos had received a total of 48 koalas from Australia. The zoos had recorded 58 births and 29 deaths during this period, and at December 1992 77 koalas were held in captivity.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 5 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Will the Minister confirm that Mr John Doohan of Willagee, Western Australia wrote to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on 22 September 1993, referring the Prime Minister to the sinking of HMAS Sydney in November 1941 and seeking confirmation of the following matters: (a) did Fleet Radio Unit Melbourne (FRUMEL) intercept and/or decode signals to or from the raider Kormoran before, during or after the alleged 19 November 1941 action between HMAS Sydney and HSK Kormoran; (b) did the foreign government referred to in a letter from Mr R. Summerrell, Assistant Director, Legislation and Policy Development, Access and Client Services Section titled `Statement of Reasons Pursuant to Section 40 of the Archives Act' of 6 March 1992, intercept or decode signals to or from the Kormoran before, during or after the alleged action between HMAS Sydney and HSK Kormoran on 19 November 1941; and (c) were the codes or cyphers intercepted by FRUMEL or the foreign government, as described, solely German codes and cyphers.

(2) As publication of such information may increase public understanding of the loss of HMAS Sydney, how would the publication of material relating to actions which occurred in 1941 reasonably be expected to threaten Australia's national security in 1993.

(3) Did Mr Doohan's letter further refer the Prime Minister to a signal from Australian Naval Board to Admiralty 117, C in C China on 25 November 1941, and in particular to the following matters relating to such signal: (a) was the original signal transmitted to the addressee as purported in the copy in archives; (b) in the message original, were the `Time of Origin' and `Date and Time Sent' identical with the `Time or Origin' and `Date and Time Sent' as they appear in the copy made available to Mr Doohan; if not, why not; (c) if the original of the message and the copy concur as to `Time of Origin' and `Date and Time Sent', were those times and dates as accurate as one should expect such officially important instructions to be in the circumstances; if not, why not; and (d) if so, to (b) and (c), can the Prime Minister explain how it was possible to send such instructions to Admiralty 117 in view of the fact that important events described in the original message and in the copy provided did not occur until many hours after the transmission of the message.

(4) In relation to the four Chinese survivors of the alleged Sydney/Kormoran action, was one of the Chinese landed with German survivors on a beach at or about Red Bluff, north of Carnarvon, Western Australia; if so, what became of this Chinese survivor after his rescue.

(5) Did another three Chinese survivors from the Kormoran land at Fremantle; if so, were they at any time quartered in a Commonwealth administered hospital then known as Davies Road Mental Hospital, Claremont, Western Australia and what became of these three Chinese survivors after their landing and possible hospitalisation.
(6) Were all the Chinese survivors of the Kormoran interrogated about the Sydney/Kormoran action; if not, why not.
(7) If the Chinese survivors were so interrogated, where are their statements, particularly that of `Shu' Ah Fah.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: I have nothing further to add to my earlier replies, printed in Senate Hansard on 20 May 1993 (p1059) and 27 September 1993 (pp1237-38).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 5 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the reference to the termination of funding for the Resource Assessment Commission (RAC) on page 3.132 of the 1993-94 Budget Paper No. 1 mean that the Government has decided to shut down the commission; if so, what are the reasons for this decision.
(2) In view of the importance of the work of the RAC, why has the Minister not seen fit to announce this decision appropriately.

(3) What is the timetable for the shutting down of the RAC and what arrangements are being made to ensure that expertise in the analysis of significant resource use issues built up in the commission since 1989 is not lost.
(4) Does the Government's decision represent a significant change in policy towards the way major resource use issues are to be considered in Australia in the future.

(5) What is the Minister's response to the comment in the report, published on page 46 of the New Scientist of 21 August 1993, that, as a result of the abolition of the commission, future resource-use decisions in Australia will be `less visible and, in the current jargon, less transparent'.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, the Government has terminated the Resource Assessment Commission's (RAC) administrative functions while retaining the RAC legislation to provide for flexibility should an inquiry reference be appropriate at a later date. Since the RAC was established there have been significant developments that have enabled the Commonwealth to integrate consideration of economic and environmental priorities for natural resource allocation in co-operation with the States and in consultation with conservation and industry groups, including through the Intergovernmental Agreement on the Environment. Nationally coordinated policy developments such as the National Strategy for Ecologically Sustainable Development, the National Forest Policy Statement and the National Greenhouse Response Strategy have removed much of the need for a Commonwealth-based inquiry agency. The Commonwealth also has a wide range of investigatory and general inquiry bodies including under the Environment Protection (Impact of Proposals) Act 1974 through the Commonwealth Environment Protection Authority (CEPA), the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) and the Industry Commission (IC).
(2) The decision was included appropriately in the Government's overall budget documentation.

(3) The Resource Assessment Commission establishment will be terminated from 31 December 1993 following completion of the Coastal Zone Inquiry. The Government is working to ensure that core resources are transferred to complementary agencies.

(5) No changes to the way in which resource-use decisions are to be made are indicated by the termination of funding for the RAC. The RAC was established to provide advice to the Prime Minister on resource-use issues. The Government has retained the RAC legislation to allow for the possibility of any future inquiry references. Other inquiry agencies such as CEPA, the IC and ASTEC also have the capacity to undertake environmental resource inquiries when the need arises.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 5 October 1993:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that the estimates for maintenance and technical services for Rolls Royce Dart engines and components between July 1993 and December 1995 is $3 million.
(2) Is this work being carried out by Air New Zealand Ltd.
(3) Was this work put to tender.
(4) What other companies submitted a tender.
(5) What were the costs submitted by these companies.
(6) Are there any Australian companies that are capable of supplying this product; if so, why were their tenders not accepted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes.

(3) No, it was not put to tender. The Air New Zealand contract for Dart engine overhaul for the Australian Defence Force fell due for renewal in 1993. A new Standing Offer was negotiated with Air New Zealand in July 1993 without putting out Requests for Tenders on the basis of satisfactory performance, value for money and the fact that Air New Zealand is now the only company in the Australia/New Zealand area offering Dart engine maintenance facilities.
(4) Unsolicited offers were received from Rolls Royce, Scotland and an engineering company in India.

(5) Detail in regard to costs submitted by companies is commercial-in-confidence. However, both the offers from Rolls Royce, Scotland and an engineering company in India were more expensive than that from Air New Zealand.

(6) Several Australian companies could possibly develop a capability of supplying this service. However, to our knowledge, there are currently no Australian companies with Dart aero engine overhaul experience, equipment or capability. Requests for Tender for this contract were not issued because of sole contractor availability within Australia/New Zealand.
